The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:John is studying animals.   What is one of the many things he has to watch them doing? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n>Output:		John is studying animals and one of the many things they do is mate.<n>So the final thing John had to watch them doing was E: Copulate<n><n>Input: What is the cost of the entire meal served to the family?<n><n>Output: The total cost of the meal = A =$20+$20+$36+$40.25+$12.37+$5.14 = <<$20+20+36+40.25+12.37+=47.66>>$47.66<n><n>Output: A =$20+22+32+40.28+12.48= $<<20+22=20+22>>20 + 22<n><n>Input: How many more dollars does Betsy have than Ashley?<n><n>Output: There isn't enough information to answer this question. Maybe there is another pair of students who also have $15.<n><n>Input: What's greater: 5 apples, or 11 bananas?<n><n>Output: 11 bananas<n><n>Input: A: apple B: banana C: pineapple (1): 5 Apples 10 Bananas 32 Pineapples. <n>Which is more?<n><n>Output: bananas<n><n>Input A:  The number of dollars it costs to buy two bottles of water B: 20 <n><n>Output: 20<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What do only some types of police do? Choices:  A: direct traffic B: board vessels C: arm themselves D: help people E: find drugs<n>Output:		A: direct traffic B: none of these C: none of these D: only some types of police E: board vessels<n>Answer the following question.<n>What do some types of police do that other types don't?<n>F: help people G: arm themselves<n>So the final answer for answer choice F, which is G, is 4<n><n>Input: The restaurant owner wants to buy 240 hamburgers. The average cost of the burgers is $5.75 each.<n>However, the delivery driver wants to buy burgers at a lower price of $5.00 each.<n>How much would the delivery driver save by making the burgers cheaper?<n><n>Output: We need to work out what the difference in price would be.<n>The restaurant owner will pay $5.75 for each hamburger = <<5.75>>5.75<n>The driver will pay $5 instead of $5.75 = <<5,>>5)<n>The difference in price is $0.75 = <<0.75>>0.75<n><n>In the answer choices, we can see that there are many similar numbers and we just multiply by different factors. Choices are: 1x, 1.5x, 1.25x, 2.5x, 4x<n>So the final answer of 1.25 would be the answer. So A or D.<n><n>---<n><n>Input: The grocery store is having a sale. A bag of apples in the store costs $1.25 and an apple pie is $4.00.  The shopkeeper wants to sell two bags of apples and 3 apple pies for $6.25. After the sale, they have to charge $10.75 for 5 apples. If the storekeeper knows that each apple pie uses 1.5 apples and each apple costs $1.26, how can you help them figure out how much they spent on apples?<n><n>Output: The shopkeeper bought 2 + 3 = <<2+3=5>>5 bags of apples at $0.126 each = <<5*0.126=6.30>>6.30<n>She also bought 3 apple pies = <<3>>3<n>So overall they spent 6.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:She'd sooner just spray herself with water than the what she didn't like the smell of? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What would a person do if he or she wanted to get good grades? Choices:  A: feel proud B: try to learn C: need assistance D: thank god E: read alot<n>Output:		The choices are: <n>A: pride<n>B: try<n>C: assistance<n>D: thank god<n>E: read <n>The person needs to be aware of pride, trying, assistance, and thank god and read to do good in school.<n>So the final answere is D<n><n>Input: When is there no solution to the equation 4x+2=6x-3?<n>Output: Choices:<n>A: One choice is to make the statement false by making 6x-3 greater than 4x<n>B: Two choices are to make 4x+2 greater than 6x-3 or to make 4x-2 less than 6x-1<n>C: Choice is to make 6x-3 less than 4x+2.<n>D: Choice is to add 1 to both sides of the equation. This makes 4x+2 = 4x+3<n>E: Choice is to subtract 1 from both sides of the equation, giving 4x+2 > 6x-3.<n>Since there are 6 choices, D is the answer.<n><n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What can happen in your mind while sleeping? Choices:  i) the bumpers hit b) the cars knock each other ii) the cars push apart c) both vehicles move d) neither vehicle moves<n>Output: Answer B because pushing against another object causes the object to push back.<n><n><n>Input: If A+C=D and B+D=F, how big is B?<n>Output: Answer B) = D, because the numbers on each side of the two equalities must equal.<n><n>Input: You have a box with n coins. The n-th coin has value $n$, the (n-1)-th coin has 95% the value of the n-th coin, the (n-2)-th coin has 75% the value of each coin in the 1st and 2nd sets, the 3rd set... has 20% the value of the original coin. If you flip all coins, how much money do you have in your box?<n>Output: Answer A) n(n-1)(n-2)...(2) because every successive coin is worth $n*(n-1)*(n-2)*...*3*2*1), and flipping all coins results in $n(n-1)(...(2)) total money when it is all added together. <n><n>Input: If 2^x=A and 3^x=B, what is x? <n>Output: x = Log_2 3.  B^x= (2^x)^2=(2x)^2 = ((2^x)*2)^x = A^x*(2)^x = A*(2)^x because A=2^x and B=3^x and (2)^x=A and (2)^x also=B. <n><n>Input : A dog was walking with a man, and the dog started drooling. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: mountain dew B: glass C: soft drink D: whirlpool bath E: coffee cup<n>Output:		Choices are mountain dew, glass, soft drink, whirlpool bath, and coffee cup.  So mountain dew is the only beverage that contains water<n>So the final answer must be Mountain Dew<n><n>Input: The sum of three consecutive integers is 21. If one of the integers is 4 less than twice the other one, what is the greatest possible value of the third integer?<n>Output: The sum of three integers could be greater or smaller than the largest number in the set of three; in this case, smaller.<n>If we choose two consecutive integers (2 integers that follow one after the other) and let one of them be 4 less than twice their combined value, then our third integer will be:<n>2n+1+2 = 2 × (n+1)<n>So the final answer will be 21 + 21 + 4 + 2 = 21 + 62 + 4 = <<21+62+4=88>>88
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What divider stores papers for work or school? Choices:  A: street B: binder C: obesity D: living room E: office suite<n>Output:		Office suite<n><n>Input: An apple costs $0.89 per pound, and there are 4 pounds in a bushel. How much does a bushel of apples cost, per bushel?<n>Answer: $<<0.89/4=0.222>>0.222<n><n>Input:If the first digit is 3: The next digit is 6. What is the first digit?<n>Output:9<n><n>Input:What is the next number in the sequence: 1,9,17,25,33,41,49,57,65,73,81?<n>Input: 55<n><n>Input:What are the first four multiples of 6?<n>Output:6,6 x 2 = 12,6 x 3 = 18,6 x 4 = 24<n><n>Input:Find the sum: 14+10+11+19<n>Output: 44<n><n>Input:Add five consecutive numbers and show in expanded form: 21, 22, 23, 24, 25<n>Output: 21 + 22 + 23 + 24 + 25 = <<21+22+23+24+25=110>>110<n><n>Input:(38–4<sup>2</sup>)<n>Output:14<n><n>Input:What number do I add to both sides of the equation x<sup>3</sup> + 7x = 17 to get all positive numbers?<n>Output: 5<n><n>Input:If 3 ÷ 8 = 0.375; 2 = 0.176; 2/3 = 0.4166630; 4/3 = 1.45; 3/4 = 3.351811; and 4 = 1, what is the sum?<n>Output: 0.422424224224<n><n>Input:(x+5)/(x-2)*(x-7)/(x-3)=9<n>Output: -/-<n><n>Input:If there are 3+4 blue balls and 3 red balls, what is the
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would one find a captive monkey? It has a monkey in the gorilla pit.<n><n>Zoological is scientific study of animals in captivity<n><n>The great outdoors is an outdoor, natural environment that doesn't have a roof or walls, and animals can roam freely. They can also be found in zoos and it is an animal park.<n><n>So the final answer will be A: rain forest<n><n>Input: A family of five has spent $120 at a supermarket on food and personal items. Also she runs four miles in 4/3 of an hour
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If the number of students in every other group is two less than the number in the first group, what are the names of all four groups?<n>Output: The number of students in every group is seven less than the first group. When you see the first group has a number is seventeen, you should find 7 + 4 - 0 = <7+4-0=3>>3.<n>Then the answer of question three is fourteen. Next look 14 - 7 = <<14-7=7>>7.<n>If the group has a name is seven, you need to find seventeen - seven = <17-7=10>> 10.<n>Then the answer for seventeen is ten.<n>For next question fourteen, you still using the same method with the answer is seven. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:You are seeking to provide yourself what when you're applying for a job? Choices:  A: work B: employment C: income D: hope E: offer<n>Output:		A <n><n>Input:Which day in the month has 28 days?<n>Output: Monday, because it is 3rd after Sunday<n><n>Input: If I have two brothers and a sister, how many siblings would I have?<n>Output: Three. Counts up from zero.<n><n>Input:There are two teams – one with 3 players and the other with 5. The score for each team is equal when both teams are playing. How many different games can two teams of this size play?<n>Output: 4 different game possibilities because each player could be on one of the 3-player or 5-player team.<n><n>Input: There are two kinds of cookies: chocolate chip and oatmeal. The ratio of chocolate chips to oatmeal is 5:7. If you purchase 13 chocolate chips, how many will you end up having?<n>Output: There are:<n>Chocolate Chip: 5 + (5/7)*13 = 8<n>Oatmeal Cookies: 7 + (7/7)*13<n>So the total cookies = 5+8+7 = 1 < 8><n>This  means that  we have 13 choc chip and 5 oatmeal cookies<n>So the final answer could be 30<n><n>Input:There's a box of 12 donuts. Three of the donuts are chocolate; 7 are jelly. How many jelly donuts would I get if I take 5 of the donuts at random?<n>Output: If we look at the first step, we take 5, so we take 5 chocolate and 7 jelly. Take away the chocolate would be 5+7+5 = <<5+7+5=17>>17<n>If we multiply by 3, we get 17*3 = 51. So all of the jelly donuts.<n>So the final answers could be 51<n><n>Input: The number of people in a family is equal to the number of years since the youngest child was born. The sum of their ages is 99. How many years ago was the youngest child born?<n>Output: The youngest child was born in (19 + 19) years ago which is 3
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. How many pieces of pizza did each customer get?<n>Output: The pizza shop had 7+6+6+4+2 = <<7+6+6=16>>16 pieces of pizza.<n>Since they gave 16 per 5 people, each person got 16 ÷ 5 = <<16/5=3>>3<n>So the final answer 3<n><n>Input: A man needs to pay for 3 different pizzas. Alice planned to buy a dresser for $150, a lamp for $120, and a matching throw rug for $50. If she doesn't have enough money to purchase all of the items, how could she break the remaining money evenly between them?<n>Output: Let x = remaining $ to purchase items:  She planned on buying a dresser for $x dollars, a lamp for $x/2, and a rug for x/3, so x = 200 x = 20(10) = $200<n>She can buy the dresser for $10, the lamp for $6, and the throw rug for $4. So she spends a total of $20 + $6 + $4 = $234, and has $6 left over.<n>So the final decision is x/2 = (x) / 2 = x / 3, giving a total of $2x/5 = $12.<n>So the final money left over is $6, and the final answer is x/2 = 60<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question:<n><n>Input : The 360º compass has 360 different points, so how many degrees does the 180º compass have?<n>Output : There are 360 different degrees between 0º and 360º, so the 180 degrees comes from 180/360 = << 180/ 360 = 1/2>>1/2 of those degrees.<n>The 180º degree compass has 180º - 1/2 = << 18(0.5) - (1.5) = 1.5>>118º<n>So the final answer 118º<n><n>### Instruption :Answer the following multiple choice questions<n><n>Input: In each row, choose the number that appears three times.

How many families had two or more cars?<n>Output:The number of drivers doesn't matter, since they are not families. Only the cars matter.<n>So to count the families with two or more cars, count how many cars there are, use division to figure out how many groups with 2 or more cars there are, and then sum those groups with 2 or cars.<n>Use 412/2 cars = <<412/2=206>>206<n>So we have 206 groups of two or more cars<n>Then 206+206= <<206+26=412>>412 = total number of families<n>So the final answer 412/412=1<n><n>Input:Which month has 29 days?<n>Output:February, since it's the only month that has 29 and is on the calendar<n><n>Input:What color is an octopus? 1) blue 2) purple 3) brown<n>Output:Octopuses are not actually one particular color. If the average bad experience will cost your friend $25, what is the worst-case situation for your friend?<n>Output: The ticket price is $50<n>3 ways to get the result: A: Investing 0 time.<n>B: Investing 30 days.<n>C: Investing 1 day.<n>A and C are the same, so the average time invested is 30/2 = <<30/2=15>>15 days<n>The percentage of winning is 25/100 = 25%, or 0.25<n>The chances that it’s a good event is 0.71 = 1 - 0.75 = 1-0.75<n>His chance to lose is 1-0.075 = <<1-0.745>>1945/50<n>The percent of losing is 39.25.<n>The worst case: The sum of all events happening is the chance of winning with multiplied with the cost of winning, and the chance of losing with the cost of losing.<n>The sum of all events is the chance of winning 0.25 * 25 = <<0.25*25=6.25>>6.25 + the chance of losing 1945/70 = <<1945/2=972.5>>972.5<n>So the final answer would be 972.5 + 6.25 + 1945 = <<972.5+6.25+1945=2014>>2014<n>So the answer is 2014.<n><n>Input: A friend has a dog that weighs 6 pounds.  If the family has one more dog, what is the probability that the combined pounds will
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where can you get a stray small dog? Choices:  A: living room B: animal shelter C: georgia D: pet shop E: dog show<n>Output:		The answer is C, because Dogs are known to come out of nowhere and find their way into your life. Even if you are careful not to disturb a stray, they will take the initiative. We call this phenomenon the “dog effect”, referring to the tendency for someone to seek out a new relationship if he or she finds themselves in need of one. The “dog effect” is used to describe the propensity for people to seek out a relationship if they find themselves in need of one, regardless of whether or not they intend to stay in a particular relationship<n><n>Input: What is 28 + 72 + 35 + 13 + 52?<n>Output: The sum of the first set of numbers is 28. If we add this 28 to the second set of numbers, we get:<n>28 + 75 =<<28+75=103>>103<n>Adding 103 to the third set of numbers, we now have:<n>103 + 72 +13 + 48 + 7<n>103 +72 +13+48+7 =<<72+13+48=14+7>>14+7<n>Since we have one number left over, we will add this number to the fourth set of numbers, giving us:<n>14+7+13+45+52 =<<14+7+32=31+52>>31+52<n>Adding this sum to the fifth set of numbers we end up with:<n>31+52+13+30+58 =<<31+58=39+52>>39+52<n>At this point, we no longer have any numbers left over, so the answer to your question is:<n>39+52=<<39+52!=79>>79<n>So the final answer will always be 79<n><n>Input: What expression must you enter above to get 541?<n>Output:<n>The answer is C 541<n>Since the question 541 is already given input, enter:<n>Answer 541<n>So the answer will be 541.<n><n>Input: What number to I multiply by 216 to get 64
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Choices:  A: amusement park B: urban area C: airport D: shopping malls E: train station<n>Output:		There is two correct answers at D and E<n>D because of shopping mall is in the airport and the airport in the train station which is in E<n>E because of the airport is the train station and the train station in the amusement park<n>So the final answer should be E and D<n><n>Input:The 6th word is the middle of the word. Find the middle of "ababcd."<n>Output: First we need to find the length of the string, because we know it is 5 numbers then we have this as the first step, so we start with 6 + (6/2) = <<6+6/2=10>>1 which is the length <n>The middle is 1 + (1/2) = <<1+1/2=1.5>>, and the string is 10 = <<10>>10<n>Then we need to find the range, (7-1) = <<7-1=6>> then there must be 3 digits after the decimal point which is 1.5 = 1.5 + 3/10 = <<1.5+3/10=1.6>>1.63<n>We also need to do this process again, (6-1.63) = <<6-1.6=4.37>>, (4.37-1) = 3.37 = <<3.37>>3.37<n>And (3.37-1.5) = (2.87) = <<2.8>>2.8<n>And (2.87-1.53) = (1.34) = <<1.3>>1.3<n>So the final answer for the word "ababcd" is 1.3<n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:James used the cannon to shoot at something while seeking lunch. It was overkill.  What did he shoot at? Choices:  A: body armor B: ungulate C: bomber D: kill people E: animal<n>Output:		James used the cannon to seek lunch.  He shot at an unknown animal, but it was overkill.<n>So the final answers is animal<n><n>Input: How many animals are standing 10 meters away from the house? Choices:  1: None 2: Only one 3: One 4: Two 5: Three 6: More than three<n>Output: There aren’t any, they are far away.<n>So the final answe is 1<n><n>Input: There are exactly 7 red balls or 7 green balls in the box. What is the probability of picking 2 green balls in one pick?<n>Output: Let R be the event of picking a red ball, and let G be the event of pick a green. We want to know Pr(R | G), and to compute this we need to know Pr(G).<n><n>The event G occurs whenever the pick is a green ball, so Pr(G) = 7/14<n><n>Pr(R|G) = Pr(R and G)/Pr(G)  (The intersection of two events.)<n><n>Pr(R and G) = Pr(R) * Pr(G)<n><n>Using the 7/4 formula (red = 7, green = 4) we have<n><n>Pr(R) = 7/8, which = 1/4<n><n>Pr(G) = 4/7, which = 16/14<n><n>So to finalize we have this equation, which equals the final answer 7/14 (to the nearest tenth)<n><n>(1/4)(7/8)*16/(14) = 7/44<n><n>Input: After a certain number of moves, all games in Othello (Reversi) end in a draw. How many moves are needed for this to happen?<n>Output: In Othello, your turn is to flip a coin. When it lands on tails, you get to make the next move. When it lands on heads, your opponent gets to make their next move. As long as you have the coin, you have more turns to play than your opponent.<n>This means you must win, right? Or more specifically, you must not draw. After this, your opponent is forced to draw.<n><n>We are allowed to flip a coin 3 turns

The menu has ten items  and costs $5 for every item and you are paying for yourself. How much will you pay? Choices: D=7A: D=0 B: D=5 C: D=134 D: D=115 D: D=135<n>Output:If you pay $7, your total bill will be $0 since this is one item.<n>$5 for every item and we already pay for ourselves ($5 * 1 = $5), so $5 + 5 = 10 is the total bill.<n>$5 for the first item only, which means you will pay $5 + 0, the total bill = $5<n><n>Input:The cost of a pair of shoes is $175 plus 14% tax.  Determine how much tax is?  Answer choices: D: $160 E: $130 F: $35 G: $225<n>Output:The cost of a shoe is initially $175. 14% Tax of total = $
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The window of the Honda was hit from the inside, not the outside. Where was most of the the broken glass found? Choices:  A: bridge B: in spain C: beach D: field E: street<n>Output:		If the broken glass is found inside the Honda, then it must have been hit from the inside not from the outside, so the best answer is: A bridge<n>So the final answer must be A (bridge)<n><n>Input: How much does each box of 12 cookies cost? Choices: A: 12 cents B: 10 cents C: 21 cents D: 13 cents E: 24 cents<n>Output: Cookies costs 21 cents because C = <<21>>21 cents<n>So the final answer for this is C (21 cents)<n><n><n>Input: Which expression is divisible by 9?A: 8 times B: 2 times C: 11 times D: 3 times E: 7 times<n>Output: If the expression that is being divided is divisible by 11 then it must be divisible by 9 which must be divisible 11 (C is divisible by 6=<<1/11=B; 3/11=D; 7/11=E>>3)<n>So the answer must be B (8 times) because C isn't divisible as well<n><n>Input: Mr. Martinez gave the students a test. Each student failed except one. One student passed the test. How many students took the test if 10% passed?<n>Output: Students who passed has a total markings of 1 because of 0.10 = 0.1 <n>and Students who failed has a total markings A = 100-0.1 = 99.9<n>So one student passed which means the total number of failing students which includes the student who passed is<n>A+ 1 = <<A+1=99.9+1=100>>100 students.<n>The Total number of students who took the test is A+B=100 + 100 = <<100+100=200>>102 students.<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What creatures performing pollination are loved my millions? Choices:  A: birds B: action C: butterflies D: happiness E: anxiety<n>Output:		Millions is to create a plural form of million so here the answer will be A and the final answer is A<n><n>Input: The answer is 100, What number does it multiply to form 100?<n>Output: Final answer: is B. Here in question it is asking what number does it multiply to, so the choices <n>are a:5 b:3 c:2 d:1, so the answer is b<n><n>Input:How many different values can the variable x take?<n>Output: x can take all values, so the answer is A. Final answer A.<n><n>Input: In a baking class, there are 4 boys and 3 girls. They decide to make individual cakes in pairs. How many 3-layer cakes can they make?<n>Output: There are 4 boys in the class and 3 girls and when they are paired in groups, they cannot be together<n>so there are 4 boys divided in two groups of 2 = B and 3 girls divided in two groups of girls,<n>they can also in one group of girls (C), because 3 girls can make one cake so overall 4 groups of boys and 3 with one girls group can make 3 - layered cake. So the choice A and the final answer I is A.<n><n>Input:"Even though the cost of a video game is $25.00, you can find one with a sale price of only $15.00." ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Deciding to watch tv or play with your cell phone might be a routine but they provide no help in being able to do what? Choices:  A: have tv B: fall asleep C: learn D: sitting E: dancing<n>Output:		Watching TV might help you fall asleep. But TV will not help you learn things when you are watching TV. Your cell phone in your hand does not help you sit down or stand up. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If you're standing in line and the line isn't moving what might you feel? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If a person wants to buy a radio, where are they likely to go? Choices:  A: station B: every car and house C: shop D: bedroom E: space shuttle<n>Output:		I am going to choose shop because shop is the only choice that is not a person.<n><n>Input:I used this algorithm to build this web site called https://github.com/bhj5981/P037 and I am also learning how to code with Python and C. <n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Learning usually leads to greater what? Choices:  A: get to know B: gain knowledge C: intelligence D: education E: gaining knowledge<n>Output:		The option ‘c’ is correct.<n><n>Input:Mario was a big brother who was 9 years older than his younger sister.  Their total age was 11 years.  How old is Mario’s younger sister?<n>Output: The boy who is 9 years older than another boy, we should add 9 years to the 2nd person’s age, then - add 11 (their total age) to this, so 8 should be subtracted from 11 (total age), so this person’s age = 3.<n><n>Input:You can make the difference between 21% of a number and 1/5 of another number using what? Choices:1. division 2. subtraction 3. division and subtraction 4. multiplication 5. addition<n>Output: Add + = <n><n><n><n><n><n><form id="f1"><n><n>    <input type="hidden" id="opm" value="<?= $opm;?>"><n>    <n>    <div class="" id=""><n>    <n>        <p id="m">1+2=<p><n><n>    </div><n><n>    <nav><n>        <div class="nav-item"><n>            <span class="nav-link active">1</span><n>        </div><n><n>        <div class = "nav-item"><n>        <span class="nav"><a href="#">2</a></span><n>        </di ><n><n>        <div><n>            <img src="/img/next.svg" id="nexti"><n>            <img src="" id="navigate"><n>        </div> <n><n>        <div type= "submit" class="btn" id="btn">Go To Next </div><n><n><n>    </nav> <!-- /.nav-inner --><n><n><n></form> <!-- /form-1--><!-- /form-1--><n><n><n><n><n></body><n><n><script><n>    let next = document.getElementById("navigate");<n>    let page = 1;<n><n>    function getPage() {<n>        let id = document.getElementById("opm").value;<n>        page = Number(id).toString(2);<n>        let prev = page - 1;<n>        let nextId = `opm-${prev
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Illegitimate designer handbags will not have a certificate of what? Choices:  A: actions B: legal C: authentic D: logical E: legitimate<n>Output:		Illegitimate is the same word as fake and so this question is antonym for legitimate, which means authentic. Choices: A: midnightB: afternoonC: noon D: dawnE: twilight<n>Output:The time of the day most likely for fireworks to occur is actually during the daytime as the sun is out. The time of the day called twilight occurs after the sun sets in the early evening and before the sun rises at dawn. So the final answer would be D<n><n>Input:The distance between the two cities: 11,000 miles Choices: A: is greater thanB: is less than C: is the same asE: is between D: is equal to<n>Output:The distance between the cities is the same as they are both one mile. Choices:  a: even numbers b: negative numbers c: natural numbers d: prime<n>Output: choice of even numbers is the answer<n><n>####Solution<n>```python<n>import math<n><n>def getAge(x, y):<n>    if x > y:<n>        return x-y<n>    elif y>x:<n>        return y-x<n><n>def solveFirstProblem():<n>    x=0<n>    y=0<n>    while x+y < 20:<n>        if x < y:<n>            x=x+1<n>        else:<n>            y=y+1<n>    return min(x,y)<n><n>def solveFirstQuestion():<n>    print("Input: Hurley is 16 years old. How old will he be in 5 years?")<n>    print("output:  Hurley will be 21 in five years")<n>    #code<n>    answer=getAge(solveFirstProblem(),5)<n>    return answer<n><n>def solveSecondProblem():<n>    print(" Input: Pablo read 32, 68, 150, and 220-page books. How long did Pablo have to read each book?")<n>    #code to get the books<n>    booksread=[]<n>    print("booksread = ",booksread)<n>    print("bookslist = ",bookslist)<n>    while bookslist:<n>        if (bookslist[1]%150==0) or (bookslist[1]*bookslist[1]==32) or (bookslist*bookslist)==150 or (bookslist*220==220 or bookslist==68):<n>            print("booksread is ",booksread)<n>            booksread=booksread+[bookslist[1]]<n>        elif(bookslist[1]*220==200):<n>            print("number of books in 220 is ",bookslist)<n>            booksread.append(220)<n><n>    return sum(booksread[::2])<n>def solveSecondQuestion():<n>    c=solveSecondProblem()<n>    print("Input : Pablo’s mother agreed to pay him
