If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What would a person do if he or she just woke up? Choices:  A: drink tea B: thank god C: open eyes D: feel angry E: complete sentence<n>Output:		The person wakes up and first of all, he/she would thank god, then after thanking god, he/she would open his/her eyes and the final step would be to feel angry if he/she is not thankful to god after everything so the final answer is C<n>You will be given a number (n) a string that represents a number n in one of four formats described below.<br> Choose the format that most clearly represents the number of n (not its value).<n><n>1. 000<n>2.100A format of two 4-character groups separated by commas (e.g., 0101, 1203)<n>3.100010<n>4. 1.0103E+16<n>Input:<n>Choose the format that most closely represents n = <<000>>000<n>Think about why your program outputs answer0 is:<n>Because n = 000 (zero three times) and that's the only answer that makes sense<n>Now, consider what other options you explored while creating the program. What additional options did you discard and why did they not appear as a valid answer?<n>I discarded option 3 because the value in it was really big than n.<n>A number is picked randomly, from 1 to 99. The probability of guessing the number is 1/99. If two guessers guessed a number, but did not guess it at the same time, what is the probability that the first guesser guessed it?<n>Input:<n>Chooses a number between 1 and 99 (inclusive)<n>Chooses another number between 1 and the first one, inclusive<n><n>If they choose the same number, it's unlikely (about 1/(1+99^2) or 1/3666).<n>If they choose different numbers, then the probability is 1/98 (about)<n>Think about why it's unlikely that the first guesser correctly guessed the number. In which situations is it more likely for a first guesser to guess the number?<n>Input 3:<n>If they choose the second number 99, it is unlikely to find it, this is because there are 2 number between 1 and second number and therefore the probability will be one of the 2
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What are people playing when they want to take the lead with small papers? Choices:  A: very heavy B: video game C: news article D: card game E: lead pencil<n>Output:		All the answers are correct in some context, but they can all be simplified and grouped together.<n>All the answers are different types of games that require small papers to be played properly.<n>A: A person can play "Rummy" with many different versions <n>B: People play video games using video games and video game controllers.<n>C: A person could read a news article<n>D: A person could play card games with card decks<n>E: A person could use a lead pencil<n>So the final answer can be (A,B,C,D,E).<n><n># Program in Python<n># Python code<n><n>    import sys<n>    from math import answer<n>    sys.stdout = sys.stdout.buffer<n><n>    def number(m, p, n, u):<n>    	if (m<p<=n<=u):<n>    		answer = (((u/2)-(p/2)))+((n-p)/2)<n>    	elif (m<=p<n<=u):<n>        answer = ((u/2)-(m/2))+((n-m)/2)<n>    <n>    while True:<n>        p = int(input("Please enter a number from 1 to 10: \n"))<n>        m = int(input("""Please enter a<n>                        number between 1 and 10: <n>                                 """ ))<n>        n = int (input("What number is between m and p? "))<n>        q = int(input("What number is<n>                       between p and n? "))<n>        u = int (input("""What number is between<n>             n and q? """))<n>        if(answer==0):<n>        	print("It is invalid")<n>        else:<n>        	print(number(m,p,n,u))<n>        if (answer==1):<n>            print("Invalid,please re-enter m or<n>                    n.")<n><n><n><n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What do you fill with ink to print? That is where the ink comes in, with ink you get _____."<n><n>Input:You want to read a new book.  You have three dollars to spend.  You can buy a  textbook or a novel.  Books cost $10 more than nonfiction books.  How much would you have to spend to buy the same book?<n>Output:Start by finding out how much a nonfiction book costs.  $3 - $1 = <<3-1=$2>> $2<n>Nonfiction books cost $10 more, so $10 + $2 = <<10+2=$12>> $12<n>For the same book, you need $12 - $10 = <<$12$-$10=$2>> $2 more<n>So the final answer to buy the same book is $12 - $2 = <<12-2=$10>>$10<n><n>Output: The last few students in John’s class are very quiet. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is a person likely to feel when they are abandoned by everyone after they stop being married to someone else? Choices:  A: grief B: solo C: isolation D: pleasure E: happiness<n>Output:		According to the description "abandoned by everyone after they stop [being] married to someone else", this means this particular relationship has ended.<n>So the best response is "grief" because "Grief is a multifaceted response to loss, particularly to the loss of something or someone upon which the individual has come to rely.<n>So the final correct answer is "D: grief"<n><n>Input: A person is able to pick up an apple that weighs 46 pounds with one arm but is not strong enough to pick up a book that reads one page.  What is the weight of this book? Choices: A: 20 pounds B: 23 pounds C: 14 pounds D: 15 pounds E: 46 pounds<n>Output: "This person is able to pick... one book..."<n>So it must be only one page long.<n>So the book must weigh 46 pounds.<n>So the final correctly is "E: 46 pounds"<n><n>Input: The population at a school has doubled in the last several years. The school administration had 70 new desks made and 30 of the current teachers have to share a classroom because of the additional students. If there are currently 40 desks in the classroom and 10 additional classrooms, how many desks does each teacher currently have?<n>Output: We know that the school administration had 7x30 desks made because the wording of the question is clear- "7x30"<n>We also know that there currently 4x30 desks in this classroom because we have 14 currently, and 40(start) – 70(end) gives us 70 - 70 = 0 which means we have 40 desks right now<n>This means that the word currently means that they still have 40 desk currently<n>Then subtract those 40 desks and the question is 3x30 = 90<n>Which means there are 90 new desks made<n>Then 90/30 = 3<n><n>If there are 3 additional classrooms because the population doubled, that means there are 3x30 desks<n>So 3x30 + 3x30 is 90<n>Then<n>90/30 is 
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:She had a knack for entertaining, everybody told he she had a what? Choices:  A: fun B: talent C: learn about D: intelligence E: recognize<n>Output:		She had lots of people around to entertain with A.  Everybody told her she had a what?  B. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. De los números pares posteriores a 756 es 69092. ¿Cuáles son los números pares que son consecutivos y cuáles los números pares separados?<n><n>La solución es 143, 231, 461, 851, 971, 1847, 1967, 3801, 4929, 5895, 6401, 6829, 6997, 7 9623, 8 8661, 9 9237, 6 35209, 235377, 464467, 692799, 852579, 975399, 1826797, 1959879, 3790324381 (El primer dígito es 3, luego de 24, por lo que el segundo dígito deben ser 3 + 4 = 7, luego no queda otra opción, porque, la última cadena 81 tiene 10, que hace 11 x 8 + 0, entonces son los números entre 11 y 11999. Que tienen 11 a la derecha.

So the final answer should be (C)<n><n>Input: Which operation does not require regrouping? Since we are looking at which operation does not require re grouping, this is an instance that 23+5=3.4 will not require re group. Hence, option (B) is correct.<n><n>Input:Whether or not a number is prime is only based on the number itself. If I were asked if 20 was prime, the only thing I would have to do would be to check if it was even or odd.<n>Output: The answer to this question is that it is true because even numbers are not prime. So, option (E) is correct.<n># Input:Is the number 200 prime?<n># Output: False<n><n>Input: How many apples are in the fruit basket? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is the opposite of a village? Choices:  A: rural area B: africa C: ohio D: big city E: tribe<n>Output:		If the question says village it doesn’t make sense for the answer to be rural, but if it says town it does make sense for the answer rural.<n>So all the answers are 1 and 6.<n>Their is one answer which is rural and the only one that has been mentioned is B<n>So the final answer has to be B.<n><n>Input: One in nine children suffers in poverty in the United States.  Of all 3-year-olds in the United States, approximately 1% are in poverty.  Poverty rates differ based on the child’s race; black children suffer in poverty at a rate double that of white children.  By how much is the poverty rate for white children lower than the poverty rate for black children?<n>Output: We know that we are given 9%, then divide by the other number 1%. This will make the answer (90/100) 90%<n>Poverty rate for white children is: (90/1) = <<90/1=90>>90 %<n>Poverty rate  of black children is: ((2/9) * 1) = <<2/9*1=25>>25%<n>The difference of 90  -  25 = <<90-25=65>>65 %<n>The difference is 65%<n>So the final answer to question is A<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:It had a beach with shallow water, while not the ocean this was a hot spot all the locals enjoyed on the what? Choices:  A: swimming pool B: pond C: lake D: bathe in E: childrens pool<n>Output:		None of the above<n>The water is only up to your chest and it's not salty<n>1 mile south<n><n>Input: A man is going for a weekend camping trip to what? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What place would a person go to look at zebras? Choices:  A: zoo B: museum C: hospital D: desk E: opera<n>Output:		B: The correct place to look at zebra is B, as the answer is given to be as the museum but the answer is hospital, in this case the answer is given wrong, so it cannot be accepted as correct, and the answer is given as desk but the answer is not desk but it's given to be as a zoo, in this case the correct answer is zoo.<n>So the final ansawer is B<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:I was shopping at a car dealership, what did a salesman do? Choices:  A: appear suddenly B: bottom out C: go downtown D: scream E: roll over<n>Output:		He bottomed out because when we talk about a car bottoming out, this usually means that the undercarriage has slammed into the ground suddenly.<n>So the final choice is C<n>

If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Mark wanted to know the truth, because he didn't want to continue existing in what? If there are 360 degrees in a circle and there are 60 minutes in an hour, what was the length of the match, measured in degrees? <n>Output: First, the players shot three points each so there are 3 points made, then in 360 degrees and there are 6 points made.  <n><n><n><n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What would someone wear to protect themselves from a cannon? Choices:  A: ungulate B: bomber C: body armor D: tank E: hat<n>Output:		Choice (E), hat would protect someone from a cannon.<n>A is wrong as it is referring to ungulate, which is a hooved animal. B is incorrect as it refers to a bomber, which is a heavy bomber plane.<n>C is incorrect as body armor is used to protect from bullets or knives, not cannons. D is incorrect as a tank is a large, heavily-armored fighting vehicle, and most tanks also have cannons as main weapons.<n>E, Hat, Is the only answer that is appropriate, meaning someone wearing a helmet, or something similar can withstand a cannon.

What tool should I use to fix this? Choices:  A: humidifier B: surface of earth C: skating rink D: ice cube E: burn it to the ground<n>Output:		I should use a humidifier because it brings moisture to air.<n>So the final choice is D: I should use a Humidifier<n><n>Input:Aaron went to the store and paid 37¢ for three apples and then paid 11¢ for four oranges. How much did the apples cost?<n>Output: Aaron paid $$37$$¢ for three apples. If he paid a higher price per apple than oranges, then the apple cost must be higher than the orange.<n>In this case, he paid 37¢ ÷ 4 = <<37/4=9>>9¢ for three apples<n>He then paid 11 ÷ 4 = 2.75 ¢ for each apple or a total of $$37+4(2.75) = 11$$¢ for 4 apples<n>Or 9¢ apples ÷ 4 = $$2.25$$¢/apple<n>So the apple cost is $2.25<n><n>Input: A restaurant has a 25% discount deal on its sandwiches. What is a sandwich worth without the deal? Choices: A: $15 B: $15 C: $20 D: $20 E: $30<n>Output: A restaurant has a discount or 25% off of the sandwich price. Since it has a discount of 25% we need to know what the original price is to know how much a sandwich cost without the discount.<n>I will simplify by saying that each sandwich is $15, so the full price is: $15 multiplied by 1.25 for a total of $18.75<n>A sandwich discounted by 25% is $18.71, in dollars and cents.<n>So the final option is B: A sandwich without a discount is $18.05<n><n>Input: In our class there are 7 kids in Mrs. Brennand’s class. In our class, 34% of the kids are boys and 94
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:She had been applying for job for weeks with no call back, she knew she was qualified, so what did she feel? Choices:  A: employment B: frustration C: stress D: working hard E: love<n>Output:		She was feeling: <n>if she answered: A: employment, then choice A = <<A=employment>>employment<n>If she answered: B: frustration, then choice B = <<B=frustration>>frustration<n>If she answered C: stress, then choice C = <<C=stress>>stress<n>If she answered D: working hard, then choice D = <<D=working hard>>working hard<n>If she answered E: love, then choice E = <<E=love>>love<n>Choice C or choice D or choice E = <<C,D,E>>C,D,E<n>If Choices are C = stress, D = working hard and E = love, then,<n>C is stressed because she's working so hard and loves the work because stress is a feeling and a working hard and loving it are what she does, So choice C = <<C is stressed because <<C,D,C,E>>C, and D = working hard which means she loves her job, So we get E = love and choice E = <<E is love>>love is the correct answer<n><n>Input: There are 6 students and each student got the same grade.  What grade did each student get?<n>Output: 6 students, so 6 students * 6 grades = 1 score per student<n>The score is 82, so score = 82<n>The students got 1 score = <<The score is 81, so students got 1 score====3.6>>3.6<n>The students got 3.6 = <<The score is ____, so students got 3.2====3.6>>__score____<n>The students got the grade = <<The students got ____, so the grade____====3.6>>_score_____<n>The students got the ____ = The grade = <<The students are _____, so the grade is ________ ________>>_A or _Bor_C____<n>__________ = The students got _____, so the ______ is ________ = <<The students are B, so the grade is B>>____<n>______________ = The grade is ________ = Answer A is B<n>So the final answer A = <<Answer A is _____, so the answer is ________=>>B>>B<n><n><n>Input: The two friends
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n>Output:		A, B, C, D, E are all reasons as to why you would exercise<n><n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The wind tore off the shingles, what was the wind like? Choices:  A: dry hair B: spreading C: blowing hard D: change direction E: wave wheat<n>Output:		Let's see what the choices are and how they are affected:<n>A: dry hair -> Dry hair isn't affected much by the wind, which is why this answer is probably wrong<n>B: spreading -> Spreading is a movement of something along the surface, like the wind spreading out across the surface of the Earth. This answer is probably incorrect, because it's implying the wind is moving in the same direction for a long time<n>C: blowing hard -> Blowing hard could be a description for the wind's movement as well, since we would describe someone's blowing hair as it blows hard. Maybe this one is right though? Blowing is a movement of something that gets stronger in the same direction, so this answer could be right!<n>D: change direction -> Change direction? No, the wind doesn't change directions like something turns into something else, it still just moves forward like a constant wind of some sort. This is probably the wrong answer, as the direction we're describing has to do with the direction the wind blows - not turning into something else.<n>E: wave wheat -> We don't know what "wave wheat" means.. But it feels like it's describing something that's not affected by the wind, so this answer is probably also wrong. And it's not blowing - that's the way we describe something moving in the same direction at different speeds.<n>So, even though C and E are the only two answers we haven't eliminated, the right answer seems to be D - change direction.<n><n>Input:  The weather forecast says you can't go to the beach today, but you'll be able to go tomorrow. How much colder will it be tomorrow?<n>Output: It’ll be 10 degrees colder tomorrow since 45 -20 + 55 = <<45-20+55=10>><n><n>Input:If you look at the last row of cells, you will find that each number's right neighbor and left neighbor are larger. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Ice fishing can be done surprisingly far out most winters on what greatest of the Michigan's greats? Choices:  A: pond B: underwater C: aquarium D: lake superior E: body of water<n>Output:		Lake Superior is the largest of the Great Lakes. It is 317 miles from Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, at the north into Duluth, Minnesota, at the south, by a distance of 160 statute miles across. At its east-west diameter, it is 82 miles wide from southwest North Township, Ontario to the Straits of Mackinac.<n>Since they asked for the biggest lake, Lake Superior is the right one to choose<n><n>Input: The total of all seven digits in the number 713. What does each digit represent in reverse order?<n>Output: In a number like 713, the place value of each digit starts with 1000. For example, the 7 in 7 1 3 equals 7×1000 = <<7*1000=7000>>7,000 and the 1 in 713 equals 1×1000 to get <<1*1000=>1000>>1,000<n>The next digit, 3, equals 0+2+5 = <<0+2+5=7>>7<n>So 713/7 = <<713/7=102>>102 each<n>So the final answer 102<n><n>Input: Two years ago, in 2016, you bought 100 shares of Apple (AAPL). The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where is one likely to purchase listening vinyl? Choices:  A: safeway B: record albums C: record store D: car E: wallpaper<n>Output:		If you pick wallpaper you probably are looking for music not vinyl. If you are looking for Wallpaper, you should probably say "Where do you buy wallpaper?"<n>In response to a question about where to buy listening vinyl, a possible retort is to mention someplace that doesn't sell vinyl or some kind of wall decoration.<n>In this case, if you are purchasing vinyl, you are not buying wallpaper.<n>So the final choice is B: Record Albums.<n><n>Input:Which of the following is not considered  a fruit?<n>Choices: A: blueberry B: cranberry C: grapefruit D: apple E: kiwi<n>Output: Apple, cranberry, grapefruit, and kiwi are all fruits, while blueberry and Cranberry are not.<n>So the final input is C: Grapefruit<n><n>Input: Which word is not contained within these words?<n>Choices:<n>A: 2-letter word<n>B: 2-letter world<n>C: 3-letter word<n>D: 3-letter world<n>E: 6-letter word<n>Output: The only 3-letter word here is WORD; however, it is also a 2-letter word.<n>So the final word is C: 3-Letter world<n><n>Input: If you count to 1000 in two hours, how many minutes each hour will you be counting?<n>Choices: Choices: A: 2 minutes B: 3 minutes C: 4 minutes D: 5 minutes E: 20 minutes<n>Output: Since each minute is counted as 60 seconds, each hour is broken down into 60 minutes, so 60 minutes per hour = 1000 ÷ 1000 = <<1000/1000=1>>1 hours<n>So the final answer in hours is 1.<n><n>Input: If it takes 20 minutes for each mile to walk to the mall, at what minute will he arrive?<n>Choices: Time: A: 0 hours B: 1 hour C: 2 hours D: 3 hours E: 4 hours<n>Minutes: A: 0 minutes B: 20 minutes C: 40 minutes D: 60 minutes E: 80
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n>Output:		Letters A and B are incorrect, so the answer must be a cabin carries people, so choose E.<n><n>Input: I found it on the internet! What are the four letter code used to protect web sites? Choices: 1: HTTP 2: HTTP 3: TCP 4: HTTPS 5: TCL<n>Output: The four letter code used to protection for web sites is HTTPS, so answer number 4, https.<n>HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is a set of rules for how the HTTP client and HTTP server exchange information on the network.<n>What does HTTP/2 (HTTP version 2) mean for SEO? What are the new HTTP/2 SEO issues?<n>HTTP/2 is the next generation HTTP web transfer protocol. By upgrading to HTTP/2, you are ensuring faster loading times and increased security features. This article will give a brief introduction to:<n><n>* The core features of HTTP/2<n>* Why is HTTP/2 important?<n>* What are the downsides?<n>* How do I upgrade to HTTP/2?<n><n>What does https stand for? What are the differences between http and https?<n><n>The SSL security protocol provides a way to securely exchange information on the internet. But what exactly does the SSL abbreviation stand for? And what exactly does https stand for? SSL stands for Secure Sockets Layer. It is a protocol for encrypting data across networks. It provides an algorithm for encrypting confidential information sent over the Internet. <n><n>Input: What’s something that can be made with corn? Choices:  Cookies  Corn on the cob  Tacos  Nachos  Fritos<n>Output: Cookies can be made with corn, Corn on the cob is an item and is not related to making things, and Nachos are just chips. So the answer is Tacos.<n>Corn, or maize ( Zea mays L.) as it is botanically known, is among man's first domesticated crops and the earliest known species was native to Central America. Corn is produced in many forms including dry field corn, sweet corn, flour corn, and popcorn. As the basic source of America's corn, farmers grow field corn for animal feed (primarily corn-fed beef and pork), corn for ethanol, and, of course
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where can you buy a binder? Choices:  A: college dorm B: back pack C: class room D: backpack E: office supply store<n>Output:		You can buy a binder in any of the places as binder is sold in all of the places<n>So the final answer will be A, B, C, D, E and is the same as 1, 2, 3, 4, 5<n><n>Input:How much money does the car owner get back? Choices: 1. A: $4 B: $8 C: $6 D: $7 E: $5<n>Output: If they have sold their car for $100 then they are going to get $80 (100 - 10/100 of 100 = <<100-10/10=80>>80).<n>Therefore the final answer is E<n><n>Input:What does the banker need to use to give people $50 bills? Choices:  $5 $10 $20 $1 $100 B: $50  C: $100  D: $50 E: B and C<n>Output: He needs 2x5 = <<2*5=10>>20 $50 bills to give people $5 to keep the original bank account as well as give each person the change. So the final answer is E.<n>He needs 3x50 = <<3*50=150>>150 $50 bells to give everyone $5 and then keep the original bank account value $10. So the final answer will be B and C.<n><n>Input:Ryan had 10 marshmallows. Mary eats 5 of them. If Ryan had 21 marshmallows, how many does Mary have? Choices: A: 1 B: 2 C: 5 D: 13<n>Output: Mary had 5, and she eat 5 so 21 - 5 = <<21-5=16>>16 more marshmallows so you do 16 + 10 = <<16+10=26>>26 marshmallows and then 26 % 5 = <<26/5=5>>5<n>So the final answer should be D.<n><n>Input:How many books did Linda take out of the library? Choices: A)7 B)8 C)

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What do horses do to get energy? Choices:  A: eat grass B: play C: kept in stables D: dominated E: drink coffee<n>Output:		The right answer is E: drink coffee<n><n>Input:The teacher in an 8th grade class has 22 students on the basketball team and 18 on the soccer team. He needs the teams to be equal in numbers. He is thinking of increasing the number to an even value but is running out of options. How many more students should he add to the basketball team to make the two teams equal?<n>Output:It's already an even number, so he has 22 students playing basketball, so he needs to take away one student from the basketball team to make it even.<n>He then has 21 students playing basketball.<n>If he takes away one student, then he'll have 22 students on both the basketball team and the soccer team.<n>So he takes away 1 student from the basketball.<n>The remaining students are on the basketball team and the basketball team is even.<n>Adding a student to the basketball team would make it uneven.<n>This way, the two teams are equal.<n>So the final solution is one student<n><n>If they had 22 + 1 = <<22+1=23>>23 students playing basketball and they can only add one more student to make the two teams even, I would ask, how am I adding one more student to keep the teams even?<n><n>If they had the basketball team at 22, and need 22 + 2 > 23 players to keep the teams equal, I would ask, why I am adding 2 students to the basketball team when they have 22 players?<n><n>They'll get me right if I only ask how am I adding one student to make the two team even.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:How would someone feel after going for run? Choices:  A: working out B: sore C: get tired D: satisfaction E: falling down<n>Output:		A feels working out, B feels sore C feels tired D feels satisfaction E falls down<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Mary was a bad girl, but she was always open about that.  People liked her because she was what? Choices:  A: excellent B: fun C: honest D: worthy E: choice<n>Output:		The right answer is E: Choice.<n><n>Input:Ali and his sister Maria are going to the movies.  If they each buy 4 tickets, how many tickets do they have in total? Choices:<<4>>4<n><n>Output: The answer is 4 tickets in total.<n><n>Input: In a certain city, the average salary of all workers 90,000.  The average rent for a one-bedroom apartment, or $190,00.  If two friends each have a salary below average and want to live closer to work, then the cheapest way for them to do that would be to  A: have both move to an apartment and commute together,  B: buy an apartment and move in together,  C: live in separate apartments.  D: None of the above<n>Output: The answer B: Buy an apartment and move together.<n><n>Input: Jack is going to sell some CDs. He has two boxes of identical CDs. In one box, there are 4 red and 4 blue CDs. In the other box, there are 6 red and 4 blue.  In all, he has 44 CDs.  If he picks one CD at random, what are the chances that it will be a red one? Choice:<<0.5>>0.5<n><n>Output: The CD is guaranteed to be red because there are four times more red CDs than blue CDs. Therefore, the answer is 6.<n><n>Input: A student gets a score A in Physics, B in Biology, B in Chemistry, B in Maths, and B in English.<n>If the mean scores are 70, what is the total value the student got? Choice:<<55>>55<n><n>Output: Adding up all the scores, the student gets a total value of 50.<n><n>Input:You are working as a baker, and you can bake a bunches of either cookies or cake balls. The cost of cookies is always twice of cake balls. You can make $55 from the cookies and $85 from cake balls. You start each day with a batch of cookies you buy, and you have a pile of left over cookies which are cheaper to make. What is the maximum profit per day
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The competition was to see who would be the last one the drop the object, the hard part was you had to have your arm extended straight out while what the object? Choices:  A: holding B: lift up C: pick up D: lifting E: hold onto<n>Output:		A &C are out because they are doing too much work and the other 3 do not work at all<n>So the answer would E.<n><n>Input: How much do you like to see your teacher?<n><n>Output: I really like to see my teacher<n><n>[Input] I don’t like to see my teacher.<n>[Output] I don’t really like to see my teachers<n><n><n>Input: If one were to buy 1 cup of milk from the store, how much money would one have?<n>Output: You would have one cup of milk<n><n>Input: If each of five apples costs $0.99, and the store sold three apples, then I think the store will sell $3 in apples. Is this a correct conclusion?<n>Output: The total is 15 cents<n><n>Input: How many cups of juice were there? If there is 2 cups of juice, and each is 16 fluid ounces, then there's 32 fluid ounces of juice. Correct?<n>Output: There are 2 cups<n><n>Input: If 50 seconds equal 1 minute and 14 minutes equal an hour, the total seconds in an hour would be 3600 seconds.<n>Output: One hour is 3600<n><n>Input: If I took 25 pence and I wanted to buy £1 worth of things, how much change would I normally get?<n>Output: I need to round up<n><n>Input: You took a penny from the counter, then put it back. If 2 pennies equal 1 dime, and there are 10 pennies to a dime, what is the total amount of pennies in 9 dimes?<n>Output: You need to divide to find the total amount<n><n>Input: You wanted to get some chocolate, but the store had some chocolate shaped things that were a total of 50 cents. If you got 16 dimes, how many chocolates could you get?<n>Output: You'd get 16<n><n>Input: You can give 51 pennies to your friend if each penny is a fraction.
