If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where can someone keep a digital file? Choices:  A: suitcase B: filing cabinet C: computer D: desk drawer E: cloud<n>Output:		A filing cabinet is a cabinet with drawers.<n>A desk drawer is a drawer on a desk for filing or keeping knick-knacks. A computer is a tool, a machine, that you interact with to make the digital file. So, the answer is definitely not C.<n>There are suitcases and cloud based storage. So the answer is A or E if your digital file is big and bulky. And the answer is E because it would cost a lot of money to buy a suitcase just for storing a file while you can just store in the cloud for free. E is definitely not D and D is definitely not A.<n><n>Input: Which city’s population is the greatest per square mile: Miami, Chicago, Philadelphia, or Los Angeles?<n>Output: None of them fit, because <n>Miami's area is 558 sq.miles, Chicago's area is 225 sq.miles, Philadelphia's area is 134 sq.miles, and Los Angeles has 352 sq.miles. All of their areas are not large enough to put them on a 10 x 10 square grid. <n>Therefore the answer is none of the above, because none of them <n>actually satisfy the conditions.<n><n>Input: You get to have your students come up to your desk one at a time. You have 22 students in your class. How many more times do you have to pass out grades  to have an equal number of students at your desk?<n>Output: The answer is 11, because <n>the only numbers that make 22 come out the same amount of times (once) are multiples of 2.<n>So, 2 * 22 = 44, and 4 * 22 =<n>88, and 11 * 22 = [11 * 2= 22]22 more times.<n><n>Input: At a birthday party, each child in attendance got three presents (each worth 1 coin, 2 coins, or 3 coins). A total of $5 was given to hand out the presents. How could the children get the same number of presents?<n>Output: The solution is no present valued at 1 or 3 coins should have been valued at 1 coin, which is
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:i like to examine different things,why do books the chapters on the back Choices:  A: examine thing B: go somewhere C: knit D: read book E: see particular program<n>Output:		The right answer is B : 'The chapters are on the back'<n><n>Input: How many times can i say the words ‘I’ and ‘me’  Chosess:  A: 2 B: 4 C: 3 D: 1 E: 5<n>Output: 'I don’t think there is a way to say "I" and "me" 5 times and still not make a meaningful sentence.'<n><n>Input: The time on a clock is even minutes past 12.What two numbers make up the hours and what two numbers make up the minutes?  Chosesss:  A: 7:28 PM E: 8:53 PM<n>B: 7:17 AM H: 0:20 AM<n>C: 7:34 PM M: 4:51 AM<n>D: 8:03 PM G: 5:20 AM<n>Output: The correct answer is Choice 'D': '7:34 PM' and '4:51 AM' for the hours and the minutes.<n><n>Input: There are 0.822 kg (just under 2 pounds) of cookies. I gave 32g (just under a third of a cup) to each of my friends.  A) When I had 4 friends, each friend got 80g.  How many friends were there? (0.822/28=0.3g/gall)  B) When I had 8 friends, each friend got  23g.  How many pounds does the cookie mix make?<n>Output: First half:  A. It is not possible for the question to be true, the answer could not be positive and the answer is not positive.<n>Second Half:  B. It is not possible to get the answer correct because if there was 23g per person and 8 friends there would be 9.5kg(20.9lbs) of cookie mix.<n>C The answer is D. With 8 friends and 23g per cook 8*23=176g and 8*8=64g. If you add the total of all the cookies for your friends 64g and 176g together its 240g. if you add 23g and 3g
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What building has a ot of glue bottles? Choices:  A: art room B: police station C: classroom D: desk drawer E: school<n>Output:		The classroom because it should have desks, a teacher, books, etc.<n><n>Input: What building has a ot of toys? Choices: A: classroom B: police station C. art room D: desk drawerb E. house<n>Output: The classromm because it should have desk, teachers etc.<n><n><!---- Input: The building has a ot of paintings? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where will a bullet projectile be found during a war? Choices:  A: battle field B: museum C: weapon D: canon E: tornado<n>Output:		At least one battle is during war, so the battle field will be during war.<n><n>Input:What is the best thing to do if you get a dog for your birthday?<n>Output: If you get dog for your birthday, the best thing to do is to take a walk with it.<n><n>Input: If you get a dog for a birthday, what is the best thing to feed it?<n>Output: If we get a dog for birthday, the best food to feeds it is to dog food.<n><n>Input: What is one of the best things to get if you get a dog?<n>Output: If I got dog, one of the best things is to collar.<n><n>Input: Where will a battle be during a war? Choice:  A: the battle field B: the museum C: the weapons D: the canon E: the tornado<n>Output: If we pick B, a battle will be at the battle field<n><n>Input: Choose the most important part of a speech.<n>Output: In speech, most important things are ideas<n><n>Input: What color dog is it? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:A night owl is what you'd head at sunset and you'd hear a what at sunrise? Why don't you take your time, and just wait a while and enjoy both meals!” If Kendra eats her breakfast at 11am, and her lunch at 11:21am, at what time does she eat her breakfast?<n>Output: If Kendra eats their breakfast at 11AM, her Lunch is 43 minutes later, so: 11:23am + 43 = <<11:23+43=12:06>>12:06<n>So her breakfast is 12:06 AM<n><n><n>Input: The temperature outside is 12 degrees celsius and the humidity is 75%. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where is small knight likely to be found? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. This means 45 children/10 children = 4.5 children for each adult, or 0.45 or 45%<n><n><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B3zK4WCW7cY">Watch videos here</a>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is a place that could have hundreds of sporting goods store? Choices:  A: buy athletic equipment B: city C: espn D: town E: jerseys<n>Output:		<n>Place: If the sporting goods store is a chain, you can pick it A, city B, espn C, town D, jerseys E<n>So the final answer would be city because city is the only correct one that doesn’t need any modification<n><n>Input: Which of these three planets is closest to the sun? Choices: A: venus B: earth C: mars D: mercury E: pluto<n>Output:<n>Planet: Venus (orange and is the hottest)<n>So the final answer will be Venus because that is the only correct answer<n><n>Input: Which color is the biggest number in the color? You give him a plant that can yield 500 lemons a  year. The tree he takes care of can yield 20 lemons a year. The fruit of a lemon will last for 2 days. If it is used as a decoration, it will last forever. How many times can Toby use 1 lemon a year?<n>Output: There’s 20 lemons from the tree and 500+20= <<20+500=520>>520 lemons from plant, which means the tree could use 520 /20= <<520/20=26>>26 times. But after that the plant will be used out so, the plant will have one more year of lemons.<n>Then, the tree will have another 20 / 20 = <<20/20 = 1>>1 lemons and the plant will have one 690 + 1= <<690+1=700>>700 lemons. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would you put a light? Choices:  A: ocean B: desk C: universe D: attic E: chair<n>Output:		You cannot place a light in the chair because a light isn't the same thing as a chair<n>You cannot place a light in a desk because light is not the same thing as a desk<n>You cannot place a chair in the chair because a chair and a chair aren't the same thing<n>You cannot place a desk in the attic because a desk and attic aren't the same<n>You cannot place a universe in the ocean because a universe is not the same thing<n>so the only thing that is left is a desk in the chair<n>So the final answer the final answer is desk in the chair because desk and chair is same and Ocean, Universe, and chair and attic are different<n><n>Input:The total weight of 8 dogs is 42kg. Each dog weighs 6kg more than another.  If each dog costs $20, how much does one dog cost?<n>Output: Start with the total weight, 8(42) = <<8*42=336>>336.<n>Then subtract 336 by the weight of each dog which is 8*6 = <<8*6=48>>48<n>There are eight dogs so $8*48 = $<<8*48=416>>416<n>So, the final answer is $416<n><n>Input: A 7kg watermelon costs 6€. A 5kg watermelon is on sale for 5€ each. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Mary wasn't familiar with James, so she wasn't comfortable speaking with him. How might she come off? Choices:  A: cold B: unfamiliar C: unknown D: unacquainted E: shy<n>Output:		I think the best answer would be Choice D, "unacquainted", since that seems to be the most polite way of saying it.<n> <n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What might someone want to be if he or she is thick? Choices:  A: slender B: free flowing C: sparse D: unacquainted E: diet<n>Output:		This is a trick question, since a thick person must be either fat (slender) or overweight (free flowing) or obese (sparse). The term diet may actually refer to someone who is on a diet, or someone who is thin, rather than referring to a fat individual.<n><n>A person who is obese may or may not be on a diet.<n>A person who is thin may also be on a diet, because thinness is not a direct result of eating a diet.<n>People who are slender and free flowing are fat.<n>Input:  There are 305 students in a class.  There is 1 boy less than a 1/3 of the class.<n>Of what sex is the missing student? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is made out of only one piece? Choices:  b) Alaska<n>	c) California<n>	d) North Dakota<n>Output: California<n><n>Input: Which movie is on Disney+? Choices:  d) Jungle Book<n>	a) Monsters’ Inc.<n>	b) Toy Story 4<n>	c) Mulan<n>Output: Mulan<n># Question 2<n><n>Input: The average of 2 and 3 is 2.5, so what is the average of 5 and 7?<n>Output: The average of 5 and and 7 is 4.5, so 3+4.5 = <<3+4.5=7>>5<n><n>Input: The value of 7 divided by 1/5 is 42. So what is 7 divided by 5?<n>Output: 7 divided by 7 = <<7/7=1>>1<n><n>Input: Multiply 4 and 5. 7 is the sum of those two numbers. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. How much money does pumpkin cost?<n>Output: $1, because it is $1 for every pound.<n><n>Input: If you add 138 to 20%, what do you get?<n>Output: 57.5%, because 138 + 20% = 138 * 0.2 = <<138*0.2=27.6>>27.6 and 27.6% = <<27.6%=5.14>>5.14 rounds up to 5<n><n>Input: A box has 20 sticks.  Half of them are brown and the other half are green.  One-third of the brown sticks are broken.  How many whole, green sticks are left after removing half of the brown sticks?<n>Output: 2 sticks + 5 whole brown = <<2*1+5*1>>2, and 4 brown sticks + 1/3 broken brown = 2 * (4/3), so 4/3 = <<4/3 =.666>>.666 So there are 6 sticks left (4 brown sticks +.333(6 = 3/2 = <<3/2=1.5>>.5 brown stick,.666 +.666 = 1.333, so 1.33 +.5 =
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Bill did not abandon the fight, but did what to the enemy? Choices:  A: arrogate B: retain C: embrace D: smile E: engage<n>Output:		Bill did not abandon the fight but did what to the enem<n> <n>Because the fight<n><n>Input: What happened in the past, happened in the present?<n>Output: If someone thinks, acts, or talks in the past tense, it means that something happened in the past and now it is over.The past tense is used if the action was complete.<n>There was a fight between Bill and Fred. They both got hurt. Now that’s in the past and that’s over.<n>They can now smile to each other.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would you find people gathered near liquid in a workplace? Choices:  A: water cooler B: opera C: hospital D: hockey game E: beach<n>Output:		I think it would probably be E: Beach
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where could you find a fox hunting when not in a forest? Choices:  A: open meadow B: arctic tundra C: beach D: great outdoors E: england<n>Output:		The fox is a nocturnal mammal and a carnivore.<n>The fox can be hunted in an open meadow, during the day<n>An open meadow could be located in arctic tundra, but only during day<n>The arctic tundra is located in the great outdoors, during the day<n>The great outdoors could be found in England, during the day<n>So the answer is C<n><n>Input: The sum of a number multiplied by the number is 6. Subtract the original number from this sum and the answer is 9. What is the number?<n>Output: The original number is one less than the sum of the number multiplied by the original number, 1 - (n x n) = 1 - 6 = <<1-6=5>>5<n>5 subtracted from 9 = <<5-9=4>>4<n>So the final answer for the number is 4<n><n>Input: How far can a jet fighter travel in 4 hours?<n>Output: Jet fighters have to cover a certain mileage each day to meet daily requirements. This is known as the minimum daily demand (MDD). In this problem, we are asked how many units of the MDD were to travel in 4 hours.<n>So the answer is 9<n>

Choices:  a: to save money b: to get rid of things c: to have money d: to make money<n>Output: A is the correct answer because to "make ends meet" is an alternate way of saying someone "has enough money to make ends meet." Ends are often defined as the final expenses in life: shelter, food, and clothing. The phrase is most commonly used to express that people are getting by or managing to cover their basic financial needs. Make ends meet - to get by financially.<n><n>Input: How much does 15 gallons of ice cream weigh? Choices:  A: do enjoy B: get laid C: enjoyable D: work less E: enjoy living<n>Output:		If you pick the right answer A and B, then it is a choice because <<A and B=?>>A and B<n>If you pick the right answers B and E, then it is also a choice because <<B and E=?>>B and E<n>If you pick the wrong answer A then it is wrong because <<A=?>>A is wrong<n>If you pick the choice E then it is right because <<E=?>>E is right<n>Thus all the choices are equal in terms of whether they are correct or not. The turtle's average speed going 10 km/h is faster than the race car’s average speed of 50 km/h because the turtle's speed is slowed during the race, but the race car goes the whole time, so the turtle car will always take less time to get to 50 km. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:There was a show on television about a ranger who loved flowers, but the next day it was about a gardener who also loved flowers.  It was a what? Choices:  A: countryside B: anthology C: dull read D: state park E: surface of earth<n>Output:		First it was a TV series about flowers on the ______________. But after the series finished it became a _____________, which is about everyday life, and has a new theme each day.<n>Flower (series) > Ranger loves flowers > Flower (anthology)<n><n>Input:In a survey done to find out what kinds of music people listen to, if 60% of people like one style of music, how many people like a different style of music?<n>Output: The survey found that 60% of the people liked music A; 40% of people like music B. So the remaining 40% were split as 60% (40%) of the remaining people like music A; 36% of the remaining (40%) of people prefer music B. The remaining 4% of people prefer other music A. The remaining 3*40% = <<3*(40/100) = 12>>12 like other music B, (36/100) + (12/100) of the remaining 40%.<n>So the final answer would be 12, other music A and 12, other Music B!<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If I have a vintage, decorative light source in my possession, what is it likely to be? Choices:  A: sun B: sky C: candle D: house E: lamp<n>Output:		It is most likely that the light source is D: house if I find one in my possession because light  sources don't just randomly exist - they need to be made.  Thus, they are not found in their natural state.  Therefore D is the best answer<n><n>Input:What is the best thing that anyone could possibly eat? (Bonus points for making it yourself!)<n>Output: BACON!<n>Bacon is the only food item that's considered so yummy, that it's a food group in itself.  Everything else is just secondary.<n><n>Input:What do you know about cereal with a dog's name on it?<n>Output: It is likely that the cereal has a dog's name because dogs are the best<n><n>Input:When I say I'm in an emporium, you might guess that it's a place I've been. Where have I most likely been?<n>Output: An emporium is a fancy word for a store, like CVS or Walmart or Target. You will most likely be going to a place with a fancy name!<n><n>Input:How do you pronounce "puddles"? (Hint, it's an easy one!?)<n>Output: It is pronounced as "Puddles" because the "d" is silent. Like most words that have a "d" like this, the "d" is usually pronounced like a "b" in this word<n><n>Input:Which of the following is the most obvious thing to do when someone hands you something?<n>Output:Take it!<n>You might need to be careful if you're holding a cup or drink because you don't want it to spill from being dropped on you.<n><n>Input:When someone is talking to me, do they tend to look at my face, ears, or eyes?<n>Output:People tend to look you in the face because that's where most of their attention is focused. You don't usually look at a dog's face because dogs are much smaller than people, so their faces are much further away.  You might also look at a dog'y ears because they usually can't move them. So people tend to look at the face and ears when talking to a dog.  Since the dog's ears are near their head rather than their face, so it is not most likely to look at
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:He was good at traditional science but excelled at social science, his favorite subject was what? Choices:  A: geography B: history studies C: math D: religion E: dancing<n>Output:		Traditional science is science with an emphasis on facts and methods from classical times. Social science is a grouping of academic disciplines that study society. Geeks are smart kids, Math is the mathematical study of natural sciences. So the final answer is Math<n><n>Input:  An elephant takes out a 12-month auto loan with 9% APR at a dealership. She makes 36 payments every year of $1,200 each. She ends up paying $5,164.  What was the original loan price of her car?<n>Output: She made 72 payment = 36 * 2. So the original loan price would be 36 * 12 = <<36*12=432>>432 (rounded)<n>The final answer is 432<n><n>Input:  How many months were there in 3 years 11 months 7 days?<n>Output: There were 3 years 1 month and there are 12 months in a year. Then 11 months and 7 days in 3 years <n><n>Input:  A plane can fly at an average speed of 500 miles per hour.  After flying 18,900 miles, how long did the plane take to fly?<n>Output: She flew 18,920 - 2,000 = <<18,92-2000=16,70>>16,700 miles<n>She flew 16,70 ÷ 500 = <<16,70/500=33.4>>33.4 hours<n>The final answer is : 33.4 hours.<n><n>Input:  It was raining every day until January 20 after which it only rained 53 days. What is the ratio of rain in January to rain in February?<n>Output: First, we'll count down January's rainy days.<n>Rainy days till January: 21<n>Rainy days in February: 53<n>Ratios: 53:21 = <<53:21=2:1>>2:1<n>So the final answer ratios: 5:2

The 5 projects in this case could potentially take 7 days and 5 hours to complete, but 6 days and 9 hours to completely finish the 4 projects. Which project would you tackle first?<n>Output: Since you can either do 4 or 5 projects, the total no of time is either 7 days and 4 hours(total of 4 projects) or 6 days and 8 hours(total of 5 projects)<n><n>Therefore, it looks like the total of all the projects is equivalent to the time that it would take to complete the 5th project.<n>Because time=project number, the optimal project to start with is the 5th project, which would take 6 days and 6 hours to complete.<n>So the final ans is 6 days and 1 hour<n><n>Input: It was 11pm and it’s raining really bad outside. Choices:  A: become depressed B: welcome change C: thank god D: experiences E: pay bills<n>Output:		They look for change<n><n>Input: A plane leaves Dallas 2 hours and 30 minutes after a flight from New York arrives. The New York flight is in the air when the Dallas flight leaves. How long does it take each flight to arrive in New York?<n>Output: To answer this question we must compare the arrival times of the New York and Dallas planes, and find their difference.<n><n>They both leave New York at 6:00 AM: New York plane leaves at 6:02 AM;  Dallas plane leaves at 8:32 AM.<n><n>So the airplane from New York lands in Dallas at 9:09 AM.<n><n>Then they both arrive in New York at 11:03 AM.<n>So the flight from New York arrived in Dallas 10 and 7 hours earlier.<n><n>They both left a time t apart, which makes their difference 10 - (t).<n>So to find the time the New York plane lands in Dallas we take 10 – (t): 10 – (11:03) = <<10-11:03=19:43>>19:43<n>So the New York flight arrived in Dallas at 19:43.<n>And to find the time the Dallas flight arrived in New York we take 10 -(11:03): 10 –(11:03)= <<10-12:03=1:57>>1:57<n>So the Dallas flight arrives in New York at 8:57<n><n>So the final answer was one to nine times 9:43 minutes more than the Dallas flight arrived in  New York.<n><n>Input: Which of the following could not be changed by a programming language translation? Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n>Output:		Explanation: A: sickness B&B: motion sickness C&D: fatigue E: jet lag Answer: B<n>The word that is found in all choices with the letter B is motion as in "motion sickness"<n>The word that is not found in any choices is jet, which only occurs in the last choice "fatigue"<n>So the final answer can be found by looking at the choices and removing out all the letters that are in all of the choices,<n>and subtracting that number from all the other choices to find the choices that contain the last letter E<n>Example:<n>>>"fatigue" - jet = "fatigue - j= t ue"<n>So the letter "t" is found in the answer which would only fit into option B<n><n>Input: A man is 3 times as old as the sum of his age and his son’s age. In 4 years, his father will be twice as old as his son. If the sum of the ages of the father and son is 78 years, what is the son’s age?<n>Output: Explanartion: A man is 2 times as old as his son's age + his own age = <<2(a+b)=b+a>>2+(a+b) is equal to b+a<n>b= (a+b)-2a<n>b=16<n>a=7<n>The Sum of the Ages of the Father and Son is 78 years. 78 is 2x the son's age (because 2 +78 = 80) but the son's age isn't found yet<n>3x = 78<n>So, 3/2 = 78/2 = 55<n>So we'll divide 55 by 3 because it will result in the correct answer for son's age<n>55/3 = 18 Years<n>So the final answer would be: 18 years old.<n><n>Input: Which is the correct formula for the sum: A+(B+C)<n>Output: Sum of three numbers<n>Addition<n>Subtraction<n>Multiplication<n>Explanation: A+(B+c)<n>Multiplication<n>Sum of three numbers<n><n>Answer:<n>Addition<n>Sum of three numbers (sum is the result of adding)<n><n>Input: You’ve
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where is a likely place to view an old copy machine? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What would you put furniture on top of? Choices:  A: roof B: room C: floor D: apartment E: neighbor's house<n>Output:		The answer is E<n><n>Input: There are 13 players on the basketball team. How much money does the coach need to buy tickets for home games?<n>Output:<n>The coach needs to buy tickets for 9 home games. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Choices  A: all B: none C: some D: half E: two thirds<n>Output: If you have 79 apples then a third of the apples is 79/3=<<79/3=26>>26 apples.<n>We already know that two thirds of the apples = <<2/3=6>>6 thirds,<n>So 26 + 6 = <<26+6=32>>32<n>So the final  answer is (26)<n><n><n>Input: The owner of the pet store wants to save 75% of the money from sales. Over two days, he earned $340. How much did the owner save, if he divided $25 for groceries from the money he saves 75% of?<n>Output: The owner saves $240 / (1 + 75% / 100) = <<240/(1+.75/100)>>240 / (2 + 3/100)<n>So the final  Answer is (185)<n><n>Input: For a test, there are 2 people with the same answer.  If 30 students took the test.  The teacher asks if anyone got a 25.  Who told her they got the answer since it must have been someone in her class?<n>Output: This is called a two headed coin.<n>The probability is ½ because (½)(½) = <<½*½=½>>½ = ½ = (½)(½)<n>So the final Answer is 5/10<n><n>Input : You bought 3 blue pencils and 5 green pencils at the store. Each pencil cost $5 including tax. What is the total cost?<n>Output: The cost for the blue pencils is 3 x 5 = <<3x5==>15>>15 and the cost for the green pencils is 5 x 5 = <<5x5==
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:How can an artist commemorate a horse forever. Choices:  A: hoof B: kentucky derby C: race track D: painting E: triple crown<n>Output:		The answer to this problem is: A (horse hoof)<n><n>Input: A father and son are having a serious discussion.<n>Father : <<Father:>>Why do I support you?<n>Son: <<Because I'm your son.>><n>Father: <<That’s a good reason to support you but a bad reason for why you support me.<n>Son: <<I support you because you’re my father.>><n>Father - <<That’s an even better reason to support you, but a bad reason for supporting me.<n>Son - <<I love you!>><n><n>Output: Son replies to father’s question with something true but unrelated<n>Father replies back to Son’s reply with something true but unspecific<n>Son asks the father why he supports him, which the father replies unrelated<n>Son replies back to Father's answer with something true but unsubstantial<n><n>Input: The doctor orders a medicine for his patients. He will give half of these to children and the rest to adults.  The medicine is only effective on animals weighing less than 250 pounds and is only effective in temperatures higher than 80 degrees Fahrenheit.  The doctor has no further instructions on how to use it.  If he gives exactly 3,000 pills, how many children does he expect to cure?<n>Output: Assume the maximum possible number of adults with a lower weight restriction (250 pounds) = <<250lbs>>250lbs. Assuming 3000 total patients (250 + 1500), 3000 - 600 = <<3000-600=2400>>2400 pills for the kids and 600 for the adults.<n>2400 kids * 250lbs < 3000 < 2400 * 1500lbs = <<2400*250lbs<3000<2400*1500lbf><n>So 1500 patients are over 250 pounds; all adults are over 80 degrees F. So the doctor expects to cure 1200 children (90%).<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The color yellow is associated with the opposite of the characteristic, what is it? Choices:  A: fearless B: english carrier C: courageous D: brave E: achromatic<n>Output:		The opposite characteristic of fearless is courageous because  "courageous" in simple terms means not fearing.<n><n>Input: What number multiplied by? results in <n>Output: <n>128<n><n><n><n>
