The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where can you eat fruit on a red bridge? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: engineering school C: san francisco D: tree E: market<n>Output:		Redbridge starts with R which stands for refrigerator, So the answer would be A<n><n>Input:How many eyes does a man have? Choices:  Answers:  A: 2 B: 1 C: 8 D: 22 E: 10<n>Output:Man is a word that also begins with M which stands for 8. So the answer would be C<n><n>Input: How many hours did you sleep on your last birthday? Choices:  I don’t remember B:  I slept for 24 hours C:  a whole year D:  I have no idea<n>Output: Since you sleep on your birthday, your reply should be yes, So the answer would actually be A<n><n>Input How many years have I been running? I’m not sure: Choices: Answer: B:  In my whole entire life<n>Output: You are 59, and 59 starts with a 5 which is a whole year. So the answer would actually  B.<n><n>Input: If 3*4 is 13, then 9*13 is Answer: B: 157<n>Output: If 3*3 is 9 so in 9*13 it becomes  9*13 = 9*12 = 936. Therefore, the right answer will be 936.<n><n>Input: What is the square root of 64,000? Answer: B: 800<n>Output: If 8 is twice of 4 so 8*8 is 64,0 so the square root of 8 would be 8 / sqrt of 8 which is 8^0.5 which is 2 so 2*2 becomes 4*4 becomes 64.<n><n>Input: How long is a minute, second, and hour? Choices:  Minute: an answer: B: a second Answer: D: an hour Answer: An hour:  E: An hour:  A: an hour: minute is a time so it is between 0 and 59 so from 0 to 59 and 60 minutes make 1 hour<n><n>Input: How old is my oldest nephew? My nephews are: A: 27 B: 31 C: 13 D: 31 Answer
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What makes people happy when it is surprising and unexpected? Choices:  A: joke B: humor C: frightened D: fight E: laughter<n>Output:		If people are happy when it is unexpected, that makes it funny. So the answer is B.<n><n>Input: What does a person look at that they can find happiness? Choices: A: door B: window C: mailbox D: tree<n>Output: Some happiness is found in nature, so we can answer C: tree.<n><n>Input: In which of the following situations can a baseball player hit a home run? So we can answer D.<n><n>Input: Which of these is a real number? Choices: A) 1 B) 1.00001 C) 2 D) 2.00002 E) π<n>Output: The answer is pi/4. Since the choices involve repeating decimals, the only option among the choices is π.<n><n>Input: Find the common denominator  if 8 and 128. So we answer B.<n><n>Input : What equation could be used to represent the total weight of the eggs and the container? Choices: A : 3x \+ 7 = 60. B : 11 + 7 = 68 <n>Output: You want the total of the item in the container. So we have to add the items.<n>Therefore the answer is B. <n>Input : Is 344 a multiple of 5? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The man took 3 hours every morning for grooming, what is the likely result with his job? Choices:  A: tardiness B: looking good C: injury D: vacation E: neatness<n>Output:		If there 3 hours each day is spent on grooming, then we have (3*60)/24 = <<3*60/24=15>>15 hours and since there's no half-hours it means (15*60)/60 = <<15*60/60=25>>25 days<n>A vacation is an absence from work. Thus, if the results of vacation is A, then the result would be 25*24 = <<25*24=600>>600 days, but this means the time is over a year. Thus, the actual answer would be E, because a man taking 3 hours each day for grooming is unlikely to be on a vacation (vacation=A)<n><n>Input: The store sells 12 toasters the first month, 20 toasters the next month, 28 toasters the next two months, and so on.  How many toasters will the store sell in 60 months?<n>Output: We use the Fizz-Buzz algorithm to determine the answer.<n>fizzBuzzAlgorithm()<n><n>def FizzBuzzAlgorithm():<n><n>  t=1<n><n>  while( True):<n>    	if (t%5==0):<n> 	        print(t%5)<n>    	elif (t%3==0):<n> <n> 		print('Fizz')<n>    	elif ( (t%3==2 and t%5==0)):<n>    	<n> 	        print('FizzBuzz')<n><n>    	t = t + 1<n> <n>Input:  A group of four college students lives together in the same dorm, in a building with 12 apartments. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n>Output:		The movie had many a song, so it was a musical.<n>The movie had many a dance, so it was also A: a bollywood B: a record C: a jukebox E: an napster F: a jukebox D: a musical F: a musical<n>So the final answer should be musical<n><n>Input: A farmer is raising rabbits. She has 7 boxes of 5 bunnies each except 1 box which only has 4 bunnies.  How many total bunnies is she raising?<n>Output: The farmer is raising 7 boxes of 7 bunnies each, except 1 box which has 6 bunnies. <n>She is raising 7 boxes x 7 bunnies per box = <<7 x 7=49>>49 bunnies.<n>But there is one box with 6 bunnies, so subtracting from 49 she is raising 49 – 6 = <<49-6=43>>43 bunnies.<n>So the final output is 43<n><n>Input: A man named Timo travels around the world. He travels at 3 times the speed he drives his car, but he also gets 3 times as tired. How many times slower is he than the speed he drives his vehicle?<n>Output: The answer is 1 / <<1/3=0.3333330.333 + 1=1.3333 = 4 times slower>>0.333<n>So the final answer will be 4 times<n><n>Input: A restaurant that serves $9.80 cheeseburgers and $2.90 fries charges tax at a 6% rate. How much is an entire meal including tax?<n>Output: The cost of a full meal is $2.90 + 2.90 + $0.05 + $1.06 = <<2.90+2.90+0.05+1.06=6.91>>6.91<n>The restaurant charges a 6% tax on the entire meal <n>So an entire meal has 6.91 + 0.63 = <<6.91+0.63 =13.54>>13.54% tax<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:After the guilty verdict in the killing the judge gave a speech, he told the murderer he was pure what? Choices:  A: wrong B: death of C: bad D: negative E: evil<n>Output:		Pure is something that is good/better than others (good or evil, but not bad).<n><n>Example: Pure is better than bad.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The billionaire donated a large sum to his former college, this allowed them to construct a new science what? Choices:  A: fraternity house B: bank C: big town D: big city E: building<n>Output:		The word “what” in the original question has a problem, it should be which word would replace the what, not the building<n>You have 4 choices which is A, B, C, and D<n>The billionaire donated to his former college, that college then constructed A building to commemorate the donation<n>So the final answer should be A: bank
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Many containers full of goods are unloaded where after their long sea journey Choices:  A: port B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: food E: lorry<n>Output:		A lorry is a truck, so it takes away the contents of a container.<n>The journey from ship to lorry is a short one.<n>Therefore, the right answer is A lorry.<n><n>Input:A woman’s shoe size is one less than twice the size of her daughter’s shoe size. If her daughter’s shirt size is three times her shirt size, what is the length in inches of her daughter’s dress?<n>Output:Let the daughter be 3x as tall as her and her dress be x.<n>Subtracting twice the daughter and mother's heights we get: 2.5 - 2 (the mother's height)<n>= 0.5 inches<n>If add 3 (the daughter's height and divide by 3, the daughter's dress length = <<3+0.5/3=17/3=5.66>>5.66 inches<n>So the final answer<n><n>Input:You and your friend go to the store. Choices:  A: question B: dispute C: deny D: contradict E: refuse<n>Output:		The application fails if the reference denies what has been previously said.<n>So what to do is say the opposite of what the reference said.<n><n>Example 1:<n>I will ask the applicant about the reference's comment, "He has 12 years of experience in the industry."<n>The reference will say he doesn't remember saying anything about the applicant's experience.<n>Now we ask the applicant, "What did your reference say about your experience?"<n>Now the applicant will say that her reference said, "She doesn't have any experience in the industry." <n><n>Example 2: <n>I will ask the reference about the applicant' application to an event.<n>The reference will say, "I remember she applied because she wants to dance a lot."<n>The application fails because the reference said the exact opposite:  "I don't remember her applying."<n>So the final answer in this case is C<n><n>Input: A student paid $1600 for a laptop, 100% of the total cost. How many months did it take to pay off the total purchasing price?<n>Output: Since the 100% rule comes first, it should be used first.<n>100% = $<<100%=1600>>1600, so 1600/1 = $<<1600/4000=0.4>>0.4<n>Then, we apply the percent rule in reverse order. <n>100% -.4 % = <<100% - 0.4%=0.6>>0.6<n>The 0.6 represents 60%, so 60% of 1600 = <<60% of 800=100>>100 months.<n>So the final amount is 100 months<n><n>Input: What’s the answer to a word problem where Tad has 4 pumps of gas, and 7 gallons cost $2.26?<n>Answer: 4 x $<< 4 x 2.26=11.36>>11.36, cost of 4 gallons is $<< 4 gallons=508.68>>508.6.<n>To get the rest, subtract the $<<538.

Choices:  A: open doors B: drink water C: need food D: annoy E: play<n>Output:		Let us assume that cats are only allowed to drink water, not water and doors which means option a cannot be correct<n>Now we need to think about the second option B.  Cats are always annoying other animals, not other humans, so option c cannot be the correct answer.<n>Doing the same for other options D and E, the only logical answer is that cats should be annoying other animals every day.<n>The correct answer is that "Cats annoy other animals every day"<n><n>Input: Which team wins a game of basketball when they both score 26 points, the first team to 27 wins?<n>Output: We see that 26 and 27 are both integer values. If we add them, we can check if they are identical and they are<n>The answer is that the team with more points will win. When there is an integer value tie, the team with less points will lose<n><n><n><n>Input: You’re at the fairgrounds. You get a medium sized hot dog, and you get 2 bags of chips and 4 soda bottles. In order to get all of your food for the fair, you decided to walk 200 meters. If you are walking at 3 km/H, how long does it take you to get all of your fair snacks?<n>Output: First we should note that we have three subcases. First we have the medium sized hot dog that is smaller than 200 meters, the hot dog costs 10 dollars. The second bag of chips that has a cost of 2 dollars, and finally the 4 soda bottle that is 1.50 each or 6 dollars.<n>First it is going to take us 10 minutes to complete the first food item, which is the med hot dog. We get that with 200 meters over 3 km/h. Second we get the second case. Since the second food item, the bags of chips cost 2 dollars and the speed of 3/km/hr is 3cm/s. So it will takes us 60 seconds for that food item. Finally the third item, which is 4 soda bottleneeds is 4 * 1.5=6 dollars and we get 1.5 over 3/km/s, completing the third item it will need 48 seconds

Choices: A: Mt Fuji B: Mt Everest C: Mt Kilamanjaro D: Mt Mckinley  Choices: <<A:Mt Fuji B:Mt Everest C:Mt Kilamanjaro>>D: Mt Mc Kinley<n>Output:  Mount Everest is the tallest mountain. <n>Mount Fuji is not the tallest mountain, but it is the tallest in Asia.<n>Mount Kilamanjaro is not the tallest either but is on the continent of Africa.<n>Mount McKinley is Mount McKinley is in the North America.<n>The tallest mountain choices are Mount Fuji, Mount Everest, and Mount McKinley<n><n>Output: Mount Everest is the choice that doesn’t fit into a continent.<n>The options are Asia, Africa, North America<n>Mount McKinley fits in North America.<n>Mount Fuji fits in Asia.<n>Mount Everest doesn’t fit in Asia nor Africa, and it is not in the area of North America.<n>So the final option is Mount Everest<n><n>Output: The first letter "C" does not correspond to any of the letters on the other choices.<n>The second letter "L" does not correspond to the letter E.<n>The third letter "T" does not correspond to another letter.<n>The choices are CHEAP, CHEATED, CHEATER, CHEATORS, and CHEAPLY<n><n>Output: This problem has no logic in the answers, so none of the four choices will be correct. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where are you if your reading magazines while waiting for a vehicle on rails? Choices:  A: vegetables B: market C: doctor D: train station E: bookstore<n>Output:		I would answer A because I am standing on a train station waiting for a train. I am in a bookstore I would answer E<n><n>Input: In a box, there are exactly 5 red balls, 7 green balls, and 1 blue ball. If you pick 6 balls from this box, how likely is it to contain exactly 3 red balls, 2 green balls, and 2 blue balls?<n>Output: There are only 6 balls, so after pick 6 balls, there are definitely not going to get a mixture of balls. It must be one of the following: <n>All 3 red balls <n>All 2 green balls, 2 red balls <n>All green balls <n>All blue balls<n>In other words :  <n>3+5= red<n>4+5= green<n>1+4= blue<n>so we can say  <n>3+2+2=4+5-3= 4+5-4=1
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If an actor is said to be on the “silver screen" where would you see them perform? Choices:  A: play B: movies C: theater D: screen E: television<n>Output:		A "silver screen" is a movie screen.<n>So the final would be answer be B the movies(play)<n><n>Input: If a baseball bat is 3 feet long and a football bat is 6 feet long, how long does it take to shave 14 feet of wood?<n>Output: The difference between the lengths of the 2 bats is 9-6 = <<9—6=3>>3<n>So it takes 3 seconds<n><n>Input: You can fill a bucket in 3 seconds. She turned around and began driving east.  If it took her 1/3 hour to cover 2/3 of the distance she traveled, how far did she drive?<n>Output: From the start, she drove west for ¼ = <<1/4=1/4>>1/4 hour and began driving east.<n>The ¼ hour she spent west was equal to the ¼ = <<1>="1/4">1/4 hour it took to finish the same time traveling east.<n>She made that journey 1/3 = <<1/3=1/3>>1/3 of the way and spent 1/3+1/3 = <<3/=2+1=>2 hours on the road.<n>If she spent 2/3 = <<2/3=2>>2 hours on her 2/3 = 1/3th of the way, it took her 3/3 = <<1+1=2>>2/3 hours to travel the full 3/3 =>>2>2/3 miles.<n>So the final distance is 2/3 =2/3 >2<n><n>Input: <n>Lynne is visiting a shopping mall and needs to pick out a pair of shoes. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n>Output:		John needs to travel South and doesn't say he's going to a certain point, just the region, so I put 'oklahoma'<n>The final answer is A<n><n>Input: Find the missing number in the sequence.<n><n>1,11,21,111,211<n>Output: This sequence has an obvious pattern that allows you to calculate the next term quickly.<n><n>1 + 1 = <<1+1=2>>2<n>11 + 1 = 111<n>21 + 1 =211<n><n>So when you get to 211 in the sequence, you simply add to it 211 + 1  - 211 + <<211+1-211+1=1+1=211>>211<n>To get the answer<n><n>So the final answer for this one is 221<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What happens when you take a shower after going for a run? Choices:  A: feeling refreshed B: becoming tired C: restlessness D: leg cramps E: sweating<n>Output:		When you go for a run, you need to start a shower, which does not leave you restless.<n>Your sweat is the byproduct of running, which is a by-product of energy expenditure, which is caused from running.<n>So the final is C<n><n>Input: A bird makes a nest out of sticks, string, rope, and cobwebs. A predator that weighs 5 pounds (lbs) is trying to sneak up on the bird. The bird weighs 3 times as much as the predator. Which of the following equations best represent both the predator’s weight and the weight of the bird?<n>Output: First we need to find the total weight of the bird by adding the weights of each item together.<n>3 x the bird’s weight = 3 x the weight of everything in the bird’s nest:  sticks, string, twine, cobwebs, and the bird<n>3 x the bird's weight =  <<3x the bird's weight=3x3=9>>9<n>The predator weighs 5 lbs + the final answer, so the predator weight -9 lbs = <<5+9=14>>14 lbs.<n>So the final result is 14 lbs<n><n>Input: There are 8 people in one room. The people are at different ends of the room and count the other people from their end of the room. If there are 7 people at the opposite end of the room, how many people, in total, can count the people at the opposite end from both ends of the room?<n>Output: There are 8 total people<n>7 people are on the opposite side<n>8 - 7 = <<8-7=1>>1 person left, so there are 7 + 1 = <<7+1=8>>8 people at both ends of the room who can count 7 people on the opposite side.<n>So the final anwer is 8. The total number of people<n><n>Input:  A small town is trying to plan a budget. A local restaurant donates food to keep the number of people fed at 125 for a certain day. If the price of food at the restaurant is $5 per person, the total donated food is $6.25 per person. They also have $30.13
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:No matter the background of the person, they should all be given what in applying for the job? Choices:  A: critical thinking B: congratulated C: equal opportunity D: compliments E: raffle tickets<n>Output:		Everyone who applies for the job should be given the same treatment and it does not matter what their background is so their answer should be A: critical, thinking D: compliments<n><n>#### Question #11<n>Input: The 3 friends all went to a baseball game for $30.  No one wore their tickets out yet so everyone gave theirs to someone else.  After making exchanges, 4 people came to the game with the tickets.  How much money did each person at the game spend?<n>Output: 3 people went to the game initially so each person spent 30/3 = <<30/3=10>>120$ each.<n>3 people went out of the game by giving their friends tickets so 4 people went to the game so each person spent 120/4 = <<120/4=30>>30$ each! How can that be?<n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What happens to the next appointment when a grooming takes longer than expected? Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n>Output:		We need to know what happens to a grooming appointment that took over time? Here are the choices:<n>A: If there is an injury, then the grooming appointment takes longer than expected<n>B: If a beauty grooming takes longer than normal then it takes longer<n>C: If your appointment is late then it will take longer than expected<n>D: If the groomer makes a mistake then the grooming appointment will take longer<n>E: If the appointment is annoyed then it will take longer.<n><n>We need to think about which situation has the groomers appointments taking longer.<n><n>So it’s going to be C because if they're late then it’ll take longer. So the final answer is C<n><n>Input:When you mix a pound of flour with 3/5 cups of sugar the flour and sugar should be about equal. What happens when you mix 7/5 cups of flour with 7/5 cupps of sugar?<n>Output: You are trying to use 4/5 cup of flour with 4/5 cups of sugared. But they're 7/5 and 7/5 so it shouldn't be about equal.<n>This means that 7/5/5 + 7/5= 5/5. Which isn't equal So the final answer is A<n><n>Input:Amy invested money in two different savings accounts, one pays a higher interest rate than the other. The graph shows her savings over time. To calculate her total savings, her interest rate is 8%  + 8%. What percent higher is her second account?<n>Output: We want to know what percent greater is the second account. So, we need to compare the values then the final percent.<n>We need to graph both of the values. Here's the graph:<n>Letters are not capitalized<n>[L: 8%  1] 8%= A                     [U: 8%  3] 8%= B<n>[L: 9%  4] 10%= C                     [U:  11% 9] 12%= D<n>We can see that C = D.<n>So the final percent is 9% ÷ 11%= <<9%/11%=100-1=99>>99.9 % or 10
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would you stand in a line and need a coat if it is cold? Choices:  A: graph B: bank at noon C: good book D: post office E: bus stop<n>Output:		If you are waiting for the bus, then you need to stand at the bus stop; otherwise, you don't need a coat.<n>If you are waiting at the bank; then you need to stand in the bank; otherwise, you don’t need a coat. <n>If you are waiting for a good book; then you need to be at the library.  Otherwise, you don’t  need a coat.<n>Either way, you need to be at a place where a good book exists.<n>If you are at a graph, then you don’t need to be at the bank; otherwise,you  need to stand in the coat line.<n>Either way you need to be near a warm bank at noon or 12 (the noon of 12)<n>If you are waiting in line at the post office then you don’t  have to wait at the bank at noon; otherwise, you need to be somewhere at noon.<n>So the final option is that you should be at the post office.<n><n>Input: Anika wanted a new pair of boots and saw a $40 pair on sale for $10. She has $100 to her name. At what other price should she look?<n>Output: First think about what items Anika can afford on her $100. She can’t afford the original $40 price. Since she has $100 and the boots are $40, then the boots exceed her budget.  When the original $40 boots exceed her budget, she can’t purchase those boots because there aren’t any other prices of 30 boots that she can afford.<n>If Anika finds a pair of $30 boots, then she can buy them. Anika’s budget is $100 and her budget exceeds the price of two $30 items. Since the boots exceed her $100 budget, she can afford an extra $30. Since her total budget is $10, she can also afford two $30 boots.<n>So the final options are to choose the $30.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. Choices:  A: park B: motel C: corner D: bus stop E: store front<n>Output:		The most likely answer is (A, B, D, E) because that is where you would expect to generally find these locations (in a park, motel, corner, or shop)<n><n>Input: Which two of the following words are not synonyms?Choices (A, D, G) Choices (C, D, G)<n>Output: The answers are (A, D,) because of the different spelling structure.<n><n>Input: Who has more points?<n>Choice (A) 8 points<n>Choice (B) -7 points<n>Choice (C) 700 points<n>Choice (D) -17 points<n>Output: A is smaller than D, so the answer is D.<n><n>Input:  A = 8 + 7<n>B = -10 - (9+2)<n>C = 30 - 22<n>D = 8 - (4+4)<n>Choose all the equal expressions.<n>The expression A is not equal to B because 8 + 7 is different from (-10)(9+2), 30 is different from 22, 8 is different from 4+4.<n>The expression B is not equal to C because -10 is different from (9+2), -10 is different in -22 etc...<n>The expression A is equal to C because 8 + 8 = 8 + (9+2).<n>The expression A is even to D because 8 + 2 = (8+4+4)<n>So the final answer was C was even to D.<n><n>Input -2(x+2)<n>Output -2 (x+2) = (2x-4)<n><n>### Step 1<n><n>Instructions: Add the two statements to create a conditional expression<n><n>## Input -2(x+y)<n>## Output -2 (x+y) = (y-5))<n><n>### Step2<n><n>Input:4(x-2)<n>Output: 4 (x-2) = (x+1)<n><n>## Step3<n><n>[![](https://github.com/pink-sugar0727/CS451.2016/raw/master/problem6.jpg)](https://github.com/-sugar1207/CS45.2

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:John loves animals and he hates animal abuse.  Because of this, john is very careful about the places he goes.  Where might he avoid going? Choices:  A: pet store B: parking lot C: woodland D: north america E: park<n>Output:		Since he loves animals, and he doesn't like animal abuse, he wouldn't go to a park. So the answer is, he wouldn't avoid going to a park<n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What would you tell ali to do if he bumps into you when you are walking? Choices:  A: work hard B: slow down C: wear shoes D: sell products E: speed up<n>Output:		When asked if you walk fast or slow, the options are:<n>A: work hard - <<work hard>>work hard<n>B: slow down - <<slow down>>slow down<n>C: wear shoes - <<wear shoes>>wear shoes<n>D: sell products - <<sell products>>sell products<n>E: speed up - <<speed up>>speed up<n>So the A is work hard and its answer is not B: slow down <<slow down>>slow<n>the B is slow down and its answer is not A: work hard <<work hard>>work<n>the C is wear shoes and its answer is not D: sell products <<sell products>> sell products<n>the D is sell products and its answer is not E speed up <<speed up>>speed<n>the E is speed up and its answer is not C wear shoes << wears shoes>> wear shoes<n>So the final answer<n>is wear shoes<n><n>Input: The farmer had 200 eggs.He divided his eggs equally to make several kinds of tarts. He divided each kind into 3 pieces. How many does each customer get?<n>Output: Total customers = 200<n>Each customer will get 3/200 = <<3/200=0.015>>0.015<n>So the final answer = 0.015

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:She curled up under a blanket to get warm, this made her what on the couch as they started movie? Choices:  A: sleep B: feel more comfortable C: sweating D: blush E: cuddle<n>Output:		She felt more comfortable in the blanket than she felt without<n>If we look at all the words that could possibly describe the feeling, we'd see that:<n>A could only be feeling warm, and it could only be while she was in the blanket.<n>B could only be feeling more comfortable in general, and it wouldn't make sense that she felt comfortable while she was feeling warm.<n>C could only be feeling sweaty<n>D and E could both be a description of when she was already comfortable.<n>D could also be a description of when it wasn't the movie that made her comfortable, but another person.<n>E could also be a description when the other person made her comfortable.<n>We could also see that A has the right prefix (a- is a negative prefix)<n>C and D have the right suffix (ful is an adjective suffix that means "the state of being")<n>E has a similar structure to B<n>So the final answer for the last question is A.<n><n>### The following question requires you to write a short program that will take one integer and convert it to an integer in binary.<n><n>    #define MAX 10000<n><n>    class Binary<n>    {<n>        public:<n>            Binary(int value) : num(value) { printf("Got a binary value of %d\n",value); }<n>            void getBinary(int value)<n>            {<n>                int i, n, k;<n>                n = 0;<n>                for(i = 0; i < MAX; i++)<n>                {<n>                    n = i;<n>                    for(k = n; k > n; k = k/2)<n>                    {<n>                        n = k;<n>                    }<n>                    if (n % 2)<n>                    printf("%c\n", n);<n>                    else<n>                    printf("%d\n", n); <n>                }<n>            }<n>        private:<n>            int num;<n>    };<n><n>If you want to try another option:<n>https://www.hackerrank.com/contests/css/challenges/integer-to-binary-conversion/e5297b75-d7a8-4ec2-84cf-c21306ed689f<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20.
