Your alarm typically goes off 5 minutes before your morning shift starts. How many minutes early do you really have to wake up on average?<n>Output: <n>First you add the two times:<n>05:35 + 5<n>= <<05:35+5=>6:35<n><n>Now to find the difference in minutes:<n>You subtract the alarm by the time you wake up:<n><n>6:35 - 6:20 = <<6:35-6:20=>10<n><n>So divide that time in half<n>5:35 minutes before clock is supposed to actually start<n><n>5:35 / 2 = <<5:35/2=2:45>>2:45<n><n>And then you add in the time until you have to be to work<n><n>(05:35 - 2:45) + <25> + <20><n>= <<(05:30+25+20)=41>>41 minutes on average
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Sarah thought that she had been home all evening.  That meant that the only time to leave was when? Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n>Output:		Sarah thought she'd been home all evening. So we can assume she wasn't home in the morning, and the night.<n>That leaves Sarah in day time.<n>So the final answeir is option D "day time"<n><n>Input: If someone is at most 18, then can they be at least 14 and at least 10? Choices:  True False<n>Output:If someone is at most 4, then can they be greater than or equal to 10? ChoiceTrue<n>If a person is at most 14, they are at least 10 since 14 is at least than 10.<n>So the final choice is yes.<n><n><n>Input: Is the statement "all boys are people" false? Choices:  False True<n>Output:There are cases when "all boys are people", since a boy could be a person too. So it's not always false.<n>So we select option True for the final answer<n><n>Input: Is it possible to make a meal, using only vegetables and fruits, that costs more than the minimum monthly salary of an adult in Denmark? Choices:  Yes, no<n>Output:It's not possible to make a meals using only vegetables and fruit that can costs more than the minimum salary. Since Denmark is a cold weather country, so fruits and vegetables are really pricey because they're in large demand.<n>So we select 'no' as the final answer.<n><n>Input: Someone says that it is possible to make a meeal, using only vegetable and fruits. Can this be correct? Choices:  Absolutely Not Absolutely Incorrect Absolutely Yes Absolutely Correct<n>Output:As long as it's in the right kind of foods, it can.<n>So we select answer option Absolutely Yes as the final answer.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The child really wanted to teach his grandpa to read, he thought it was wrong that he had spent his whole life what? Choices:  A: ignore B: write C: learn new things D: illiterate E: having fun<n>Output:		The child really wanted his grandpa to have fun learning to read because he wanted to teach his grandfather  to read because he thought it was wrong: <<3: C: learn new things>>C: learn new things<n>So the final answer should be c: learn new things<n><n>Input: There is some fruit juice in Bob’s 5 gallon pail. The fruit juice is 5% fruit juice. How much fruit juice is in it?<n>Output: Since it is 5 gallon pails and it is 5% fruit, then the answer is 5 * 5 = <<5*5=25>>25<n>So the final answer here is 25<n><n>Input: Tom wants to give to his children equally. He has $2 to start and he can purchase a new toy every time he doubles his money. He buys five toys and is left with $1 to give to his children. How much should each of his children get?<n>Output: Tom’s initial amount is $2, each time he doubles his money he will have $4 since 2 x 2 = <<2×2=4>>4<n>However five doubles is 1x5 = 10 and Tom’s initial amount, 2, is left when he has $1.<n>It is 10/2 = 5 left for his children<n>So each child will get $5 in Tom’s toys because 5/ children = 5<n>The final answer is 5<n><n>Input: There are three candies left in the candy jar. One is 3 times as sweet as the other, and 2 is 6 times as sweet as the third. Each candy is a different size: one small, one medium, and one large. If the small and medium candies are equal in sweetness but double the size of the large candy, and each candy is a different price, which candy is which size and how much is each candy worth?<n>Output: There are three candys left, one is triplet the other. Each candy is 3/ the large one. <<5: E: the large candy cost 5 times more.>>E: the candy cost 5 time more.<n>So, one candy is triple the other and double in size. One is big but cost more than 3/ cost same amount as the
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What would a person expect if they are competent in their school work? Choices:  A: compliments B: passing grade C: intellectual challenge D: sticker E: avoid pain<n>Output:		What is the probability of receiving a compliment and having a passing grade for doing school work?<n>(Probability of receiving a compliment) * (Probability of getting a passing grade) =  <<Probability of receiving compliment*Probability of getting passing grade>><n>Probability of receiving and compliment from their teacher = <<4/20+7/20>>4/16 = 0.25<n>Probability of getting and passing grade from their teacher = <<9/30+2/30>>9/3*9/3 = 0.35<n>Multiplying 0.25 * 0.35 > <<0.25*0.35=0.0875>> 0.087<n>There would still be 0.08 chances (0.087 / 0.16) = <<0.087/0.16=0.08>> 0.06  for the teacher to give both a compliment and a passing grade.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:There weren't enough chairs for everyone.  What might have to be delayed? Choices:  A: bookstore B: building C: meeting D: office E: coffeehouse<n>Output:		If you have less of something than the total amount, you "run out", "finish", "run out of", or "have no more of".<n>So what would have to be delayed is the meeting<n>So the final answer <n>is the meeting<n><n>Input: What is 748 + 120?<n>Output: 748 = <<748=748>>748<n>Plus 120 = <<Plus 120:120>>120<n>+ 120 = 0<n>So the final answer<n>is 0<n><n>Input: 40 x 5 - 8 x 3 = ______?<n>Output: 40 x <?40=40>>4=40 5 - <-8x3:-8x3=16>>16<n>40 x 5 minus 8 x 3 will equal 40 x 20 - 8x 5<n>So 20 and 5 in the first two multiplications<n>So the final answer will be 40 x 15<n><n>Input:What is 420-160+3-2<n>Output: I start off with 420-<-160-+3-/-2>>-160-3-2<n>So 420 take away 160 plus 3 minus 2 will equal 248-3-2<n>When I take 248-<3-2>>3 and I subtract 2<n><+1>>1 I would get 246 minus 1<n>When I did that I got 246 minus<1>>1<n>So the final answer = 246<n><n>Input: What time is 6 plus 6, 8 plus 8, and 8 plus 8?<n>Output: 6+6= <<6+6=12>>1<n>8+8 = 16<n>I have 16-12 because 12 is what I get for 6+6<n>So I get 16 - 12<n>So the answer is 4<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What preposition do you use if you want to combine two words? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: chemist's shop C: kitchen D: drug store E: bedroom<n>Output:		If your birth control pills are near your toothpaste, then they are in the medicine cabinet.<n><n>There are two methods of answering this question.<n><n>The first method is to choose each choice individually and calculate how many are in the kitchen vs. are not in the kitchen:<n><n>    Answer = if((B-E)/A>0.5, 1, 0)<n><n>The second method is to add the options where they are not in the kitchen and subtract to get the options in the kitchen.<n><n>    Answer = (B-E)+(A-E)-(C-E)<n><n>The method that allows more flexibility in how the question is answered is to use the second method.<n><n>Therefore, the answer will be:<n><n>    Answer= (B-E)+((A-E)-C)<n><n>Using the second method we can see that 9 out of 11 birth control pills are in the kitchen.<n>So 0.8181 or 81.81% of birth control pills are kept in the kitchen.<n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where should you find a school in? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: mosque C: every city D: prague E: community<n>Output:		The answer is A because a residential neighborhood is the answer for a school<n><n>Input:Find the cost based on a price of $5 and a quantity of the price. 10, 20, 40<n>Output: Cost is based on a price of 5 and a quantity of 10, which is equal to 50<n>Cost based on 50 is 10 = 50 ÷ 5 = <<50/10=10>>1.<n>If the quantity is 40, then cost is 40 = 50 / 2 = <<50/2=25>>5<n>Cost based on 25, is 25 = 50 /4 = <<50/4=12>>1.<n>If quantity is 5, then 5 = 50 10 = <<50/0=5>>5<n>The answer is between 1 and 5 and not more than five<n><n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where is a notebook often purchased? Choices:  A: bookstore B: backpack C: abraham lincoln's grave D: desktop E: classroom<n>Output:		Choices are A, B, C, D and E<n>It is common for students to find notebooks in the back of the classroom when they are using a desk as a seat because most notebooks are in backpacks.<n>It is common for people to find notebooks sold in stores, like A is back of the classroom then the answer is C<n>It is possible to purchase notebooks in bookstores, like A is backpack then the answer is B.<n>It is uncommon to have notebooks sold on Abraham Lincoln's grave, like B is a classroom then the answer D.<n>It is common to find the answer in a classroom, because a classroom has most probably notebooks.<n><n>So the final answer<n>Output: A and C<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If you are driving too fast on an icy road you are being what? Choices:  A: deadly B: dangerous C: unconcerned D: stressful E: harder when weather bad<n>Output:		If you are driving to fast on icy roads then it is very dangerous because it becomes hard when weather is bad<n>So the final answer should be A<n><n>Input:In a survey of 600 adults, 2/3 have children, 1/4 are atheist, and 1/5 are from a different country than the U.S. How many adults in the survey do not have kids?<n>Output: If 2/3 have kids then 2/3 - 1/4 - 1/5 = 600 - 18 - 20 = <<600-18-20=562>>562 people don't have kids<n><n>Input: What is the greatest common factor of 100, 120 and 140? Choices: A: 30 B: 20 C: 40 D: 0<n>Output: The greatest common factor is 20, and 20 is between 100 and 14<n>So the final answer will be A<n><n>Input;When you move a 75 pound rock, you use 35 pounds of force. How much force is needed to move an 120 pound rock<n>Output:So if 75 lb is 35pounds of force x2<n>So you need 68 lb of force to move a 120lb rock<n>So the final answer would be D<n><n>Input: The height of a rectangle is twice the width. If the measurements are 3 feet by 6 feet, what is the length of the rectangle? Choices: 33 feet 20 feet 40 feet 44 feet<n>Output:(3+6)² = 7²=28<n>So The length could be 28 feet

A 36 pound dog needs $11 to get in shape.  By how much is the dog overweight?<n>Output: The dog is overweight by 3 pounds.  A dog of 36 pounds requires $11 to get into shape.  The dog walker charges $3 per pound for each mile over 36 pounds.  Here $3 per pound x 3 pounds over 36 pounds = $<<3*3=9>>9 more required for each 3 mile walk, because 9+11 = <<9+11=20>>20 miles total and $9/20 = <<9/20=0.45>>0.45 per walk<n>So the final answer 0.45<n><n>Input: After a day at The Museum of Science and Industry, Emily earned $1.25 after spending $1.75. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Choices:  A: feeble B: bullbleep C: cow D: female E: charging prey<n>Output:		 A bull is often used as a nickname for men, just based on the name alone.<n>So the final ans<n><n>Input:He decided when playing a video game to be a: <n>Choices:<n> A: fighter B: fighter jockey C: fighter jet D: fighter pilot E: fight<n>Output:<n>A fighter = fighter<n>B fighter jockey = fighter jockey<n>C fighter jet = fighter jet<n>D fighter pilot = fighter pilot<n>E fight = fight.<n>So the final and answer is fight.<n><n>Input: A pizza was divided between three children. 10% of the pizza was saved to be frozen. The pizza was then completely divided between the children, making each child have the same number of pieces. What percent of the pizza is reserved?<n>Output: One can think of this as:<n>(1-0.1) * 100% = (90% - 10%)/100% = 90/100 = 9/10 = < 9/10=.9>>.9<n><n>This is the percent of the pizza saved to be frozen<n>.1 * 100%, in this case, is the percent of the original pizza that each child gets. Then, divide it by 100%.<n><n>Answer: 100 % /.9 = 111.111111...<n><n>So,.9 * 111. = 97<n><n>Answer is 97<n><n>Input: You are given an equation that can be divided by 2, 3, or 5. If that equation's solution is a perfect square, enter "Perfect Square", if not, enter "Not a Perfect Square", otherwise enter "Cannot be determined". For example, "Cannot be determined" if the equation is 3×2 = 6, and cannot be divided by 2 or 3. Or, "Not a Perfect square" if the equation 10003 = 1003023, and cannot be divided into 3's.<n>Output: Solve for n: y = mx. y = 3x+1 (y = mx + a) Divide by 3: 3x
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:James drove his niece to her father.  Where did he drive? Choices:  A: great granddad's house B: family picture book C: brother's house D: family tree E: family reunion<n>Output:		Here, James has to drive to his niece’s father’s house. The correct answer is "E: family reunition".<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the multiple choice and numeric questions.<n><n>Input: How many people were in the audience last night? Choices: A: 8 people B: 16 people C: 32 people D: 37 people<n>Output: The correct answer is Choice C "32 people". (We know that the number of people in the audience can't be negative, and can't be "37" because 37  > 36.)<n><n>Input: The number of students in the school is prime and the number of children in the school is even. How many students are in the school? Choices: A) 20 B) 10 C) 60  D) 21<n>Output: The correct choice is "D: 10". Choice "A" (20) and "C" (60) are not prime. We know that the given condition on the given number of students says that students in the given school must be prime, so they can't be 20 or 60.<n><n>Input: 4 children in a class have brown hair and 6 babies in the nursery have brown hair. If the nursery has 12 children, how many children in the nursery don’t have brown hair?<n>Output: 12 - 4 = <<12-4=8>>8 children.<n>Since 8 ≠ 0 (zero), then there are 8 babies in the given nursery without brown hair.<n><n>Input: I read that 3 is a prime number?<n>Output: Yes, 3 is a prime. 3 ≠ 0, 3 ≠ 1, 3 ≠2, 3 ≠3.<n><n>Input: Can you name all of the Prime numbers?<n>Output: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19,<n><n>### Instructions:If you answer a given question wrong, you get credit for the following 3 questions! But don’t worry, its all fun.<n><n>(if you answer something incorrectly, you are given 3 points
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What could you buy in a bookstore? Choices:  A: carpeting B: magazines C: strip mall D: city E: applesauce<n>Output:		The answer: A(carpeting), E(applesauce)<n><n>Input: What animal does most of its sleeping on its back?<n>Output:  Cat(cat)<n><n>Input: A person wearing clothes that have a $500 clothing. If he wears 50% off everything, does he still have $500 left?<n>Output: The answer is Yes<n><n>Input: What type of cheese is mostly yellow? Choices:  C: American D: Brie E: Cheddar F: Swiss G: Mozzarella<n>Output: The answer A(America)<n><n>Input: How many pizza places per a million people must a state have? Choices:  H: at least 5 I: at most 5 J: at least 4<n>Output: The answer K(Korea)<n><n>Input: If a person takes in 12 liters of water per day, how much water might he be holding in his bladder each day?Choices: A: 1 liter B: 12 liters C: 24 liters D: 100 liters E: 500 liters<n>Output: The answer B(12 liters)<n><n>Input: In which month was Halloween in 1993?Answer: A: November B: May C: October D: December E: February<n>Output: The answer D(December)<n>	
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. Choices:  A: get money B: pay money C: go shopping D: lose money E: save money<n>Output:		Some stores trick women to buy many different things. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What does god want people to do for money? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is the result of instituting civil action? Choices:  A: bad feelings B: confusion C: going to court D: hurt feelings E: sandwiches<n>Output:		Civil action can make people have confusion and bad feelings<n><n>Input:What was on the TV? Choices:  Apple Pie A: apple B: peach C: vanilla D: blueberry <n>Output: Apple pie<n><n>Input:How long is 10.3 hours? Choices: <n>A: 1 minute B: 10 minutes C: 190 minutes D: 2 minutes<n>Output: 10.3 equals 10.3, so 10.3 minutes.<n><n>Input:What does 1+3 =? Choices: 10 A: 2 B: 13 C: 8 D: 4 <n>Output:  1+3=4<n>Input:What does x =? Choices:  10 A: 3 B: 4 C: 5 D: 6<n>Output: x=3<n><n>Input: How much does the dog cost? Choices:  <n>A: 200 B: 300 C: 400 D: 500 <n>Output: 500. Dogs cost $500<n><n>Input: Find the length of the triangle Choices:  A 6 inches B 10 inches C: 12 inches<n>Output:  The triangle  is 150 degrees and 12 inches. So, the length of the triangle is 6√150=<<6√150≈3.820985>>3.82085 inches. The final answer is 3.8205 inches.<n>Input: When she was 20 pounds lighter, her weight was: A: 20 pounds more B: 20 pounds less <n>C: 2.6 times heavier D: 2.66 times heavier<n>Output: 2.6x1.05=2.66<n><n>Input: What is 2.863826 rounded to the nearest hundredth?  <n>Choices:  A: 2.87 B: 2.86 C: 2.85 D: 2.84 <n>Output: 2+.8638 = 3, so the nearest hundredth is 3.86, which rounds to 3.8.

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is something that you feel when you go to the opera? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: headache C: boredom D: relaxation E: sick<n>Output:		A: fall asleep<n>B: headache<n>C: boredom<n>D: relaxation<n>E: sick<n>If the answer is something other than fall asleep, you do not have to answer this problem (it can be A or B or C or D or E).<n><n>You do not have to answer any more problems if you get a question wrong.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would you find a desk normally occupied by a young person? Choices:  A: office building B: schoolroom C: library D: bedroom E: gym<n>Output:		A desk is something normally found in your office or in an office building. So, the correct answer is A: office building<n><n>Input: A young woman is 3 times as old as her friend, whose age is one-half that of her own. How old are they?<n>Output:Let Youngwoman's age is A, her friend's is B, and (A/4 is a quarter of Youngwoman's, and of her friend's.<n><n>A is A+1.<n>So, Youngwoman's is A-1, and her friend's is A/4-1= <<A/4-1=A/5>>A/5<n>Now, find Youngwoman's by subtracting A/4-1 from A, which is:<n><n>4A - (A+1) = <<4A-A+1=A-1/4>>A-1/4<n>-A-1/4 = <<-A-1/A=1/4+1>>1/4+1<n>-A-1(1/2)-A-1/4= <<-A-1*1/2-A-1/2=1/4+A-1/4+A>>1/4+A/2-A/4= <<1/4+A+A/2>> A+A/2<n>So, (1/4)+A/2+A-1/2 = << 1/4+A2+A-1= A-A+1/2>> A-A+A/2<n>And, from this, (A-A/2)-A = << A-A+A-A/2= -A/2>> -A/2<n>And from this, A/2-A = << A/2-A= A/4>>A-2A<n>So, subtracting A/2 from A-1 and subtracting A/4 from A results in A-1-A/2 = A-5/4<n><n>Now, Youngwoman'an age is A-2A/2 + A/4 - A/2 = << A-5/2 -2A>>-2A.<n>It is a quadratic equation, so we can solve for the two sides of it, and see to which one the result of solving the equation for
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:People celebrate by going places and riding rides.  What's one obvious place people might go to celebrate? Choices:  A: state park B: opera C: disneyland D: carnival E: park<n>Output:		One obvious place is State park, because the rest of the options talk about rides such as Roller coaster, Rides, carnival, etc<n>So the final answer here is <<A>>A<n><n>Input:The numbers 53, 70, 20, and 85 are all divisible by 5.  Which one is also divisible by 2? Choices: A: 70 B: 53 C: 20 D: 85 E: all of them<n>Output: Since every number is divisible by 5, then they are all divisible by <2>.<n>So the final answer has to be <<E>>E<n><n>Input: There are 30 people going to the movies this Friday night. Each person attending the movies will buy 2 large bags of popcorn, and 1 small candy bar. There are 4 different types of candy bars that the people might buy. Three of the people will buy 5 of each type of candy bar. Seven of the people will buy only 3 of each type of cody bar, and one of the people will only buy 1 of each type of cocoa bar. How many of each type of cloy are the other 19 people going to buy?<n>Output: There are 3 different types of chocolate that the people might buy, so 19 of the 30 total have bought either 3 chocolates or 1 chocolate 5*3=<<5*3=15>>15<n>2*1=<<2*1=2>>2<n>3*3=<<3*3=9>>9<n>9*2=<<9*2=18>>16<n>18*2=<<18*2=36>>30<n>Including the 1 person who bought 1 of each type that has <<1>>1, the total number of chocolates they bought 40<n>There are 5 people in total who only buy 1 of type of chocolate, so they bought 3 of every. 1*3=<<1*3=3>>3<n>Therefore the final answer is <8>8 chocolates.<n><n>Input: One of the four siblings in this family is 9 years younger than the oldest sibling. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Stopping being married to one another was a costly task, the lawyers and their what were astronomical? Choices:  A: free time B: pleasure C: get divorced D: legal fees E: being lonely<n>Output:		A) Stopping being married to one other was a costly task. The lawyers were very expensive.  (Lawyers' fees)<n><n><n>### Instruction:The following task is based on the following image.<n><n>![image](./image/image.png)<n>![image](./instruct/2.jpg)<n>![image](https://github.com/Jason-Gao/Leetcode/blob/master/Instruct/2.jpg?raw=true)<n><n><n>## # Solution<n><n>### Java:<n><n>```java<n>public int solution(int n) {<n>    if (n == 0) {<n>        return 0;<n>    }<n>    //if n%2==0, then n is even, so n/2 is the middle of the sequence,<n>    <n>    return(n / 2) + solution(n/2) + solution((n / 2) * 3);<n>  }<n><n>```<n><n><n>### Python Solution: <n><n>```python<n>from functools import reduce<n>def solution(n):<n>    a = reduce(lambda x,y: x+y,(x,y) for x in range(1,int(n/2)+1) for y in range(1, int(n / (x*3))+1))<n>    return a<n><n>print(solution(n))<n>```
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. I will experience sadness, and the scars I will have from it.<n><n>Input:In order to win their team’s game, the coach assigned 5 defensive players. If the score was tied when the team had only played for 60 minutes, how many players did the coach add in order to win the game?<n>Output: If I win the game if I play 5 defensive players, plus some odd ones with some outliers. If I'm tied 4 players, and I have to get six people to win, so I add just one. The odd players still do as much as the others. If I win 6 times each hour, then after 1 hour I want 6 more people and the same rules I'm not losing anything.<n><n>Input: What are the possible words for 6 vowels and 7 consonants?  <n>Choices:  A. So the possible words in this combination are A:HAPPIL,D:OILY,E:POILY.<n><n>Input:  What are the odd man-out choices?  <n>Choices; A. M, N, Q, S B. J, L, Q, S C. M, N, O, Q, S D. W, Y, Z, B, P, F Output; Here the odd man-out options are: A. M, N, Q, S B. J, Q; N, S, C. M, N, O, Q;S D.W,Y,Z, WB,P,F Here all the words are the odd man out because they make a word like JO, Q, OILY or something like that.<n><n>Important Notes:<n>1. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is a common sign that someone is lying? Choices:  A: ordering dog food online B: avoid eye contact C: feel guilty D: fall asleep E: blush<n>Output:		Blush is a common sign that a person is lying because they experience an increase in blood flow to their cheeks.<n>So the final question is B<n><n>Input:In what months of the year do more babies get born? Choices A:October, March B:July, September C: June, May D: February, September E: December, June<n>Output: The question can be rephrased to, is more than one month used to determine what months have more births? If so, the answer would be D<n>So the final question would be E<n><n>Input: When is Earth's magnetic field most likely to shift? Choices: A:  April B: April, May, June C: March, April, May D: March, June, July E: April, May, September<n>Output: None of the answer choices mention the months of September or December or January or February. This is because these months do not have any solar or lunar eclipses. So the question is to identify the months of September or when there would be lunar or solar eclipses. The final answer is D
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Everybody has a little bit of creativity, but only a few lucky ones get to do what for a living? Choices:  A: sew B: create art C: express yourself D: sing and dance E: write<n>Output:		<n>C: <n>So the final answer  is C<n><n>Instruction:Answer the following short answer, long answer questions.<n><n><n>For each of the following questions, write a program that calculates the correct answer. Your program should request the user to enter the values used in the problem, or just use them from the variables provided. If there are additional questions asked in the problem, use the loop.<n><n> <n><n>Question:The price of a video game is $3 and the cost of a cup of coffee is $2. If you saved two dollars, how much would you have left?<n>Output: Saved two dollars: $2.00<n><n>How much would you have left in total: $1.00<n><n> <n><n>How much would that total cost to purchase a video game and a cup of coffee?<n>Output: The price of a video game that is $2 and the cost of a coffee is $2, it would cost $4<n><n> <n><n>If you have $5.44, does this money meet your goal of having enough money to purchase a video game?<n>Output: No, it does not, it does not meet your goal of having money to purchase a video of game $5.44 is less than $6<n><n> <n><n>Use the variables provided in this program to calculate the following. First, ask the user for their age.  Next, ask the user if they are older than the age in the variable named "ageLimit". If so, ask "Can I make you a burger?", then subtract $5 from "totalCost", and reset "totalCost" to $0.  Otherwise, ask, "Can I get you a shake?", add $2 to totalCost, and reset totalCost to $0. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Bob is in a dressing room.  He's putting on waterproof trunks and goggles.  What sort of facility is he most likely visiting? Choices:  A: swimming pool B: actors and actresses C: fancy restaurant. D: gym E: theatre<n>Output:		The correct answer is B.<n>The rest are all misleading choices<n><n>Input: Alice wants to run a marathon. Alice knows that she can run 5 miles in an hour. How far can Alice run in 22 hours?<n>Output: First, let’s see how far in an hour. Alice can run 5 miles per hour.<n>Now, let’s see in 22 hours.  We know we’re asking about how far she can run in 22, so we can let x equal that.  We can use this equation: x = 22 / 5 x = <<22/5=4.4>>4.4 (rounded) miles. <n>So the final answer for how far Alice can run in 23 hours is 4.4<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:He was selling all his collector items even the rare plate, he had bought a lot at the what for the weekend? Choices:  A: supermarket B: kitchen cupboard C: table D: flea market E: dishwasher<n>Output:		The plate is considered a collector item, so he is looking to sell the collector items.<n>He went to a lot of places over the weekend, some of the places mentioned may be a lot or dishwasher or kitchen cupboard.<n>So the final question is A or B

If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What state shaped like a glove has a lot of farmland? Choices:  A: countryside B: farming areas C: michigan D: texas E: north dakota<n>Output:		 The answer to the question is countryside, which is a different word than farmland<n><n>Input: On a Sunday, if the first letter of the day is capitalized and the rest are lowercase, how many days of the week does this describe?<n>Output: <<5>>5 days of the week.<n>Sunday is the first letter in capitalized and the rest is lowercase, so there 6 days in the week.<n>So the finalanswer is 6<n><n>Input: In a large city, half of the adults work as engineers, and one third of the children work as scientists. Ten percent are teachers. If there are 5,432 professional scientists, how many teachers are there? <n>Output: <<5432>>5,432/10 = <<5432/14>>4,029 teachers<n>There are 4,029 / 3 children per adult = <<4029/3>>1342 children<n>So 1,342 ×1/3 = <<1342*1/3=444>>444 teachers<n>So the final answer 444<n><n>Input: An ancient book found in an Egyptian pyramid was 1,210 pages. Of the 1,21 pages in the book, 25 were missing. How many were there if each page is 4.5 by 3 inches?<n>Output: <<4.5x3>>2081/25 = <<121/25=4.84>>4.84<n>The missing pages were 5 of 12.<n>Total = 450 -5 = <<450-5=445>>121.<n>So there total is 121/22 = <<121*22/22=4.84>></><n>So the final answer it is 4.84<n><n>Input: There are 1,215 students at school, 49 of whom go to the library each day.
