He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would you find a sign with some people lined up next to it? Choices:  A: bus stop B: street corner C: roadblock D: fast food drive thru E: city<n>Output:		All of these are options for a line.<n><n>The correct answer is: A: bus stop<n><n><n>Input: A store bought 50 donuts at a discount on which 40 remain. During a sale, a 25% discount is offered on each item. After paying for 10 donuts at the sale price, 75% of the total cost of his purchase is reached. What does he end up paying?<n>Output: A: $<<25/100 x 50+100=230>>230<n>B: $<<500-230=360>>360<n>C: $<<250-360=110>>110<n>D: $<<20-20=0>>0<n><n>The correct answer: D: $<20-20 = 0>>0<n><n>Input: How would $25, $20 and $15 look?<n>Answer: <n>1 x 1 = 1 <n>   2 x 2 = 4<n>   3 x 3 = 9<n><n>Input: A class has 32 students: 4 girls and 28 boys. If one of the boys got a parking ticket during a school field trip, how many less boys would still be at the field trip if the same number of girls were there?<n>Answer: The number of boys that are at the field trip would be 28 - 1 = <<28-1=27>>27<n>The number of boys that are still there, after removing 1 boy that got a parking ticket, is 27-1 = <<27-1=26>>26<n>The number of boys is going to be 26 - number of girls = <<26-4=22>>22<n>The number of people left overall is 32 - 22 = <<32-22=10>>18<n>The final result is 22<n><n>Input: During a school fundraiser, students sold raffle tickets with each person selling 30 tickets on their own. In total, the group sold 2853 tickets. If each sold 30 tickets, where was each student able to obtain a ticket?<n>Answer:
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What appliance uses water and soap? Choices:  A: washing machine B: space shuttle C: blender D: disneyland E: surface of earth<n>Output:		 A: wash.  It uses water and soap.<n><n><n><n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The whole family was playing cards, they were full of joy and what? Choices:  A: sadness B: happiness C: amusement D: losing money E: anger<n>Output:		A: sadness<n>B: happiness<n>C: amusement<n>D: losing money<n>E: anger<n>The only emotion you can get when playing cards is winning. And only losing money is an outcome that you feel bad. So the final answer is A
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The king was to meet an ambassador, where would the meet? Choices:  A: court B: dinning room C: throne room D: monarchy E: castle<n>Output:		After looking closely, you think it was meet A: court because the king's court is what the monarchy is about.<n>So the final chosen answer is A: court<n><n>Input:A group of girls got to work on their science experiment. The group consists of four students that formed a pair of two. Each pair needs $3 more than 30 to buy the necessary materials. All materials, minus the two pairs, come to $118. How many dollars does each pair need?<n>Output: Each pair needs $31, because 118 - 3 - 3 = <<118-3-3=31>>31<n>So the final answer to this question is 31<n><n>Input: You have 15 more eggs than 6 dozen eggs. You need to buy 14 dozen eggs for an upcoming event. How many eggs do you need to buy to have a dozen eggs left over?<n>Output: 15+12 = <<15+12=27>>27  So you need to buy 12 eggs + 27 eggs =<n> <<12+27=39>>39 Dozen eggs<n>So the final answer will be 39<n><n>Input: What is one more than 3 times a fourth of 7?<n>Output: So let’s look at the problem:<n><n>(3 x 4/4+1)<n><n>1 is 1 more than 3 times 4/4<n><n>So the final answer: 5<n><n>Input: What’s 230 – 4 times half of 80?<n>Output: So, 230-((4x1/2)+4)<n><n>230-(16+8)=230-24=206 <n><n>So, the answer is 206<n><n>Input: What do you get when you subtract 64 from ten more than 48?<n>Output: 47<n><n>Input: What's 610 – 6 times 32?<n>Output: So (610-6(32))<n><n>610 - 192=610 -192<n><n>6%10 = 11%10<n><n>So the answer is 458 <n><n>Input: Write a
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where does a person need to get when they have more kids? Choices:  A: compliments B: understand themselves C: life partner D: second chances E: larger house<n>Output:		The word is choice C: life partners.<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Riding bike through rough terrain can be dangerous, one could find themselves what? Choices:  A: pleasure B: accident C: get somewhere D: hurt E: falling down<n>Output:		B is right, you can fall<n>Biker wants to ride bike through rough terrain, but he is afraid that biker will be hurt because biker might fall down with bike. <n><n><n>Input: The teacher knows that 9 students are absent. If every third student is absent, how many students are absent?<n>Output: If every third student is absence, two students will be absent because 0/2 = <<0/2=0>>0 and 2/2 = <<2/2=1>>1 student per every third student.<n>Then two students are absent, the teacher wants to know 2 students from 9 students, 9-2 = <<9-2=7>>7 students need to be counted.<n>So the final answe is 7<n><n>### Solution:<n>Here is a simple tutorial on how to use the python interpreter with your shell. You can do this in windows as well by using CMD.<n><n>![image](https://user-guides.github.io/python-instructor/img/python-instruct-1.png)<n><n>When it asks for your answer enter your answer. <n><n>![image](./images/python-instruct/python-instruct1.gif)<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where does a spoon go on one side of a plate? Choices:  A: bowl of soup B: serving dish C: table setting D: placemat E: glass of iced tea<n>Output:		The spoon goes on the other side of the plate instead of in the bowl of soup because in the bowl of the soup, you just put soup in it<n>The spoon should always go on the plate, it doesn’t go into the bowl, you don’t put soup in the plate, and the soup isn’t on the plate<n>There is a dish, which is something that holds something else; the spoon can go in the dish but it won’t, because again you put something else in it, not soup<n>The tablecloth isn’t where we put the spoon<n>The placemat is not where we put our spoon. Also, when we eat we don’t put the spoon directly under our mouth, it’s between our food and mouth in our hand. So we don’t put a spoon directly on our platemat<n>All of the choices say ‘put it here’, we don’t put it in our iced tea, or set it on top of our iced tea<n>So the final answer for this question as shown in the example is A<n><n>Input: There are 3 people at a table, each with an even number of chairs. How many chairs are there at the table?<n>Output: From the beginning I thought there could be no odd number of chairs since 3 people each have an even number, hence there is a number of chairs = (number of people) / 2<n>So the number of people should be odd.<n>The chair is half of the person so the person should be odd so (1)+ (2)+ (3) = 6<n>Since 3 people are now at the table and that's how many people it takes to fill an odd number of chairs, there should be 7 chairs in total.<n>So the final outcome is A<n><n>Input : What is the largest number you can make with 2, 2, 3, 6, 6, 7, 18, and 28?<n>Output: There is a largest number that each of these can make so that is the greatest common factor<n>551 (2 x2 x14 x14) can be made with 2, 3 = 2 (7 x3 x14 x 14 x2)<n>221 (2 x2) or (28-2
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What does a virus primarily do to a person? Choices:  A: infect B: reproduce C: mutate D: eat food E: make computer malfunction<n>Output:		The right choice is C = mutation<n><n>Input:  A man has 100 apples in his orchard.  After some of the apples spoil, he has: A: 100 - 10 B:  10 - 5 C:  100 - 5 D:   5 - 10 E: 10 - 50<n>Output: The right answer for C = 100-5<n>The choices are:<n>A: 100 – 10 = <<100-10=90>>90<n>B:  10 – 5 = <<10-5=5>>5<n>E: 10 – 50 = <<10- 50=40>>4<n>Since C = 10/5, the final answer is 90-5<n><n>Input: Choices:  A. The cat is hungry. B. The cat is sleeping. C. The cat is in a box. D. The cat is asleep in a box. E. The cat is thinking about eating pizza. Answer:<n>Output: The right one is D = cat sleeping in a box<n>The choices are:  A: The cat is hungry because a cat doesn’t eat pizza<n>B: The cat is sleeping<n>C: The cat is in a cat<n>E: The cat is thinking about cat<n>D: The cat is asleep<n>So the final answer here is D<n><n>Input:  An elephant, a zebra, and a lion walk in to a bar, ______?<n>Output:  A: All of a sudden A zebra and lion start fighting. B: The Elephant goes "ROAR!!!<n>C: The bar goes out of business<n>D: Everything is quiet. E: Nothing happens<n>After running through your options, it is easy to determine that D = "Nothing happens"<n>since none of the other options apply in this situation<n><n>Input: What year was the 15th century in? Choices were  A:1900 B:1500 C:2010 D:2012 E:1700<n>Output: C = 2010<n>The choices are  A: 1900<n>B: 
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is a place that might not always have a queen? Choices:  A: bee hive B: england C: castle D: deck of cards E: chess game<n>Output:		England is an old place<n>It has only one queen.<n>So, the final answer is England<n><n>Input: At school, the students decide to go to a nearby pizza restaurant. They split the bill evenly. After counting, the restaurant says they were short. How much money does each student owe?<n>Output: The students go to a nearby pizzeria. They split the bill and counted in the end they were short 20%<n>Every student will owe $20<n>So, the final outcome is $20<n><n>Input: 84+10 = 94<n>94 + 13 = 107<n>107 + 5 = 112<n>112 + 2 = 114<n>114 + 8 = 122<n>122 + 4 = 126<n>126 + 2 = 98<n><n>Output: There are 8 correct answers<n>So, the final output is 98.<n><n>Input: A carnival sells 7 tickets as an entrance fee and 1 ticket for every ride. The carnival also sells a season pass for $50 per day. If there are 100 visitors to the carnival in a day and 20% of these visitors buy a day pass, how much money did the carnival earn that day?<n>Output: The carnival sells three ticket for entrance fee.<n>For every ride, the carnival also sell one ticket<n>There are 20% of visitor that only buy season pass<n>When buying a day pass, they need to pay $50 a day<n>And the carnival will make $10 revenue when buy entrance <n>By using those information with the ticket buying for the carnival,<n>We can find that the carnival make $93 per day<n>So, the final result is $93<n><n>Input: The shoe salesman wants you to buy shoes as a gift, so he asks you if you prefer black or brown shoes from the two boxes below. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. For 40 kg of wheat, 32% profit is $3.50 per animal, so 32%*40kg=13.60 per cow, so the same for sheep it's $13.60per sheep, so the total is 800kg*13.60=10920 dollars profit.<n>So the final <n><n>Input: You are traveling with 28 people and the bus fare is $24.50 per person. This process of adding the result to itself is repeated a number of times, say n times.  The value of the first n terms of the series is called a Fibonacci series.  Fibonacci series are characterized by the fact that the ratio of any two adjacent terms in the series is a mathematical constant called the golden ratio, whose value is approximately 1.6180.  One possible value of n, that gives 1
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What does someone want when having fun with their friends and trying to fit in? Choices:  A: being understood B: beer C: playing around D: hug E: visiting friends<n>Output:		A is the best answer because when you are drinking beer, you might forget what is happening.<n><n>Input:A boy has 57 stamps in his baseball card collection. He sells 17 at four for a dollar and then sells the rest at ten for a dollar. How much did he make?<n>Output:The boy started with 57 stamps. He needs 17 more to go with the 17 that he has sold.  So he needs 74 stamps in total.<n>He sells the 17 that are left for $60.<n>So we need to multiply 4 by 17 and add 28 to it which gives us $40.<n>So he sold 17 stamps and he sold 14 stamps at $2.<n>The boy has made $760 from 57 stamps, which is $16.78 a stamp.<n>Sometimes the best trick is to think about the answer, not the question. So when the first task says “he has 17 more stamps to get,” you think first about how many stamps he has.<n>If he had 56, he would have to get 17. If he had 74, then he gets 17 2X17 = 34 stamps. <n>And that’s how you can know that 74 stamps are needed <n><n>Input:The number 15 is the product of four factors. Which factors? Choices:  C: 0 and 15 B: 2 and  15 A: 6 and 15 D: 1 and 15, 3 and 4, 7 and 15 E: 1, (15/2), 3, 15<n><n>Output:The answer is C.<n>Factorials is a special name for numbers that have 1 repeated so many times.<n>It’s fun to work out the answer and get a bit of math tingle running through your brain.<n>Factorial is written as this: F(n) the base is n, and the power is n raised as power number, n^0! =1, n^1! =1,  n^2! =2, and so on.<n>To find how many ways to make 1
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:In the movie a fragile man is causing accidents, his hope is to find a person opposite of him who is what? Choices:  A: undestroyable B: unbreakable C: indestructible D: durable E: invisible<n>Output:		I think durable is correct because he wants to be destroyed because they are same in every way but durable is always the opposite.<n><n>Answer: In the movie a fragile Man is causing accidents,  his hope is to find someone opposite of him who is durable. durable is always the inverse to fragile. fragile is not the correct term but for simplicity it works.<n><n>Input:In this year’s annual math competition, there were 12 students from different schools competing. They were all grouped into 4 heats, in which each heat had 3 students. The first place finisher in each heat was determined by adding their scores. If the sum of scores is always below 12, then the person getting the top spot in each heat automatically wins the championship. Which students won the championship? Choices:  L: First place in the first heat.  F: First places in the second and third heats.  S: Second place in the second heat.  A: Third place in the first heat  M: The second and first place person from the first and second heats are the same person.  N: The first and second place person from the second and third heasts are the same person.<n>Output: The first place finisher adds their scores so that they are under 12. They should win the championship if it is below 12 or tie at 12.<n>Then each heat will choose the person or split the first place prize. Heat 1 has first place finisher in the first heat. Therefore, the top person in Heat 1 wins Heat 1 first place, the second place from heat 1 goes into heat 2, and the third place person goes into heat 2. This person from heat 2 who went into heat 2 becomes second place in that heat by default. At the end of heat 2, the top place person in heat 2, becomes the champ for heat 2. Heat 3 follows the same process and at the end of heat 3 the person who becomes top place in heat 3 becomes the champion for heat 3.<n><n>The person who wins all 3 heats becomes the championship. At the end there are 2 people, both of whom can get championships. <n><n>The remaining 2 champs go into Heat 4. They are the first and second place people. The first place person from
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:It was a vast complex, the launch pad was just one part of what? Choices:  A: movie B: cape kennedy C: space center D: military installation E: spaceship centre<n>Output:		Cape Kennedy is just one part of NASA.<n><n>Input: What comes next in the series?<n>- 1 2 3 4<n>- 1 5 4 3<n>- 2 4 3 5<n>Choice:  A: 1 2 2 2<n>B: 1 3 1 4<n>C: 1 2<n>D: 1 21 2<n>Output: The pattern is 1 2 4 8, so 1 2 6 12 should be the next number in the series.<n><n>Input: A person who makes things or invents things<n>Output: The person who invents things is called an innovator.<n><n>Input: An object designed to solve a particular problem<n>Output: The object designed to solve a problem is called a tool.<n><n>Input: Things are not what they seem<n>Output: The phrase "Things are not what they seem" means that something is deceiving or misleading.<n><n>Input: There is only a finite amount of each thing in this world. Nothing is infinite.<n>Output:  We say "There is only a finite amount" to say that there is only a specific number or amount of something you can have, not infinite.<n><n>Input: Two coins will always weigh the same amount<n>Output: We say, "Two coins weigh the same amount" to explain that two coins cannot vary in weight because of how they are made.<n><n>Input: To be honest<n>Output: To be honest just means that you are telling true things.<n><n>Input: True or false: To be honest<n>Answer: True or false:<n>Output: To be fair means that you are being honest, even if the truth is difficult or a little ugly.<n><n>Input: Good manners are a sign of good character. They also mean you know what is appropriate in different situations and not to do unacceptable things.<n>Output: The word manners means actions or behavior in a polite way, especially in public. Manners, then, are when people behave politely or respectfully. In addition, good manners are a sign that people are kind, thoughtful and can act respectfully. Good manners also mean that people can behave rightly in certain situations, such as a dinner party. It also means that people don't do what is called "not acceptable" things.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:He wore the wrong shoes while walking all day, now he has what on his heels and toes? Choices:  A: exercise B: moving forward C: feet D: blisters E: locomotion<n>Output:		The word "locomotion" means that the person had to find something to make them move forward or they were at the stopping point. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. If the train has a 70% chance of stopping at the waterfront and a 30% chance of stopping the park, what is the probability of stopping at the water?<n>Output: Flip a coin to see heads the train stops at the park, tails the train stops at the train station. So 70% probability of stops on the park so it will come up with 7 tails out of 10. Now subtract that from 10 that is 7-10=2. So it has 2 60% chances. In total the answer is 2/10.<n>So the final anser is A<n><n>Input:The city has 46 parks. 60% are near the water, and 40% are near the train station. 4% of the parks near the water has a large play set. Choices:  A: driveway B: the event C: scrap heap D: parking garage E: repair shop<n>Output:		The man still had to walk… after commuting so he still had to walk TO the parking garage.The man still had to walk FROM the parking garage and back AGAIN to the garage for a total of (3 times) (2 for going in and 1 for returning).The garage is a parking garage not a repair shop.<n>Now lets calculate how many ways there are to get back home from a parking garage in 3 steps.<n>4(10+9+8) or 324<n>4(9+8+7) or 322<n>4(8+7+6) or 242<n>4(7+6+5) or 122<n>4(6+5+4) or 62<n>4(5+4+3) or 32<n>4(4+3+2) or 12<n>4(3+2+1) or 6<n>146212344<n>This is the answer choice (D) parking garage.<n><n>Input:The group has bought a house and they need to buy furniture for the house. They put $400 for furniture. If they need 9 beds for the house, how much should they spend for each bed?<n>Output: First we must learn how many beds each person needs. This can be calculated by dividing $400 by 9, $400 ÷ 9 = $44.44.  So each person needs 9 beds each.  If 9 people live in the house, that gives each person 1 bed.<n>Next, we can determine the price of a bed. We can use the formula (price/shares of a bed) x (number of people)<n>$400 / 9 = $4,44 for a bed.<n>Now, we must multiply the number of beds by the price to get the total cost.<n>9x$400 = $3600<n>So the final answer should be 3600<n><n>Input: In a carpool, five people take turns driving. As for lottery, this option is not useful.<n>And movies are meant to be watched in the cinema. You think they'd like meat, but you want to see what their favorite kind is. You can find out by surveying them in one of the following ways. Which way would be more efficient:<n><n>1) surveying them one at a time, getting each response in alphabetical order.<n><n>a) Survey 1: Meat preference: Beef or Chicken or Pork<n>b) Survey 2: Meat preference:<n>c) Survey 3: Meat preference: Meat or More Vegetarian<n><n>2) surveying them in groups of 2 or 3, getting the responses according to the alphabetic order of the group.<n><n>3) surveying them in a circular order, one following another.<n><n>Output: 1<n><n>Input: Flying through the air feels great. Here, our hero and one of his friends take turns jumping from one moving vehicle to another. Each moving vehicle is on a track and it moves forward with a constant speed. If they take turns jumping from the trampoline onto vehicles, the trampoline and vehicles are going at the same speed, their distance from the trampoline does not change. So, they decide not to jump from the trampoline anymore. When you go faster, a distance between consecutive jumps gets bigger. When you slow down to a stop, a distance between consecutive rides on the same vehicle gets bigger as well. On the trampoline, our hero tries to maximize the distance between his rides on the trampoline. They have 1 trampoline, 3 vehicles, and it costs $100 to jump between vehicles. Also, it costs $10 to go from one vehicle to another
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The detective had to analyse all the clues, every little thing at the scene he had to what? Choices:  A: look at B: write down C: learn new D: think about E: discovery of new<n>Output:		All the clues, every small thing and every tiny clue from the scene, the detective has to  take a look at and write down for the analysis of the case. The solution is D.<n><n>Input:You have $2.12 in change. You want to make 3 quarters from it. How far can you get, if each quarter costs.89?<n>Output: You take.89 -.12 and then multiply by 3; (0,89 -.11) * 3 = $(<<0.89-0.11*3=0.6>>6)<n>So you can make 6 quarters from your original 2.12<n><n>The 11th question has the same pattern as the 10th and the 12th question has the same answer.<n><n>Input: You and your mom have the same hair colour but it is not the same shade between each other. Your mom's hair is one colour darker than yours: What is the colour of your mom's hair if your hair colour is red? The answer is C.<n><n>Input: Your mom and her friend are both the same age. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. The final answer is 1,353<n><n>Input: A number is in the form of “45X” where X=Y+Z. The digits 4 and 5 cannot be next to each other. There is a two-digit number hidden in the equation. What is that number?<n>Output: The equation is “45X = 45X”. This can be solved by solving for the variable in 45X and then using that variable in “X = Y+Z”. The equation becomes “45X = X+Z”. Since the solution for the variable “X” is “X = Y+ Z”, then X+ Z = <<X+Z>> “45 X + 45 Z”, which gives us “90”. Hence, the two-digit number is 90<n><n>Input: A fruit stand has 8 large pears and 1 large apple. Each pear costs $5.50 and each apple costs $3.50. Choices:  A: to be heard B: receive gifts C: understand themselves D: good things in life E: acknowledgment<n>Output:		A) In a session of counseling, the counselor is supposed to listen to the client without giving input or suggestions. If they give their input, that might not be good counseling and the client may not want to go back to see them again.<n>B) Clients won’t necessarily get gifts in counseling, but there are sometimes free brochures or other information that is given to the client.<n><n>C) Clients usually have questions that are answered by the counselor. Clients aren't supposed to get too attached to the answers and then start to question who they are, so they should understand their strengths and weaknesses. Then they can figure out what they should do.<n><n>D) In general, there are good things in life and bad things. There are some people who have more bad things in their life than good things. Counseling helps those people deal with and understand their bad times more easily.<n><n>E) Acknowledgement that they're in a bad place is an important part of counseling. Counseling isn't the only thing, but it's just one tool to give you the help you need. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What might someone do who is having fun? Choices:  A: being happy B: glee C: smoke D: stress relief E: may laugh<n>Output:		Choices in order were: A, D, the other answers<n><n>Input: How many inches are in 10 and 3 1/4 ft<n>Output: ten and three and one fourth feet = <<10 and 3 and 1/4=33 and 3/4>>33 and 3 / 4<n>33 and 33 / 4 = 8 and 11/16 inches (16 + 11 = <<16 + 16 = 32>>32<n> <n>Input: The total of all the 1st-3rd grade classroom petitions was 41,220 signatures, and one of the petitioners’ names was listed 92 times. How many names were on the petition?<n>Output: A total of 41220 + 1 x 0.92 = <<41220+1*0.92=37,870>>37870 petition names<n>So the final answer in 37870<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The old barn was beyond repair, they had to destroy it before they could what a new one? Choices:  A: make B: raise C: entice D: build E: fix<n>Output:		The letter A means make and the other letters B,C,D,E means raise, entice, build and fix. So the final answer is make<n><n>Input: A dog named Riley can count as high as 10. Each time he counts, he becomes more excited. So the final answer will be D doesn’t make a difference<n><n>Input: The children like strawberries and are excited about picking them tomorrow. How many more plants do they need this year?<n>Output: The children have 8 plants that produced 225 strawberries in 2015 and 175 stawberries in 2KM. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. A "square" of wood or grass is 16 feet.<n>If you paid 25 dollars for the fence in square feet you need to multiply the number of "squares" by 25:<n>square fence/25 = <<square fence/24.9>>7 (rounding)<n>7 square fence = <<
