The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Choices:  A: friendship B: aggression C: defeat D: winning or losing E: sweat<n>Output:		They enjoyed competing against one another because it was a good way for them to work on their <<friendship>>friendship, win or lose, or<<defeat>>defeat.<n>So the final question should be "What is a good way for them?", and the answer would be "<<friendship, win or loose or defeat>>"<n><n>Input: Choices: A: He was going to be the best kid at school B: He was the best player at basketball  C: He was the best student in class D: He was the best at eating burgers E: He will be the best at eating cake<n>Output: <<A: He was going to best at school B: he was the best at basketball>>He was the best at school and <<B: He was the best to basket ball>> at basketball<n>So the final answer will be "He will be the best at school and at basketball".<n><n>Input: Choice: A: It was so big, and it was falling off the table. B: It was green and yellow, and it had a blue button on it. C: It was shiny, and it didn't have a scratch on it. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What type of water transportation is human powered? Choices:  A: turn away B: let down C: have to sleep D: run E: row boat<n>Output:		Water transportation that uses muscle power to  propel itself is human powered.<n>C: have to sleep does not use muscle power to propel, B: let down uses a motor, A: turn away uses a wheel, D: run uses a sail, and E: row uses muscles to push the oars.<n>So the final answear is C: human powered.<n><n>Input: A store sells toys for all age groups, including kids and teens. How much of the store's revenue comes from selling toys to kids, and how much comes from selling to teens?<n>Output: A toy store sells toys to 2 categories of customers: Kids and Teens. We know the  percentage of revenue earned from sales to kids, since that is the question.  So we'll compare revenue from kids to revenue from teens.<n><n>If kids = x/100 + y/100, where:<n>The revenue from kids = x <n>The revenue from teens = y <n>The answer is x/100 = y/100. <n><n>Since the percentage of revenue from the kids is the same percentage of the overall revenue, we will put kids and teens together for revenue in the numerator:<n><n>Revenue from both kids and teens = x/101/100 + x/100/(100-101)/100 = <<x/101/4*101+(x/100)/4*99/4>><n><n>Rewrite 101/(101-100) as << (1+11/101)/11>>.  The 101 disappears after you multiply 100 by 99.  So the equation is x/99.99 + x/(1-101)/99.99.  Multiply both the numerator and the denominator by 999/999 to cancel out 2 x 99s.<n><n>Multiply both the numeratior and the denominator by the reciprocal of 999 to get 1 x 999 = <<1/99
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: hunt B: pay merchants with money C: mail orders D: spend money E: demand satisfaction<n>Output:		You're on the right track! In a store, customers do all of these things (A, B, C, D, & E)!<n><n>Output: You should add in the word "checkout" to your list of things that customers do in a store!<n><n>Input: In the 75th minute, the referee blows his whistle. The score at this minute is 488 - 483.  How much did the game score increase by  in the 75th minutes?<n>Output: In the 74th minute, the score was 488 -483 = <<488-483=5>> 5 and in the 75 minute, the score was (488 -453+1 = <<488 -40=44>>44. 5 + 44 = 49. Since in the 75 minutes the score increased by 5, so it increased by 5.178 in the 75 seconds<n><n>Input: This year the car factory produced 500,000 cars and in the next year the number of cars produced is double that of the number of cars produced this year. How many cars are produced?<n>Output: This year the car manufacturers produced 500000 x 2 = <<50000= 10000>>10000 cars. In the next year, this year's number of cars doubled, which is 1000 × 2 = <<1000 x 5.108>>20 times more.<n>So, the overall answer is 100,007.108

Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n>Output:		<<C - D>>C<n><n>Input:There are two people in an elevator. It has buttons for 1, 2, and -. They will press a button for every 5 minutes they wait. There will only ever be two people in the elevator. The maximum time the people can spend in the elevator is 10 minutes. Answer the following multiple choice question: What is the greatest total of the last number pressed by each person? A) 7 B) 8 C) 9 D) 10 E) 15<n>Output: The two people will wait for 1, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 minutes.  Let’s assume people press 1 at 1 minute, 5 at 5 minutes, 10 at 10 minutes, and so on.  The answer is D.  <n>The maximum total is 7 + 15 = <<7+15=22>>22.  The final answer is 22.<n><n>Input:There's a big game with a ball.  It is passed 25 times in each direction around the field before each quarter starts.  How many passes are there in total?<n>Output: The total passes are 25 passes in the first quarter + 25 passes in second quarter + 25 in the third quarter = 0 30 passes.<n><n>Input:Which of the following gives the best estimation? A) 5 miles B) 5 km C) 5 furlongs D) 5 mi E) 50 miles<n>Output: <<B >>B 5 km is about 3.1 miles, so it's very close.<n>```<n><n>The code for the questions 0-10 can be found in [here](https://github.com/gabeschwartz/instructioncode).<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is a useful activity when experiencing loneliness? Choices:  A: meet people B: meet friend C: make people laugh D: socialize E: liquor<n>Output:		It is best to meet people, either friends or acquaintances to talk to and interact with to get out of loneliness.<n><n>Input: There are seven people in a photo together. How many different ways are there for them to arrange themselves in order left to right given that they cannot overlap?<n>Output: Use the combination method.<n><n>Input: How many books are there in the whole world? Assume the number of words in all books in the world is 1 trillion. Choices:  A. 5 B. 10 C. 15 D. 25 E. 30<n>Output: There are 1 trillion words in the world, 79 languages with 280 million speakers, 1.8 billion books in the world. There are about 2-5 books for every person.<n>5 is the closest answer.<n><n>Input: What is the ratio of the first three numbers in the list if the ratios of the first to the second, second to the third, and third to fourth are 1:3, 2:4, and 1:4, respectively? Choices:  a. 1:1 b. 1:2 c. 3:2 d. 2:1 e. 3:1<n>Output: The 1st: 1 : <<1/1=0>>0 2nd: 2 : <<2/1=2>>2 3rd: 3 : <<3/1=3>>3 4th = ratio/1 : <<ratio/1=3/1>>3/1<n>ratio of the first 3 is 1:3 : <<1:3=1/(3/1)=1/3>>1/3<n>Since there are 3 numbers in the first three, the 1st = 3*1 = 3.<n>and 3*3 = 9. So the 2nd = 9.<n>The 3rd = 3/9 = 1.<n><n>Input: If 1099 is divided by 2, the remainder is 3. If 1341 is divided by 2 the remainder is 9. The ratio of 1099 divided by 1341 was 99:183. Find the value of (3).<n>Output: (3
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where might someone find old clothing? Choices:  A: trunk B: drawer C: suitcase D: book shelf E: washing machine<n>Output:		A: trunk<n>B: drawer<n>C: suitcase<n>D: book shelf<n>E: washing machine<n>So the final answer was 2-E because the washing machine is not an option in the question stem.<n><n>Input: Which of the following represents the fewest number of eggs? Choices: A: 1 B: 0 C: 7 D: 5<n>Output: A: 1<n>B: 0<n>C: 7<n>D: 5<n>So the final answer A: 1 because it represents the fewest number<n><n>Input: There is a 5 in 25 cents. How much change would you get from a 6 in 25 cen ts?<n>Output: Since we already know a 5 in 35 cents makes 5 cents, we just have to substitute a 6 in 35 cen ts in place of the 5 in 30 cents and we know what answer we need<n>So the final answer: 8<n><n>Input: Lola is building a block tower. She needs 20 blocks for the top row and 35 blocks for the second row. After setting her blocks up, she finds that the second row contains 2 odd blocks. How many blocks are in her tower?<n>Output: We start by solving for b which is 2x + 2y = 79, which b = ((2x + 2 * 2y) / 79) = <<2x+2*(2y)/79=b>>b. So b is 22, and x is not a whole number therefore b-2 is going to be 0 or 1 and b is 22 therefore there are 22 blocks in the first row.<n>On the second row we have to find all possible number of blocks, so there is 35-2 which is 33, there are 33 blocks, then subtract 1(surely we can't have an odd number of blocks). So one block was 34, meaning the second row is 33 blocks.<n>Thus, we have 22 blocks in first row, and 33 blocks in the second row, which is 55 blocks in the tower.<n>So the final answers are 22, 33, and 55
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Sam didn't like the people he met while traveling.  What might he do to get away from them? Choices:  A: come home B: airplane C: learn from each other D: go out E: make art<n>Output:		He can airplane because "come home" is not an option<n>And "learn from each", "go out" and "make art" are possible<n>So the final answer must be "airplane"<n><n>Input: Two people stand on parallel lines 11 feet apart. How many feet apart are they from the same exact center?<n>Output:  To solve this, we'll use the PEMDAS method.<n>PEMDAS is an acronym for Parentheses, Exponents, Multiplication, Division, Addition, Subtraction.<n>In this problem we have parentheses, so we subtract first.<n>Their feet apart from the same exact center = 0 feet<n>Since there is no integer answer for 2 x 11, we need to use the remainder method.  Divide the number by  2:<n>0 div by 2 = 0 remainder<n>Subtract the remainder by the original number:<n>0 - 0 = 0<n>Final answer:  0 feet apart from each other<n><n>Input: If 2 students were asked to find the perimeter of a picture, they would use a ruler. If the painting was 30” (3’ 0”) wide, and 40” (4’ 0”) tall, how much money would they spend on paint?<n>Output: If the painting is 30" wide and 40" high, then the area would be 30” x 40” = <<30*40=120>>120<n>The area of the painting / height of the painting = 120 / 40 = <<120/40=3>>3<n>So the final answer would be 3<n><n>Input: A grocery store has 10 packages of 8 cookies. The cost of each package is $1.69. A customer bought 1 package. If the total of the order was $19.75, how many packages of cookies did he buy?<n>Output: Let x = the total bill 19.75 = x- 19<n>18 < x ≤ 20<n>Subtract 19 from both sides to get: -19 = 1<n>So the customer bought 1 packs of cookie <n>(1 x 8 cookies)<n><n>Answer:

Choices:  A: switzerland B: pennsylvania C: picture D: asia E: austria<n>Output:		In the answer choices, Switzerland (A) and Austria (E) contain mountain because Europe is a mountain. Pennsylania (B) and Asia (D) don't have mountains because they are in Africa and Africa is a continent, not a mountain.<n>So we can eliminate (B) and (D)<n>There are 4 letters and 3 options for the mountain state. That gives us 3 possibilities for our answer.<n>In (A), "switzerland" contains the letter "i" as the second letter in the phrase, which means (A) is out.<n>In (E), "austria" contains the first two letters with "a" and "u" so we can eliminate (E)<n>Therefore (B) is the answer<n><n>Input: In a 5-letter word, a and i come before c and u. H, a, t, ch, and o are in the middle. Choose the word? Choices: a: handhicap b: hangicap c: hangcap d: hanicap e: all<n>Output: In a 5 letter word, a and i both come before c and u, which means h, a, t, c, u, i and o are all in the middle.<n>Handicap has the word hic in it, and hanicap starts with han.<n>Since there's only one other answer, handicap is the answer<n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If I need deodorant, where do I go to but some? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: medicine chest C: armpits D: grocery store E: kitchen<n>Output:		Let's take the letter A and let's say I went to the medicine cabinet and then, I got the deodorant. The other choices: B, C, D and E are irrelevant, right? So I just need to find out where it says " I took the deodorant from", which is choice A<n><n>Input: The two trains took off 5 minutes apart. After 30 minutes, Tom’s train was 85 miles ahead of Jim’s train. How long was the train ride if it took Tom 125 minutes to cover 85 miles?<n>Output: Let' s start 1st with the question Tom's train was 80 miles ahead of Jim's after 30 mins. Let' s call distance 80. So we are now given distance A and distance B, where distance A< distance B, right?<n>distance A / distance B = <<A/B=0.1>>0.1 miles per minute difference.<n>So we take it as 125 / 0.1 = <<125/0.1=1250>>1250 minutes for Tom.<n>Distance A + distance B x ((distance A / distance B) x minutes) = <<A+B*(0.1*(1250))>>2500. This equals to 80 * 2500 = 200000.<n>So the answer is 2000.<n><n>Input:  I can’t go to the party, because  I need to  go to the library and return a book.  I have five library books to return. Each time I return a library book, my friend tells me I owe him a dollar. If I have one dollar left over after returning the books, how many library books did I need to return?<n>Output: I have 5 books to return. Each book is 1 dollar so I owe him 5 times 1 = <<5*1=5>>5 dollars.<n><n>Let's say I return the 5th book, so I'll be $1 short.<n>$1 - $5 = <<1-5=4>>4 dollars.<n>So the number of library books I have to return = 4.<n>We've done 3 math problem questions and that's pretty good!!!
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Who sits at the center table at a receeption? He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Three quarters of what are covered by the ocean? Choices:  A: waterfalls B: underwater C: beach D: surface of earth E: river<n>Output:		 waterfalls - 3/4 -1/4 = <<wqatersfalls-3/4=-1/4>>1/4 - 1/4 = 1/2<n>So the final answaer is D<n><n>Input: The product of two numbers is 38 and the sum of the numbers is 30. What are the numbers? Choices: A: the numbers are 7 and 33 B: 3 and 19 C: 17 and 21 D: 15 and 24 E: 11 and 24<n>Output: The product of 2 numbers is 38. The sum is 30. Solve for a and b: 38 = 30 a. So a=3 - 4 = 1. 1/a is b. So b= 1<n>So the final answeris A and B<n><n>Input: Lily can jump to a height of 10 feet (3m). Her friend Lilllian is only 7 feet tall (2.1m). Lillian can jump two times as high as Lily. Can Lily reach Lillian's height of 7 feet?<n>Output: Both Lily and Lillian can jump 10 feet. 2*10 = 20 feet<n>Since Lily is shorter, she's only a portion of 20 feet tall, so she's 7/20=1/3 height. Now she can only jump 1/3 of the 20 feet, which is 8 feet (2.5 meters). So no, she cannot jump to Lillian's heighfht of 7 feet since she only jumps 8 feet.<n>So the final anweser is D <n><n>Input: The cost of a flight from Dallas to Seattle is $400. The cost of a flight to Los Angeles from Dallas is $60. A flight from Los Angeles to Seattle costs $210. The round-trip flight costs a total of $1112 to go from Dallas, Texas to Los Angeles, California and back on two separate flights. How much was the total cost for each individual person on the trip?<n>Output: The sum of the two round trips is $1112 = 2 * $400 +
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:When people want to watch a new move, the often go see it at the? Choices:  A: town B: conference C: bathroom D: theater E: train station<n>Output:		In the movie, they are at the movie theater, but there is a bathroom in the theater. So the final answer is B and D because bathroom and theater were the correct answers.<n><n><n><n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would you buy a ticket to sit in a room with a lot of chairs facing the same direction? Choices:  A: conference B: theater C: building D: floor E: church<n>Output:		This is a problem: <<A:B:C:D:E:>><n>I'll choose E: church, so it should be in D:floor<n>This is in E: church building <<D:floor>> floor<n>Since you would buy a ticket to sit anywhere on the floor, you would just buy any ticket on the floor<n>I would buy ticket D so you'd buy any ticket on the D floor.<n>So the final choice, if you are trying to buy a ticket to a room with lot of chairs, would be the D floor<n><n>Input:The students are making a cake. The recipe calls for 12 eggs. There are 25 students in the class. Each student in the class gets 12 eggs. How many eggs are left for the teacher?<n>Output: Since they are in a recipe, lets find the ingredients first:<n>Start by dividing the recipe ingredients (eggs) to the total students<n>12 ÷ <<25>> = <<12/25=0>>0 eggs<n>12 - 0 = <<12-0=12>>1 eggs<n><n>Then, add 1 egg to the left over eggs:<n>12 - 1 = <<12-1=11>>11 eggs left for teacher<n>So the final answer, if you are trying get a teacher egg, would be the 11th one<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. The subject in this sentence can refer to A, B, C, D, or E, but it is specifically a reference to kids. We also know that treats are only bought over the counter so to get more words, we could eliminate A, B, D and E. We’re left with two possible choices: C and E. We want to find words in the first set of input that can go to the same output. There are several words in the statement that can go to either B or A, like “you”, “I” and “one”.<n>There aren’t a lot of words in this that are only in A or B though.<n>We can get rid of C because it is not in B or A.<n>We can also get rid of D “I’m thinking” because it could be referring to me or the general audience. We can also get rid of E because it refers back too B which we know is the same as A.<n>That leaves us with only <<You, I and A>>.  There are more words that can go to B than A though so B is definitely one of the choices. The easiest answer would be A and B because they both fit, but I have to get to at least one correct answer. So the final answer has to be AB<n><n>Instruction:For questions 17 and 18, choose the best answer<n><n>Input: Cho

If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where could you find a laundry room that is only used by staff? Choices:  A: house B: hotel C: green house D: college E: dorm<n>Output:		A laundry room in a college would only be used by staff.<n><n>Input:A man is moving across the country and he plans on taking his bicycle.  If he takes his bike, how many miles can he bike each day? Choices: 16 miles 20 miles 25 miles 15 miles<n>Output: He can ride his bike 20 miles, because 20 x 5 = <<20*5=100>>100 miles per day.<n><n>Input:How do you know the temperature is 90? Choices:   It has a temperature sensor  There is a thermometer  It has a color sensor If the temperature is not 90, how many degrees from 90 is it? Choices:  It is 89 It is 1 It is 110 It is 0 <n>Output: It is 90 since one 90 is 90 -1 = <<90-1=89>>89.<n><n>Input:  What did Mrs. Hewson eat for breakfast? Choices:   Toast and jam Bread with butter and cheese  A sandwich Pancakes <n>Output: Mrs. Hewson had a sandwich for breakfast.<n><n>Input: How many cats are in Mr. Chang’s house? If Ben and Alice invited the same amount of kids to their birthday party and both parties were the same night
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The artist didn't use many colors to capture the view, he was famous for his very plain what? Choices:  A: landscape B: east side C: countryside D: middle america E: georgia<n>Output:		The artist is famous for his very plain landscape because his landscape is very plain.<n>So the final anwser is B<n><n>Input: What is 2/2 - 3/3?  Choice: A: 1/2 B: 1 C: 1/<n>Output: When you subtract fraction 3/3 from 2/2, you are actually subtracting (half - three thirds).<n>The result will be (1/2) - (3/3) = (1/2) + (3/3). The 1/2 and 3/3 cancel each other out.<n>Therefore, (1/2) and (3/3) cancel each other out leaving you with one half.<n>So the final answe is A<n><n>Input:There is a line of people waiting in line to use a public payphone. Each person in the line wants to send a 10 cent phone call. The total number of phone calls for the line is one hundred. If each person calls for 2 minutes, how much time does it take for all 100 phone calls to be completed? Choices: A: 1:23 B: 0 C: 1:59 D: 1:40 E: 2:23<n>Output:Since the duration for 100 calls is 2 minutes, therefore the time required for 1 phone call is (2/100) = <<2/100=1/50>>1/50.<n>The total time required = (1/50)*100 = <<1/50*100=1.96>>1.96<n>So the Final answer is D<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Wanting to avoid the cabbage spoiling, where did he put it? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. String value<n><n>For Part I:<n><n>- - - -  Incorrect<n><n>For Part II:<n><n>- ------  Correct<n><n><n><n>## Explanation:<n><n>**Explanation**: First we had to answer the first question. Part II is where we will have to compare two things and determine which value was higher than the second<n><n>We first set up the if statement<n><n>`if(Hurley_Age == Richard_Age + 20)`<n><n>this is setting the condition for which value is higher. If Hurley_Age is 20 higher than Richard's age + 20, then Hurley_Age will be returned.<n><n>Then we determine the higher value by subtracting the smaller from the greater.<n><n>We use this code to set up the if condition.<n><n>`if(19 > [age_of_first_person] - 20)`<n>`or`<n>`if(21 <= [age_of_second_person] - 40)`<n><n>If the first person is 15 years old, then the second person is:<n><n>`21 - 15 = 6`<n><n>The lesser number will be returned: _6_<n>`40 - 6 = 34`<n><n>In order to determine what the combined ages of the two people will be 40 years from then we subtract the younger one from the old one.<n><n>I use 54 since that is the age of a 14 year old after 40 years. <n>Since Hurley is 19, Hurley will be (20 + 19) years old after 40 more years.<n><n>Richard is ((40 + 34) - 19 + (19 - 14) = <<54-14=40>> 40 years older than Hurley. This means

They are not twins. She was born in 1991 and has 3 children, a daughter and two sons. One brother drives their car. She lives with her family, but doesn’t live in a house. She and her boys watch their father fish when they aren’t at a baseball game. How many brothers does she have? <n>Output: Anita has not twin brothers because she has 2 brothers. So Anita lives with her family but lives in an apartment as she doesn’t live in house. One brother drives their family car and her boys go fishing with their father when the are not attending a baseball game.<n>So Anita has only 3 answers for her family, a daughter and two boys<n>1. She has 1 daughter and 1 brother<n>2. Two brothers and a daughter<n>3. Three boys<n>So after eliminating any that are not the correct number her brother and boys are one of the two brothers or daughters that Anita has. After elimination we can only conclude that she has 3 boys because she has 1 brother and 2 boys which is the only answer that has 2 brothers<n><n>Input: Who was the next president of the United States? Choices: 	A: John Quincy Adams B: Andrew Jackson C: Zachary Taylor D: Martin Van Buren E: William Henry Harrison<n>Output: The correct answer is E because he was the shortest serving United States president<n><n>Input: There is a square with a hole in the middle. The area of the square with the hole in it is equal to the area 5 times the area of the square that does not have a hole in it. How much bigger is the area of the square with a hole in it compared to the area of the square without a hole?<n>Output: Area of the Square with no hole: a * s = area of the square with hole: 2a * 2s 5a * s= area no hole: 4a * s 2a * s = area no hole: 20 a 10<n>Area no hole = 20 sq. units = 20<n>2a * s = 20 5a * s = area of with hole: 20 4a * s = 4
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where is disease often spread but shouldn't be? Choices:  A: ghost town B: third world country C: human body D: rug E: hospital<n>Output:		A ghost town is an abandoned town.<n>So the Final answer is A<n><n>Input: The school will buy 3 laptops for their student computer lab.  The school is trying to spend as little money as possible.  They set a budget for $1200.  The school can buy 1 laptop for $1000, or buy laptops for an additional $50 each.  How many laptops does the school need to buy to stay under the budget?<n>Output: Lets assume all 3 laptops cost $50 each.<n>Then we have to find the sum of all 3 laptpices<n><n>We have 1+2+3 = 6<n>So the next price would be $55<n><n>And we have 6+2+7 = 15<n>So the next price is $95<n>Then we have 5+6+8 = 19<n>So the final price is $106.00<n><n>Because the next price goes over the budget<n><n>Since we made the final price is more then budget  $1200, we have to buy laptops like this:<n>6 5 4 3 2 1<n>So the final answer will be 4<n><n>Input: What would happen if all 60 people in a stadium jumped up and down?<n>Output: 60(60)(60) or 60^3<n>The stadium has 60^3 people, so the answer would be 60^3.<n><n>Input: A bag contains 3 green jelly beans, 2 blue, 2 red, 1 yellow, and 1 black. You remove one jelly bean at random from the bag. After this removal, what is the probability that it is black?<n>Output: Take the answer to a problem from before, and answer this question.<n>3 green, 2 blue, red, yellow, and black<n><n>A green is 1/3 of the total<n>3 + 2 + 1 + 1 = 7<n>This is the final probability of 1/7, or just in general a black since there is only one in the list.<n>So that gives you the possibility of the final probability for an answer of 0.1 which is 100%<n><n>### Input
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where is a snake likely to reside? Choices:  A: tropics B: nightmare C: wyoming D: bushes E: feild<n>Output:		 A: tropic B: B  C: tropic and feild D: B and nightmare E: <n>B and nightmare are correct<n><n>Input: What is another word for ‘hopeless’? Choices: A: hopeful B: wishful C: good D: fine E: okay F: poor<n>Output:  A and C: Hopeful and Fine<n>B and E: Wishful and okay<n>D and F: Okay and poor<n>So the answer is C and F.<n><n>Input: There are 365 days in a year, 52 weeks in a year, 12 months in a year and 52 weeks in 52 weeks, how many days are there in a year? Choices: A)1826 B)1825 C)1897 D)1896 E)1826<n>Output: 1825<n>12 months x 52 weeks=604 weeks<n>52 weeks in one year=604<n>Therefore 604 = 1826/365<n><n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where are small grapes used? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:A person notices popcorn, cotton candy on the grass, where is he likely? Choices:  A: soccer game B: fairgrounds C: movie theatre D: countryside E: state park<n>Output:		A man would not be at the movies because the grass is on the ground, not the floor.  A man would not be in a state park because the grass is on top of the ground, not the ground below.  A man would be at a soccer game because the corn is on top of the grass.  Also, the cotton candy is on top, not below, so a man would be at a fairgrounds.  A man would also not be at a countryside because the grass is in a field, not on the ground.<n><n><n><n>

Choices:  A: conquer opponent B: fight enemy C: join army D: kill E: terrible<n>Output:		In war, the primary method is combat and the goal is to eliminate the opponent.<n>Options<n><p>A:<span style='color: red;'>Conquer</span>  opponent</br><n><p>B:<span style='background-color: white;'>Fight</span><span style='color: blue'> enemy</span> </br><n><p><span style='background- color: yellow;'>Join</span> <span style='font-size: 20px;font-style: italcic'>army</span></br><n><p>'<span style='background: yellow;'>Kill</span>'<span style='color: pink;'>enemies</span><span style= 'color: maroon'><n>The correct answer is '<span style='background color: yellow;font-size: 10px;'><b>D</b></span> <span style= 'color:#FF8A59');background: yellow;'>Eliminate</span>'</p><n><div class='btn-box'><div class='btn-option'><n><p><input type='radio' name='options' value='A'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i class='fa fa-check-square-o'></i> <span>A</span></div><n><div class = 'btn-text'></div><n><p><i class='fa fa2 fa-check-square'></i> Conquer</p><n></div><!-- end of second option --><n><div class=' btn-box'><div ><i class='fa1 fa fa-check-square fa1'></i> <p><input type='radi'><n><input type='radio' checked >&nbsp;&nbsp;&middot; <span><span>B</span></p></div><n><span style ='margin-left: 2px;color: blue'>Fight</span><n><n><!-- end of third option --><n><div style = 'color: green;margin-left: 15px'>Join</span><span style ='margin: -10px;font--: small'>A&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><span style ='color: maroon'>Ry</span><span style="font
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would you read a passage but not write it? Choices:  A: diary B: city C: bible D: graffiti E: labyrinth<n>Output:		You need to write out the passage so it is read, so the correct answer is Labyrinth.<n>If you are reading a paragraph and writing it out, it would be written in the same place as it is read. Graffiti is written on public buildings or on walls.<n>You would need to write out the paragraphs to read it.<n><n>Input:If you have a chocolate bar and it has four squares. If you have two chocolates, how many squares do you have?<n>Output: If the bar has four squares, then each square represents a chocolate.<n>If you have 2 chocolate bars, it represents 2 x 4 squares = 8 squares.<n>So the final chocolate bars would have 8 squares.<n><n>Input: How many bags of potato chips are being sold on Saturday and how many bags are being sold on Sunday?  If Sunday's total was 186, Saturday was 382, and Saturday's total was 200, how much is the profit?<n>Output: If Saturday = 382 and Sunday = 186 = TOTAL for two days = 568<n>If the total for Monday is 580 (568+12), then profit = 580 - 568 = <<580-568=12>>1.2<n>So the answer is 12.<n><n>Input: If 32 x 11 = 342, how many x 11 =?<n>Output: 32 x 342 = 3852<n><n>Input: What is 102 x 102?<n>Output: 102 x ten is?<n>Output: 1 x?<n>Output: ten squared<n>So the final answer should be 100<n><n>Input:If 2 + 2 + 2 = 10, how many + 2’s are in 490?<n>Output: The answer to 2 + 2 is 4 because 10/2 = 5<n>So the answer to 490 should be 490.<n><n>Input:You have a bag of 33 gems.  It breaks and you now have 13 gems.  13 of what is
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What do all humans have on the side of their head? Tickets cost $9, so someone paid $10 to buy a dozen tickets.<n>(a) How many tickets did the person buy?<n>(b) What was the price per ticket of that person's tickets?<n>Output: The customer paid $10 to get a dozen tickets, and there were 12 people standing in line for tickets.<n>Then, the answer to part (a) is 12 people, and the answer to part (b) is $1.67 (12 tickets / $9 total price).<n>(a) 12 (b) 1.67<n>So the final answer for 12 and 1.67 is given as $1.67<n><n>Input: There are 45 students in the history class. Each student takes a 3-page final exam. The final exam total page count is 45 (3 * 15). If the exam has 400 questions and costs $1 per question, what is the total cost of the history class final exam?<n>Output: There are 400 questions on a $1 exam 400 * 1 = $400  The total costs $400 So the final answer for $(400 * 50)/100 = $200<n><n>Input: Derek is building a table and needs 3 feet of lumber, 4 feet of lumber and 2 feet of lumber. He'll need one more piece of lumber to make a 6' table. Choose the best answer:<n>(A) 6<n>(B) 9<n>(C) 13<n>(D) 19<n>(E) None of these<n>Output: You have three 4 feet, three 3 feet, and two 2 feet.<n>The question wants the number of feet he needs for the final 6-foot piece, and you know the math from the other parts.<n>So the final 6-feet piece needs one 5<n>So the final answer choice is E, one of 6<n><n>Input: There
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The doctor recommended washing hands, what was being promoted? Choices:  A: cold hands B: wet floor C: health D: become wet E: dry skin<n>Output:		A: Cold hands-Was recommended, but the doctor didn’t say wet<n>Hands, so the answer is A.<n><n>Input: If you are playing tennis, how would you score a fault? Choices: 000 000 111 111 222 222 333 333 444 444 555 555 666 666 777 777<n>Output:The only valid score of 777 has only been used in an episode of SpongeBob Squarepants.<n><n>Input: A team of 9 kids from two schools are going to camp with their leaders. Four of the kids are going to be from each school. If each leader has 12 campers (9 kids from each school plus themselves) in their group, how many leaders must there be to send camp?<n>Output: If each leader has 6 campers (9 kiddss +1) in their group, there must be 3 leaders.<n><n>Input: One of the best ways to lose weight is by running 5 miles a day, everyday. You walk to work at 3 miles an hour and you walk home from work 11 miles per day. In how many days will it take you to go from 122 lb to 119 lb?<n>Output: First take the day from when you decide to start walking for weight loss.<n>Let's say your starting weight is 200 lbs and you walk 11 miles everyday the first month. We will subtract 200 by 3 and divide by 11 miles to get the answer.<n><n>200 - 3 = <<200-3=197>>197<n>197 ÷ 11 = <<197/11=17>>17 days<n>So the final answer in 17 days.<n><n>Input: Choose one answer and then enter the remaining answers.
