### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. If you order a large and an extra large,  you will receive  a $2 discount.  The price of a small pizza is $9. How much will the order cost if the order is for “four hungry people”?<n>Output: If she ordered a large (with a $2 discount) + extra large (with + extra large discount), then she will receive 2 $2 discounts and one large with a + extra large with a $2 discount = <<2 x 2> = $4>>4 discounts<n>She receives 4 discounts off of the $10 price of the large and extra large, so she will receive 4 x $10 = <<$10 x 4 = $40>>40 price of large and extra large.<n>Since there are “four hungry people”, she will receive $40/4 prices = <<$40/4=10>>15 discount from the small.<n>So the final discount from the small is $40-$15=$<<40 - 15 = 25>>25<n>So the final answer will be $15<n><n>Input: Mr. Smith is a professional photographer in a beautiful port city. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where was the apple tree said to contain something forbidden? Choices:  A: north carolina B: washington state C: nil D: great outdoors E: garden of eden<n>Output:		The story was made about apple trees so the answer must be apple trees <n>Four options have nothing to do with apple trees, so they can be discarded.<n>A, B, and D could potentially be apple trees so they can't be completely disregarded.<n>The garden of eden is where the story happened so the garden of eden must be the answer.<n>So the final choice is (D).<n><n>Input: The story of the forbidden fruit came from what apple tree? Choices:  *A: northern carolina *B: washington state *C: nil *D: great outdoors *E: the garden of eden<n><n>Output: The story of the fruit, however, began in the garden of eden.<n>The story of the fruit came from the garden of eden, so (D) is the answer<n><n>Input: Which number goes with these clues? Choices:<n>1. has three ones<n>2. is more than zero but less than 2<n>3. is more than zero and less than a billion<n>4. is more than zero<n>5. less than is less than 100<n><n>Output: (A) 1000<n>First 2 numbers are 1 and 0 therefore number 2 is 2<n>Next four are: 1, 0, 1, 0 thus number 3 is 2<n>Last number that isn't less than 10, is number 5<n>Therefore the final answer is 5<n><n>Input: Which is the least common multiple of the two numbers? 16 36<n>Output: Lcm of two numbers is the least common multiple which is a number in which they are common<n>Therefore the final choice is (B).<n><n>Input: <n>In a restaurant, the tip and gratuity are 18% and 15% of the food cost, respectively. If a family of four goes to the restaurant, how much does the tip account for if food costs $36?<n><n>Output: Tip and gratuity are the same thing(same % of total bill), so $18/5 = $<<18/5=3>>3 is the answer<n>So the final answer given by the user should be $3.<n><n>Input: What is the next triangle number? Choices:  a. 5 b.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Billy's mother tripped over a stuffed animal.  She yelled at him not to leave his things where? Choices:  A: toy store B: hall C: bathroom D: amusement park E: fairgrounds<n>Output:		A, B, C, D are not places to leave your stuff, so the final answer must be E (Fairgrounds)<n><n>Input: Jackie bought 3 notebooks to store information. She had two extra notebooks at the end of the week. How many notebooks did Jackie buy?<n>Output: If Jackie had two extra notebook at the end of the day, then there was a total of 3+2 = <<3+2=5>>5 notebooks. She bought 5 notebooks.<n>So the final  answer is 5<n><n>Input: Which state won the most 2018 Mud Bowl games? Choices: A: New Mexico B: New Jersey C: Oregon D: Washington E: West Virginia<n>Output: A (New Mexico) won the most games, as they won 4 games. West Virginia won the most because they only won 3 games. E won less than any other because they only won 1 game. So the final answer is A (New Mexico)<n><n>Input: An eyeglass store has 5 different designs for frames, each for $85. One customer buys 2 pairs of frames and a case for $62 ($5 off). Another customer buys 4 pairs of frames and a pair of cases for $178. If the total cost of frames and cases is $270, how much does each frame cost for the first customer?<n>Output: So the total cost of frames for the first customer is 62+2(2*85)= <<62+2*85=183>>183 frames.<n>Now the total cost of frames with the second customer is 130 frames + 64(11 frames) = 165+20+270= 270/165 = <<270/156=23/8>>23/8 frames, where 8 is divided by all of the frames,<n>and 23/8 is the answer for the first customer.<n>So the  final answer is 23/8.<n><n>Input: Bob is putting on a carnival.  Every year the carnival charges $1 per person. He is trying to get to 1000 people. If 1024 people came this year,
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What are adult people usually expected to do? Choices:  A: shake hands B: own property C: pay bills D: smoke E: talk to each other<n>Output:		A: shake hands,  B: own property,  C: pay bills,  D: smoke and E: talk to each each<n><n><n><n># In the given code, we will be given the three operations.<n><n># In this code, we start by looping to input the values(the difference between the numbers and their sum).<n><n># Then we check all the values and keep track of which values sum to 10.<n><n># Also, we check if the third value equals the sum of the other two values.<n><n># If the value is not 10, the values are not divisible by 3. <n><n># If the third value equals the number and their sum is even, then that whole number is divisible by 3, otherwise it is not.<n><n># If all three values are even,it means that all the values have a remainder of 0, the answer is no.<n><n><n>x = int(input('Enter A - 20, B - 10, C - A+B '))<n>print(f'{A},{B},{C})\n'<n><n>ans = 0<n>while ans == 0 :<n>        a,b,c = list(map(int, input().split(' ')))<n>        if c % b == 0 and c % a == 0 :<n>                ans = 1<n>        else :<n>                ans = "NO"<n><n>print(f'The number is {b + a + c}, {ans}')<n>                   <n>              <n>

If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What do you feel from playing football? Choices:  A: exhilaration B: pain C: death D: getting hurt E: get hurt<n>Output:		A: Exhilaration and pain B: Exhilaration, death, pain and getting hurt C: Death and getting hurt D: Pain and death E: Getting hurt and pain<n>So the final answer can be any and it's C because choices C, D are covered by the options A, B<n><n>Input: How tall are you? B: 8'3" C: 7'1"<n>Output: 7'1 < 8'3<n>7'2 < 8'3 8'3 > 7'2<n>Because 3 is bigger than 2, C is the answer because it is smaller than B, but still above all options.<n>Note: B and C are the same because we can round the whole thing into the closest option<n><n>Input: The number of eggs Harper has is 32. She has some left to use for cake. If it takes 4 eggs for one cake, how much cake can she make?<n>Output: 32-4 = 28<n>32/4 = 8 (rounded to the nearest whole number)<n>8x2 = 16<n>16x2 = 32<n>32-4 = (16-4)<n>Output: A is Harper, and she can't feel anything with her<n>B is death, and Harper can feel death because death is bigger than Harper<n>C is pain, and Harper can't feel pain because the value of pain is less than the value of her.<n>D is getting hurt, and Harper can get hurt because she can't die and she's not a robot, and can get hurt.<n>E is getting hurt, and she isn't getting hurt because she is Harper. (Harper = feeling = the answer)<n><n>Input: There are 83 students enrolled in a school. The number of boys is always one less than that of girls. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Who does the government help with schools? Choices:  A: school children B: parents C: get money D: require to pay taxes E: take money<n>Output:		This question is a special type of multiple choice called a binary choice type (Choices: True vs False).<n>Since school children can mean schools at large in which case we could say government helps all of school children.<n>Schools can mean school children and their parents.<n>Other could refer to the government requiring parents to pay and not helping children.<n>Therefore, the answer is "B"<n><n>Input:  This multiple choice question asks for the solution to 15% of 78 is how do we know that it is 78?<n>Output: If percent is being asked for, the answer is to multiply by 100 and then move the decimal two places to the right.<n>So 15% of a number means multiply the number by 15, move the decimal 2 places to the right, and convert the number into a percentage:<n>15% of 55 = 15 x 55 / 100 = 15 x.55 / 1<n>15 x.5 =.75<n>75 / 2 = 37.5<n>37.5% of 54<n><n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. So how many people can come to the party?<n>Output: The only possibilities are 2 guys, 5 guys or 5 girls. Hence the answer has an odd number of girls, so there can only be an odd number of girls<n>If there were 2 guys, than the total number of people coming has to be even, as if it was not even, then there would be at least 2 guys and 2 girls. But that is not true. So we can't have 2 guys.<n>So let's start with 5 guys, but then if there were 5 girls, than the total number would be odd and we'd end up with 4 girls and 5 guys, which is still even. Hence there can't be 5 girls either.<n>So a party, we can have only a 1-1 ratio of males to females, i.e. males=odd number of girls. So we'll just assume that males = odd number of girls. For convenience, let odd number of girls = <<1stguy>>2.<n>If there were 1stguy + 2ndguy - girl1 then the total number of people comes to be even, which is a contradiction, which is true, so it can't happen.<n>Hence if 1stguy is odd then 2ndguy = <<2ndguy>>3 is also odd (because males=odd number of girl1). He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is someone likely to feel after receiving a gift that is not common? Choices:  A: special B: personal C: offended D: unique E: rare<n>Output:		The word unique means it's singular and you can't apply it to more than one person.. A unique gift is a singular gift.. So the answer is (A) special<n><n>Input:How is it possible to have a friend who is both a boy and a girl? Choices:  a) You consider the friend to be neither a boy or a girl. b) Your friend has two sets of chromosomes. c) You know your friend is only a boy some of the time. d) Your friend is part of a set of identical twins. e) You are very good friends with the person who is your friend's twin brother.<n>Output: Option(E). The only logical answer because in this case you are considering another person is your friend. Because for option choice 'D' to be considered true, there should be a set of identical twin brothers, and you are not friends with two friends.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:When playing baseball they keep track of mistakes, this stat is called what? Choices:  A: happiness B: sore muscles C: injury D: perfection E: errors<n>Output:		Choices:  A-B-C-E, but B is better than A-C-E. So the answer must be: B=sore muscles<n><n>Input: A math test is given in which the answers are to be 1 digit and the highest correct answer is 36. The student scores 9, 7, 10, 8, 2, 4, 2, 8, and 8. How many correct points does student score?<n>Output: A-B-C, but B is better. So the answer is B=20<n><n>Input: You have five coins. In how many ways can you place two coins into two places to make one penny?<n>Output: This problem has many possible ways to combine the coins to make one penny. Choices : A: 0 B: 3 C: 12 D: 64 E: 20<n><n>A is a false.<n>C is a better combination than A, so it is better to pick C.<n><n>Input: If you get paid $15 every time you finish a task, how much do you get paid for completing the 15th job (assume a round number that is not a multiple of 15)?<n>Output: $225 because 15 * 15/2 = <<15*15/2=75>>75<n><n>Input: A friend borrowed a car from you. He also borrowed a dollar from you. He gives it back to you. After that, how much you borrow from you?<n>Output: Choice A: 1. Choice B: 2. Choice C: 3. <n>C is the answer because you borrow from you only when you owe you.<n><n>Input: A student is writing four times. For the first two times, the teacher allows them to use all the pages she needs. But when she makes mistakes on the last two, the student cuts off the last half. How many pages did she actually use?<n>Output: Choices : A: <<3>>3 B: <<2>>2, C: <<4>>4, D: <<5>>5<n><n>C is the answer. In the first two times she writes, she use at least <<3>>3 pages. In the last two she cut to the last half
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Who designs a building? Choices:  A: builders B: driver C: architect D: fall down E: tradesmen<n>Output:		 First find who builds the building. You have to find the number of choices that A can choose. There are <<A=3>>3 options to choose, B, D, E<n>So you can select A or B or D and C or E. You then calculate the two possibilities. You only need one option from each possibility since they must pick A or B. Here the two options for A are B = 1 (there are only two total options to pick from) and for B, there are the same total two options: A = 2<n>This gives you the answer: ((B+D) + (B+E)) x (A x C) = (<<3+2>>6 + (<<3+2 >>6)) x (<<2>>1 + <<1>>0) = ((<<3>>6) + (<<3>>6)) x (<<?>>1 + <<?>>0) which simplifies to 16 x 1 = 16.<n>So the final answers is 16<n><n>Input: If a pig can eat 3 acorns in 8 minutes, then how many acorns could a pig eat in 35 minutes?<n>Output: pig can eat 1 acorn in 8 minutes. So, 35 / 8 = <<35/8=4>>4 quarters. If a quarter is an acorn, a pig then can eat 4 quarters = <<1>>acorn=<<4>>4 acorns in 35 minutes.

The angle of the launch is the same, so in this case the angle of launch just means that its velocity. So the arc length is d = r(theta) = x(theta) = vsin(theta) = <<vsin(theta)=120(21)>>=663 m<n>So the final answer should be 663
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If he puts 7 sheep in one pen and 5 goats in another, then he has 21 sheep left. How many sheep are in each pen?Choices: A pen is full of sheep, B pen is full of goats, C neither pen, D both pens, E both pens and neither, F they are not full<n>Output: To solve this problem, consider the farmer's situation. He has 29 sheep and 5 goats. He takes away the 5 goats (29-5 = 24), and has 29 sheep left over = <<29-5=24>>24. He cannot cut the wider woods because he thinks this will ruin the wood. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would you find a metal rod in most people's preferred method of transportation? Choices:  A: airplane B: construction site C: shops D: engine E: broken bone<n>Output:		A is Airplane<n><n>Input:If a car has 24 gears, two wheels, and drives a total of 4.08 miles per gallon, what is the gear ratio of the car?<n><n>Output: Since it drives 51 miles in 4 gallons then: 51 = 4 * <<4*51=200>>4 200 / 51 = <<200/51=>4>>4<n>So the final answer would be 4<n><n>Input: A dog is in a box. The box's length is 9 inches and its width is 6 inches. The dog's length is 30 inches. How long is the dog's tail?<n><n>Output: Length of dog - length of box = 30 - (9 * 6) = <<30-60=30>>30<n><n>Tail Width = (dog's length - box's length) / Tail Width = (30 - (9*6)) / <<Tail Length/60-30>>Tail Length/30<n><n>Since the box's width is 6 inches and the dog's length is (30-9=) 21 > 6,<n>So the dog's length/6 = 21 / 6 = 3.5<n>3.5/21 =<<3.5/20>>1/6.5<n>So that would be the final answer.<n><n>Input: You have a large bag that contains a total weight of 9kg and you want to divide it into two weights of 4kg and 5kg. How many items do you need in a bag to accomplish this?<n><n>Output: To do this, I simply added 9kg to every item, and then subtracted 4kg from the second bag, and came up with the correct answer 10.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question by filling in the 3-digit integer that matches the output in the description.<n><n>You are playing in the sandbox, which contains 6 buckets. Each bucket contains the same quantity of sand. The total amount of sand is 400 pounds. How much sand is in each bucket?<n>Output: 30 pounds<n>You should input: 3 for each bucket
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:It was breakfast time.  Brad ordered eggs, toast, and something to drink. What might he drink? Choices:  A: coffee B: throw up C: food D: getting drunk E: wine<n>Output:		What could he drink when it's breakfast? Sam and Tom were paid $11, while Dave was paid $8.  What are the three times each person was paid?<n>Start with 18 + 5 = 5 + 18 = <<5+18=23>>23 minutes<n>After that: 23-3 = <<23-3=20>>20<n>Since it took 5 minutes to clean the kitchen first, Tom was paid $5.<n>Tom and Dave were paid $18 + $5 = $/*18 + 5=*23 dollars */23 dollars total.<n>So the final answers has to be 20 or 23<n><n>Input: Your house has a 18x20 living room. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: full stomach B: getting full C: gaining weight D: sick E: satisfaction<n>Output:		A: full stomach and B: getting full<n>Since I ate all the dishes from the tasting menu this year, I felt full both times, at the conclusion of the meal and after a few bites.<n><n>Input: Your best friend lives in your building and is also a neighbor. What should you do?<n>Output:Your best friend lives in your  building and is also a neighbour.<n>You should choose the option ''Choose your best friend first''.<n>I do not know the name of one of the residents of building.<n>When I arrive at the party, I will ask my friend to help me play a trick on the party's host.<n>Letter C : You should choose this option if you know the name of one guest in the party and his/her name is the same as your friend's name.<n>Letter D : You should choose this opiton if  you do not know the name or your friend but you know any of the other information about your friend or the host.<n><n>Answer: D:I did not know the name of my friend but I know where to find him:he is a neighbor in my building.<n><n>Input:In the restaurant, there was a tasting menu. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The accelerator was controller via a hand throttle, and the foot pedals controlled the steering in the small what? Choices:  A: car B: fuel system C: accelerate D: boat E: airplane<n>Output:		A - car  B - fuel system  C - accelerate  D - boat  E - airplane<n><n>Input: A: Dad<n>B: Mom<n>C: Brother<n>D: sister<n>E: daughter<n>F: youngest child<n>G: oldest child<n>H: Grandma<n>I: Grandpa<n>J: Uncle<n>K: Aunt<n>The family was seated at a table. How many people were seated at the table?<n>Output: Start with the list: D: Sister H: Grandma I: Grandpa K: Aunt<n>Then the rest of the table: A: Dad B: Mom C: Brother D: Sister E: daughter F: youngest child G: oldest child<n><n>The family was seating at a table with 12 people.<n>So the final question is<n><n>Input: If 3 apples cost $0.75, what is the cost of 8 apples?<n>Input: 4 men and women are in a room. The men outnumber the women by 3.  How many women are in the room?<n>Input: If 15 pennies are worth $1.50, what is the value of 35 pennies?<n>Input: 5 men and women are in the room. The men out number the woman by 5.  How many women in the room?<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Too many people want exotic snakes.  The demand is driving what to carry them? Choices:  A: ditch B: shop C: north america D: pet shops E: outdoors<n>Output:		Too many people want exotics snakes, the demand is driving up the cost.<n>Choices are A: ditch, B: shop, C: north america, D: pet shops, E: outdoors.<n>We can answer the question by looking at each category and picking the one that sounds the most logical to fit with the theme of the question.  A: ditch- this doesn't really make sense related to snakes or demand<n>B: shop- If people are demanding snakes, then they would go to a snake shop<n>C: north america- If we are talking about snakes, then that doesn't seem to have anything to do with the question or the demand of snakes.<n>D: pet shops- pet shops sell snakes, so this choice seems like the logical fit to what the question was saying. So the final answer is D: pet shops<n><n>Input: A man orders a hot dog from a hot dog stand. He gives the cashier 60 dimes in change and asks for the change in dollars. The cashier says the total change is $9. If the tip is $2, how many dimes does the man have left?<n>Output: The man orders a hot dog, and gives the cashier a total amount of 60 dimes. He asks for change and the cashier tells him that the change will be $2 dollars, so the change = <<change=$2>>2 dollars<n>The man's total will be 60 dimes + 2 dollars = 62 dimes.<n>After taking the tip, the change in dollars will be 62 dimes / 10 dimes in one dollar coin = <<62/10=6.2>>6.2 dimes.<n>So the final change he receives is 6.2 dimes<n><n>Input: A mother needs to make her living family of 4 lunches for her kids for the week. Choices:  A: neighborhood B: subdivision C: city D: suburbs E: street<n>Output:		The city is enclosed by other places, so C is out.<n>If he wanted a house in the neighborhood that was gated off, that would mean searching the subdivisions which are inside of the neighborhood.<n>Now he has 2 choices remaining, either the suburbs which also are inside of the city, or the city.<n>To choose between the 2 places in the city, he can use the suburb as a guideline that separates the 2 areas inside the city.<n>Since he has never looked at any houses in the city, he would probably start from the suburbs and then slowly progress to the city as he narrows his choices.<n>In the end, he would buy a house in the city<n>So the final answer choice D: City is the best answer<n><n>Input: A boy named Ben and his brother, Tom decide to save their allowance to buy a toy. Ben saves 40% from each dollar he earns and Tom saves 15% from each dollar they earn. In three weeks, they saved $12 and $138 dollars respectively. How many dollars did each boys earn each week?<n>Output: Ben saves 40 / 100 = <<40/100=0.4>>0.4 of each dollar he earn, which means (12 / 0.4) x 40 = <<12/0.4=30>>30 dollars/week<n>Tom saves 15 / 100= <<15/100=1.5 >> 1.5 * 40 = <<40*1.5=60>>60 dollars/week<n>So the final answer  is 30+60= <<30+60 =90>>90 dollars/week<n><n>Input: A company is going to hold a meeting and they are going to charge a cost of $42 per person to attend. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What might be the result of a season of successful skiing? Choices:  A: finish line B: broken bones C: broken legs D: chapped lips E: healthy body<n>Output:		A: finish line<n>B: broken bones<n>C: broken legs<n>D: chapped lips<n>E: healthy body<n>Chose A<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The person gave a good hands on what to show how to do the work? Choices:  A: demonstration B: garage C: building D: barn E: synagogue<n>Output:		The person does not give a good hands on.<n>The answers start with a capital letter, so it is not a good hands on and does not satisfy the requirements, so the answer is E<n><n>Input: The person gave a good hands-on how to make an automobile? Choices: A: demonstration B> garage C: building <D: barn E: <synagogue<n>Output:The person gave a bad hands on, the answer is I.<n><n>Input:The boy has 10 blue coins, 8 green coins, and 6 yellow/coins. If he had 4 red coins and 2 white coins, how many coins does he have?<n>Output:The boy has 4 red and 2 white.<n>First, total how many coins he has so far = <<10+8+6+4+2>>16<n>He has 16 coins so far, then he has 4 and 2 = <<16+4+2(4+2)>>12 left to add to the 16.<n>Now he has 16 total = <<(16+4+4+2(2+4)>>26<n>The final answer is 26<n><n>Input:When multiplying two numbers, what are the factors of 18×9÷2 when doing long division? Choices:  I. 1 × 9, 9 × 2, 9 / 1, 2  <B: 2 × 9, 2 × 9 / 1 >C: 1 × 9 < D: Both 4 and 9 × 2 >E. 9× 2<n>Output: The person is doing short division.<n><n>Input: When doubling a number, what are two methods for calculating the answer? Choices:A: double + single B: multiply C: multiply by 2 D: subtract half a number E: subtract half a negative number<n>Output: The person did this correctly as there are multiple ways and this is the answer.<n><n>Input: For a square of area 129.5cm^2, What are two possible lengths of its sides to satisfy the requirements? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Jim enjoyed killing people, but he did it too often and the cops found out.  What might the cops do to him? Choices:  A: going to jail B: going to prison C: beat him up D: get arrested E: die<n>Output:		I choose the last one because I think I have the best shot out of the options, so this is the answer.<n><n><n>## Next challenge:[[/challenges/next/]]<n>### This challenge is sponsored by:[[/challengesponsor/]]

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. She asks for 20 cents for each gumball, and also asks for $8 of her own money.  Her father tells her she can't have $8, but she can have as many as she wants of the gumballs. How many gumballs can she have?<n>Output: First, she asks for 200 cents worth of gumballs. Her dad tells her she can' take the $8 but can have whatever gumballs she wants.<n>The way the $8 was posed was as a variable which is $8.  If something is divided between two variables, it goes into the fraction, so $8 divided by $x = <<>>1. The gumballs the girl will then have left is $1, the remainder of $8 by itself.  That is why she can have however many gumballs as she wants<n>So the final answer was 80 gumballs
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If someone is aloof and self-important, what is their experience when meeting people? Choices:  A: stress B: nervousness C: smile D: being bored E: making new friends<n>Output:		If someone is aloof, they likely want to be self-important.  Self-important means they think they are better than everyone else, so why would it not be stressful.<n>So the final conclusion that A is stress <n><n>Input: A man has two dogs at home. One is three years older than the other. If he buys a third dog, he will have ten more dogs than the sum of his remaining dogs. How many dogs does he have altogether?<n>Output: Let’s figure this out in our heads.<n>If he has only 3 dogs, and then gets a 4th, he has ten total dogs.<n>I.e.  3 + 4 - 4 = 10<n>If he gets a 5th dog, and already has 4, and has a 3rd dog, then 1+3+5-5 = 3<n>I.e. He has 5 + 3 + 5 - 5 = 7<n>So as long as he gets an ODD number above Three, he would have 10 + (3 to the ODD number), and he’d have 6<n>So when he buys Ten more dogs, he’ll have a total of 16!<n>So the final conclusion he has 16<n><n>Input: Aaron’s birthday is the 8th day after his friend Chris’ birthday. If Chris’ birthday is on a Wednesday, then what day is Aaron’s birthdate?<n>Output: Aaron’s brother is one year younger than Aaron. Aaron’s birth date is on the 8th day before his brother. His friend Chris’s birthday is on a different day, so this makes Aaron’s birth 8 + 1 = <<8+1=9>>9 days before his brother’s birthday. His brother’s birthday is 12 days before Chris’ birthday, so his birthday is 9 + 12 + 1 = <<9+12+1=13>>13 days before Wednesday. So his birthday is on Saturday.<n><n>Input: There is a game where players start by choosing either red or blue, and then take turns guessing a secret number that the other person is thinking of. The player is asked “Is it higher or lower?” each time they guess. If the
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would a person keep a book while it's being read? Choices:  A: closet B: library of congress C: classroom D: in bed E: desk<n>Output:		If a person chose A, closet, then their next choice is classroom. If classroom, the first choice is E. So, E,E,C,A,B,D<n>So the answer is EADCBA<n><n>Input: You have a 4-sided rectangle shaped puzzle. The puzzle is already solved. On the top-left corner there is an "O" and on the bottom-right there is an "X". Every corner, edge and side of the puzzle is decorated to reflect the color on each side of the puzzle. If the puzzle on the left looks like the one on the right, what is the color of the middle of the middle puzzle-piece? <n>Output: Since the answer is O or X, then every single puzzle piece will be O or X.<n>And since the middle puzzle piece is the middle of the middle, then it is only two choices. <n>OO and XX<n>So the answer is OO<n><n>Input: If you can buy 6 different fruit juices for a discounted price of \$4.00, and \$1 is \$1.35, how much does one gallon of any juice cost?<n>Output: I need 10 more juices to reach $100, so<n>(4)(1.35) + (5.7(6)) = 14.95<n>So the final answer should be 14.97<n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. Choices:  A: violence B: falling down C: vomiting D: vomiting E: lower standards<n>Output:		People who get angry after getting drunk have lowered their standards, by lowering their inhibitions and their resistance to peer pressure. They are more likely to hurt themselves or others in a state of impaired judgment.<n><n>Input: Two friends, Ben and Dave, made the same amount of profit on items they bought in the same shopping trip. During the shopping trip, Ben made half the purchases, while Dave made the other half of the purchases. Ben ended up paying $15 for each of the items. Meanwhile, Dave didn't pay as much. How many times did they repeat each other’s purchases?<n>Output: Ben and Dave bought the same items in the same trip.<n>Ben bought half of the items and Dave also bought the same half of the items.<n>Every other item Dave bought, Ben paid $15, and every item that Ben bought, Dave also paid $15, since Ben bought Dave's half the items.<n>Dave didn't pay as high on every item he paid for, since Ben paid more for the half the items Dave bought.<n>So Ben and Dave bought the items twice, once where Ben bought Dave's items and Dave in turn bought the same items back from Ben.<n>Dave paid for twice the items Ben already paid for, since Ben did not pay as much on every item Dave bought.<n>So the final result is 2<n><n>Input: How well do you know your family? Choices: A: Really well, B: a little C: okay D: not at all E: never<n>Output: You don't really know your family very well.<n><n>Input: A farmers co-op gave out 120 quarts of milk to a grocery store. As time went on, the milk was given out at a rate of 10 quarts per minute. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. Choices:  A: dog's mouth B: floor C: garage D: trouble E: nature<n>Output:		Cats get into trouble when they rip things apart. So the final answer is D<n><n>Input: The teacher has 3 different tests and each student in her class has 15 different problems to answer in the first test, 12 in the second test, and 16 in the third test. How many students does the teacher have in her class?<n>Output: There are 3 tests, and there are 3 different types of test, for example 15, 12, and 16.<n>The teacher has 15 problems per test plus 12 and 16. That comes to a total of 43 problems for her tests.<n>If every student has to answer all the problems, then the teacher has 43 problems ÷ 43 = <<43/43=1>>1problem for each student.<n>So 3 tests x 1 problem/student = <<3*1=3>>3 students.<n>The final answer is 3<n><n>Input: Jake has to make an origami crane but he has only 120 squares of paper and it takes 18 of them to make one bird. How many cranes can he make?<n>Output: Jake needs to get 18 colors of paper to make an origami bird. He can get the 18 colors of the paper that take 18 ÷ 12 squares to get one color of paper.<n>So 18 ÷ (6*18) = <<18/6=6>>6 different colors he can make from his 60 squares of paper.<n>To get 60 sheets of a different color of paper, it will take 60 ÷ 6 = <<60/6=10>>1 origami bird.<n>So the final ansuer is 10<n>
