If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:You can hear testimony of how spirituality changes lives when you do what? Choices:  A: go to church B: appear in court C: watch soap operas D: paying attention E: go into court<n>Output:		The choices are church, court, and soaps.<n>However, it is not a verb but a noun.<n>There is no choice D where it means 'going to court'<n>Only choice A would be correct if it says 'how spirituality changes lives when YOU go to church'.<n>So the final answer should be A<n><n>Input: Invest $1,000 per year for 12 years at an annual interest rate of 2.5%. What will you have invested at the end?<n>Output: Invest $1000 per year x 12 years (assuming 12 years) = <<1000x12=12000>>12,000<n>Then 2.5% (interest rate) will be applied 2.5% x 12 years = <<2.5%x12=30>>30 to that investment, which would be an additional $300<n>So total that account will be $13000 and the investment amount is $12000<n>So the final answer will be $1200 + $300 = $<<12,00+300=15000>>15,000<n><n>Input: What number x, where x = 3x + 5, results in x = 2?<n>Output: x = 3x (solve for x in first step) + 5 = 2 (solve for x, substitute 3x into the equation)<n>Substituted 2 for x, this gives a=6 <n>If x=3x+5<n>then x-3x=5<n>and x=8<n>So the final answer would be 8<n><n>Solution: <n>Let x = 3x+5 <n>then x-3*x = 5<n>or  simply it is x= 8<n><n>Input: What two-digit number has more than one digit different from the tens digit?<n>Output: If all the digits are same, then their will be only one 2-digit number (for example, 11 only). But if there are two different digits, then there will be a number that contains different digits (123).<n>So the final answer 123<n><n>Input: John is making a box
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where would you put a folding chair if you do not plan to use it and you do not have any large doors in your house? Choices:  A: roof B: school C: beach D: closet E: garage<n>Output:		Since a folding chair does not require a large door or space in your house since it folds up, the best place to put it would not be a roof, school, or beach, since those spaces are large.  Instead you would put it in a closet, because there is lots of smaller spaces there.<n>So the final choice is E: garage.<n><n>Input: Choice:  A: Pizza B: Ice cream C: Coffee D: Burger E: Donuts  Which would you eat most often?<n>Output: If i were to choose I don't think i could choose one because i love all of that food. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is committing perjury likely to lead to? Choices:  A: shame B: arrest C: embarrassment D: go to jail E: tension<n>Output:		You committed perjury(lied as a witness in a court), which is probably considered committing a crime and if your judge believes your crime,you’re going to go to jail. So answer should be D.<n><n>Input: What is the perimeter of a rectangle with an area of 105 and a width of 25? Choices: 1: 85 2: 80 3: 60 4: 49 5: 35 6: 80<n>Output: According to question, width and height of the rectangle are as follows. 58(W) and 690(H)<n>Perimeter = 2*(L+W)<n>=  2*(1+25),<n>= 49+58<n>=  107m<n>So answer should be 1<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What might a kid do with his friend before going to play? Choices:  A: laugh B: sit C: being entertained D: math E: meet<n>Output:		Before they go, they will laugh because they are having fun  and it can calm them down before entering play<n>So the final answer A: laugh<n><n>Input: What can you make with these items: a dollar, a calculator, and 14?<n>Output: You can make 14 dimes because 1 dollar = 100 cents, and 14 is 10 less than 24, so you can divide 24 by 10 to get 24.4<n>So the final answer = 14 dimes<n><n>Input: How many quarters will fit in a dollar bill?<n>Output: There are 4 quarters in a dollar and a dollar has 7 coins, so there are 3 dollars<n>3 dollars = 3 x 4 = <<3 x 4=12>>1 dollars, and<n>12 quarters fit on a dollar bill (from all the 3 dollars)<n>This means that there is a total of 4 quarters per dollar, so 4 quarters x 12 dollars = <<4 quarters=12 dollars>>12 quarters should fit in a dollar<n>So the final answer 12<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the follow multiple choice question.<n>Input:What do you use dimes for? Choices:  a: eating b: paying c: entertainment d: math problems<n>Output:: For dimes, we can use them for entertainment. Dimes can be used to make toys. So the final answer d: entertainment<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Sky diving scared him, once they jumped out of the plane he began losing consciousness while what? Choices:  A: injury B: death C: playing uno D: coma E: falling down<n>Output:		Sky diving scared him once they jumped out and began losing consciousness.<n>While he is losing consciousness, his organs in an unbalanced state for a short period of time.<n>The correct answer is death<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question that is given at the beginning of the problem, then answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>Input:A certain group has exactly X members.  You want to be sure that the group picks a president.  In order to accomplish your goal, you need a special process.    Choose the one process for choosing the President that you must have to guarantee that a group of X members always selects one person to function as its president.<n>Output: To guarantee that a group of  X members always selects one president, two elections are necessary.  Let's call the first election, the nomination election.  Each member of the group nominates one individual, X or less.  (A member of the group may nominate him/herself.)    In the second election, known as the election to elect the president, each member of the group votes for the person he/she nominated as president. If one member nominated him/herself, that person can also be selected president if a majority of the membership of the group votes for him/her.<n><n>A majority of members must vote for a person proposed for president in the nomination election for that person to be elected. A simple majority is sufficient in the nomination election.<n>(The definition of a majority is the plurality of votes: the person getting the most votes. In an election between three people, the one getting more votes than any other person is the majority.)    If a person is not elected as president in the election to elect the<n>president because of a tie vote, another nomination election is not required. The group can select the person receiving the next highest vote, assuming this person is not the same person nominated in the first election.<n>Choice B has all of our necessary steps to guarantee that a group  with X members will always pick a president. The main difference is that in the nomination election step,  B limits each member to nominating a specified number of eligible members, X or less.<n><n>1. Which process must you have to guarantee that the group will always select a president?<n>A. A majority selection after two election steps.<n>B. A majority selection after three election
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If you did well on the test, you might get an A as a what? Choices:  A: see work B: practice C: quiz D: school grade E: homework<n>Output:		A: If you did well on the quiz, then the final grade might be an A.<n>B: If you did well for practice, then the final grade is an A.<n>C: If you did well at school, the final grade is an an A or B.<n>D: If you did well in homework, then the final grade if an A.<n>E: If you did well overall, the final grade is a school grade.

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where is a fox likely to be caught? Choices:  A: tennessee B: inside joke C: grassy field D: the forrest E: england<n>Output:		Foxes are likely to be caught in a grassy field <<field>>, since we chose E.<n>So the final choice is "E"<n><n>Input: A local ice cream man has 64 ice cream bars to sell to children on the corner. One week, he sells twice as many to the boys as he does to the girls. How many of each did he sell the next week?<n>Output:The local ice cream man sells 2x the amount to boys. He sells 98 to girls, so he will sell (2 x 98) = <<98*2=196>>196 bars next week<n>So the final answer in 196<n><n>Input:  The chef has 65 eggs. However, they would rather get two dozen roses for $20. If the shopkeeper charges $1/flower for additional flowers, what is the cost of the additional flowers?<n>Output: The cost of the additional flowers = 8 * (8 + (20-8)/2-1 ) = <<8*(8+(20-8)/(2-1))=8*(9/3)=(9*3/3)=3*3=9>>9<n><n>Input: You have $58.62 at the beginning of the month, and another $58.63 at the end of the month. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What emotion does getting paid lead to? Choices:  A: sorrow B: paying bills C: happiness D: frustration E: spending money<n>Output:		Sorrow.<n>I got this question because I didn't know all the possible choices, but it was too obvious that it could only be B because sadness leads to spending money<n><n>Input: Two men, Rene and Peter, ran a race. The fastest runner Rene finished the race at 7 minutes. How much slower was Peter’s time if Rene finished at 7 minutes?<n>Output: Peter's time is a 100/7 = %%0.143%of Rene's time<n>Since Peter is only 100/8 = <<100/8=12.5%>>12.5% as fast as Rene, Peter finished the race at 8 minutes and 12.5 seconds<n>So the final answer was 112 and a half minutes.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Bob's feet hurt from running barefoot on the hot pavement. Choices:  A: large house B: suburban home C: big house D: old house E: keeping personal objects<n>Output:		A is 2 B is 3 C is 4 D is 5 E is 6 They moved out of the city. If there is 1 master bedroom, then it is <<2>>2 2 is  even, so A is even and B is odd.<n>If there is 2 master bedrooms, then it is <<3>>3 3 is odd, so C is odd and D is even.<n>If there is three or more master bedrooms, then (3 OR more) is 4 and (4 OR more) is 5, and E is even  Thus, they got a 1 master bedroom house.<n>So the final choice is A or B<n><n>Input: 17. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:James complained that Alexa's electric guitar was too loud and he couldn't get any work done at home,  so she decided that she should get an acoustic guitar.  Where might she look for one? Choices:  A: house B: music shop C: studio D: storage E: closet<n>Output:		If it's too loud,  we have 2 options:<n>Get an acoustic guitar or<n>Turn down the volume at the house<n>Option 1: Get an acoustic guitar = Acoustic guitar <-> <=>> house (If we play the guitar, there is a high decibel on the acoustic guitar) <n>Option 2: Turn down the volume at the music = Turn down the volume at = Acoustic guitar (If we play the acoustic guitar, it's not as loud as that of the electric guitar. So, turn down the loud volume of the electric guitar)<n>So the final answer should be C - Studio<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the questions<n><n>Question-1:<n>Write a Python program to determine how many friends were required to play volleyball.<n><n>Answer: You can ask the user how many volleyball teammates you need. For example, if I have 5 teammates, then I will need 5 volleyball courts. I will need to repeat this five times to determine the number of volleyball teams. I'll store the number of teams in a variable called "team count".<n><n>Here's how you write your program to figure out how many volleyball courts you'll need:<n><n>1. Make a variable called "num players" and ask the user to calculate how many players you have on your volleyball team.<n>2. Divide your number of players by 6, and that will tell you how many volleyball teams you need to play.<n>3. Ask the user to enter the number of players that they want to have on their volleyball team (if they want to have more than 6).<n>4. Repeat the above line and check to see if the number of volleybal players is divisible by 6.<n>5. If the number of volley bal players isn't divisible by 6, ask the user to try again.<n><n>Code:<n>    <n>    Enter name:<n>    Enter the the number of volley ball players<n>    Total number of players 0 < n < 6<n>    num players: 3<n><n>    print('total number of teams required', num of players, by 6, ( n/6, 'rounded',),)<n>    <n>    Total number of teams required 3 by 6 :
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What would happen to a person if his or her money is stolen? Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n>Output:		<<The final answer is E>><n><n>Input:A person’s money is stolen. He is feeling angry. He goes across the street to park his car and then he comes back. Then he crosses street and drinks tea. Complete the sentence.<n>Output: I think the answer is <<D>><n><n>Input: A person’s money is taken away by a thief. The person who is robbed feels anger and drinks tea. Then he comes to the library to study and crosses street again to park the car. Choose the correct sequence.<n>Output: <<The answer is C>><n><n>Input: Choose the correct sequence of events.1. You are robbed by a thief2. Then you feel angry3. you cross the street and park your car4. Then you get some tea at a tea house5. You go to library to study your next question6. You cross the street again to get home?<n>Output: <<The Answer is D>><n><n>Input: I was robbed by a bank. I came to the tea house to drink tea. Then I went to buy an umbrage. I come to cross the street to park my car. Finally, I came to my house.<n>Output: <<Answer is A>><n><n>Input: It is raining outside. When I was walking back home,I saw a cat sitting in the middle of the street. <<Choose the sentence with correct form>> 1.I cross the street, 2.I turn left and cross the street again 3. I go to the cat, and then cross the street <<You are a person in the story>> 4. The I park my car and walk back <<While walking back>> 5. I walk to my house <<And then I go to my house>><n>Output: <<The correct sentence is 4. The I cross the second street and park my car and walk>><n><n>Input: One day I was walking from my house to go to my school. It was a raining day but I decided not to take umbrella with me because I wanted to go fast. It was really hard for me to cross the street because the bus pass my side. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n>Output:		Weak<n>Answer must be 'weak'<n><n>Input: How much does the average person weigh? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is an area with no grass where I can get things to sell at a roadside stand? Choices:  A: surface of earth B: rest area C: supermarket D: state park E: garden<n>Output:		In A, the surface of the earth, there is land as the surface, but the area where no grass is (a roadside stand) may be anywhere.<n>Surface area of the planet is 508 million km2(area with grass), but its surface area is 510 million km2. The net difference in land is 1.96 billion km2, and if we subtract 1.96B km2 from 508M km2 (area with grass), we get 384M km2 (area where no grass)<n>In B, the rest area area, there is land, but the area where grass is restricted. The area where grass is not is limited<n>In C, the supermarket, there is land where grass is limited as well<n>In D, the state park, there is land for grass, but it is very limited, and the area where grass is not limited is more<n>In E, the garden, the entire area is restricted to grass<n>The answer is E: Gardens<n><n>Input: A car rental company charges 25 cents for the first hour and then 20 cents for each additional hour. If it costs a total of $9 to rent a car for a total of 2.5 hours, how much did it cost in the first hour?<n>Output: If it cost a total of $9 for 2.5 hours to rent a car, we get $25(1+20(2.5)) = <<25*(1+20*(2.5))=27>>1<n>So the final answer can be 2.5<n><n>Input: Peter and Susana were in California for a beach vacation and their total expenses were $1450. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Should they each pay their share based on the money they have? <n>If so, how much does each friend end up paying? Choices:  a: yes, each  pays their share b: yes, each pays their share<n>c: no, let ed pay the entire bill<n>d: no, let them split it equally among<n>e: no, let them each pay according to the amount<n>that they have<n>Output: a: yes, each pays there share<n>If Amy has $14 Carol has $8 Dave has $5 and Ed has $14 so $14 + 8 + 5 + 19 = 46<n>Because we also need to consider the cost of the meal, $46 should be divided by $4 = 11.5<n>So the cost of the meals are 46/11.5 = <<46/11 = 4>>4 so every one needs to pay 4 which is $<<14*4=56>>14 ed pays 19 and 56 divide by 4 = 14 so he has to pay $<< 14*4=20>>20 the remaining cost is 14 + Ed’s contribution is 66 so each should pay 3, $14, $8 and $5<n>So their final contribution should be: Ed’s: $<<20+8+14*4=126>>126 Amys: $<<14+4=18>>14 Carol: $<<8+4=12>>18 Dave: $<<8+8+19+14*4 =142>>142<n>Which is: Ed’s: 20 Amys: 18 Carol: 12 Dave's: 142<n>So the final choice is 142<n><n>Input: What is the next number in the sequence? {6, 2, 3, 4, 59

How many pieces of candy did  each student get?<n>Output:He gave 61/2 = <<61/2=30>>30 pieces per student<n>He gave the same amount of candies to each student so he gave 61 pieces to the other one.<n>Thus, the remaining 61/4 + 61/4 = 61/8 + 61/8 = <<61/8+61/8=55.5>>55.5 students.<n>So the final result is 55.5<n><n>Input: A man has a 3 gallon bucket and 9 gallon can. How much water does he need to transfer to the can? Choices: A: 5 gallon B: 1 gallon C: 4 gallon D: 2 gallon E: 3 gallon<n>Output: A man has a three gallon bucket. Let's take out 3/9 = <<3/9=1/3>>1/3 gallons from the bucket and transfer it to the nine gallon can.<n>This way he still has 3/9 of the original 3 gallon amount left.<n><n>Input:  If you walk 2 miles up the street and then 1 mile down How many miles is that? Choices: A 4 B: 3 C: 3 B: 3 D: 4 E: 3<n>Output: A man's walking 2 miles up the road and then 1 mile back<n>So he has walked for 3 miles.<n><n>Input: He wants to buy two different movies and one game. How many movies and how many games is he getting?<n>Output: He bought
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The electric motor powered many important things, including one if almost every house. Name this item? Choices:  A: electric locomotive B: electric typewriter C: multi-coloured walrus D: electric refrigerator E: electric drill<n>Output:		The electric drill<n><n>Answer:<n>D
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If I am a person, I have a unique ability to do what? Choices:  A: cross street B: stand upright C: speak spanish D: speak chinese E: further education<n>Output:		I have a unique ability, so my unique ability is to further education<n><n>Input: What is wrong with this sentence? Choices:  a: nothing b: a word is out of place c: the comma is in the wrong place d: the sentence lacks an adjective e: the sentence is missing a conjunction<n>Output: There is no capital letter before a comma<n>The original sentence was: "The dog walks slowly through the street to the bakery."<n>It should be "The dog, walks slowly through the streets to the bakery", not "The dog walks, slowly through the streets to bakery." If there is a subject and verb, the comma should precede.<n>So the final choice is E.<n><n>Input: I have a unique trait to my person. There is no one with the same trait that I possess. It is unique to me and me alone. Choices:  a.  I have a unique trait that makes me stand out from all other people. b.  I am a unique person. No other person has the same personality as I. c.  I am a special individual. d.  I am a very special person.<n>Output: A<n>"I am a special individual".<n>Since I have a unique trait, it defines the trait.<n><n>Input:  I've taken 5 online surveys.  Choices:  a - I've been paid $10 b - I'm going to be paid $10 c - I've already been paid $10<n>Output: B, I've been paid 10<n><n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:He waited for his friend at the squash court, but he was worried his friend thought he meant the at the other end of the public what? Choices:  A: country club B: rich person's house C: pool D: park E: fitness center<n>Output:		A: country club B C: rich person's home D: park E: place to get fit<n>He waited for his friend but his friend was at the country club.<n>So the final choice is option C: park<n><n>Input: The train ride from Boston to Toronto goes for many kilometers in total. For the ride, the passengers have a total of $320 in change to spend on food. The total cost of the food was $216. So how much did a single person spend on food?<n>Output: The train ride goes many kilometers in total, so the total change is $320.<n>Each of passengers has $320 / $<<320/$passenger=7.5>>7.5 total change which comes to $7.5.<n>Since the cost of the food is $7.5, the total amount is $320/(7.5 + $7.5) = <<320/(7+7.5)=$216>>$, so the total amount is $<n>So the final amount is: $ $<n><n>Input: How many cups of rice does Derek plan to buy if he is buying 18 eggs for 4.40 each?<n>Output: Derek is buying 15 eggs at 2.40 each, and 3 eggs that he got for free.<n>In all, he spent 18 * 4.40 = <<18*4.4=76.4>>76.4 dollars on eggs<n><n>But only 15 * 2.4 = <<15*2.4=36>>36 of the eggs were paid for, so the amount left over is $40, and $40/15 = <<40/15=2.67>>2.67 of each of the leftover 3 eggs were Derek's.<n><n>So the final answer 40<n><n>

What is the maximum number of names that can be included in the business’s name?<n>Output:<n>The max number of words is 9 because<n>A: 10 – 1 = <<10-1=9>>9<n>B: 10 – <<10-2=8>>8<n>C: 10 – <8 -1 =19>>19<n>D: 10 -<19 -2=30>>30<n>E: 10 –<30-2 =50>>50<n>F: 10 -<<50-2=58>>58<n>G: 10 -58 = <<10-58=48>>48<n>H: 10 -48 = <<10 - 48 = 60 >>60<n>I: 10 -60 = <<10-60=70>>70<n>J: 10 -70 = <<10 -70=80>>80<n>K: 10 -80 = <<10 – 80=90>>90<n>L: 9 <90-2 =98>>98<n>M: 9 -<<98-2=100>>100<n>O: 9 -100 = <<9 –100=109>>109<n>P: 9 -133 = <<9 - 133 = 152>>162<n>Q: 9 -40 = <<9 - 40 =51>>52<n>52, so the answer will be 52<n><n>Input:How should Tina organize her grocery shopping list? He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The camper looked up at the vast night sky, it left him feeling mighty what? Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n>Output:		The camper looked at the vast night sky which left him feeling <<"mighty"="insignificant">>insignificant.
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:To properly instruct children attending school you would need a great deal of what? Choices:  A: boredom B: patience C: time D: teachers E: inspiration<n>Output:		Boredom is needed for a child to attentively listen to the teacher. Inspiration is needed for the child to get excited about learning and try to learn<n>Teachers are needed for the children to learn properly but Patience is needed for a teacher to keep on teaching and not to get very irritated that the students are not paying attention, and time is needed for the students to learn more about the things they want to learn about.<n>Inspiration is needed for children to learn. So the final answer is inspiration.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The person put on lotion, what did they want? Choices:  A: fresh smell B: good credit C: smooth skin D: fresh produce E: headache<n>Output:		The person wants good credit<n><n>Input: Jake read 3 books in 4 days. He read 6 books in 9 days. Which statement describes the number of days to read the last 2 books in the month? Choices: A: 3 B: 4 C: 9 D: 8 E: 5<n>Output: Jake read 6 books in both 9 days and 12 days.<n><n>Input: Tracy has $100. If she buys a book at $20 and a sweater for $16, how much is left to add to her savings? Choices: A 40 B 34 C 24 D 34 E 32<n>Output: Tracy already has $100, so the $20 will leave $0 left. The sweater is $16 less, leaving $16. Tracy has $20 in the bank now, so Tracy has $28 of money left.<n><n>Input: Mary wants to buy bread for $3, milk for $4, and fruit for $5. How much does she need to spend? Choices: A $8 B $9 C $10 D $12 E $11<n>Output: Mary needs $3 + $4 + $5 = 12<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question.<n><n>## A friend and her mom were going to the zoo. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Mom is tidying a house, where would she put the loose dictionary? Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n>Output:		Mom could put the loose dictionary on A on her shelf, since the house is clean, but she put it on desk because she didn’t want lose the dictionary<n><n>Mom doesnʼt put it on a library because the dictionary is not useful. she never read a dictionary so she put it on desks. She is putting dictionaries on desks.<n><n><n>Input: How many days are there in 5 weeks?<n>Output: Monday through Sunday is Monday, Tuesday through SUNDAY, Monday through Saturday is SUNDAY, Sunday through Monday is Monday.<n>So the answer is 5 because SUNDAY comes before TUESDAY<n><n><n>Input: Auntie Joni's birthday is March 18th. If she’s 81 years old, how old is her mother?<n>Output: Auntie Jonian birthday is March 21 which means she is 6 days older then her mother.<n>Since she is 6 days old her mother is 6 days older so 6+18=24<n>So the final answer for what her mother's age is,<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Behind what small door are canned goods usually kept in? When you multiply two numbers together, you multiply the factors of the variables and the product is the result of the operations. So she buys 2x what she buys each week.
