If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is a living thing with a lip? Choices:  A: mouth B: can C: human D: snake E: kentucky fried chicken<n>Output:		A: mouth because the human mouth is an organ of the body which is 1 of many types of lips.<n>B: kentucky fred chicken is a mouthless animal, and C: snake is also a mouthless animal.<n>So the final choice is A: mouth.<n><n>Input: What is a living thing on a river? Choices: A: frog B: kentucky fry chicken C: human D: tree<n>Output: A: frog because the frog is a living thing on its own river.<n>B: human because the river is the river of life.<n>So the final choices is A: frog.<n><n>Input: A baseball game begins. After one innings, the score is 2-1. Each player is guaranteed 3 innings. After 2 innings, the score stands at 2-3. How big of an inning deficit must the current team have if they are trailing 2-1?<n>Output: The first score is 2-0, so each time the score changes, the score incrememts by 1 and the number of innings played increments by 3 because the 3 innings must be played for each score changed.<n>So if we compare 2-1 to 2-3, we can see that<n>$<<2-3>>_3 = <<2-2>> and $<<2-1>>_3 = <<1>>.<n>So 2 - _ inning defecit must the current team must have if they are trailing = <<1>> innings<n>So the final answer 1
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:If they were celebrating the occasion, how could the occasion be described? Choices:  A: drinking B: intimacy C: dancing D: happiness E: enjoyment<n>Output:		Start by listing down what we know:<n>We know that they were celebrating an occasion.<n>We know that happiness, having a good time, and dancing are options.<n>We know dancing is not the answer.<n>And we know that intimacy, drinking, and enjoyment are options.<n>So we could answer happiness, dancing, or enjoyment.<n>Choices:  D: happiness<n>Next, look back at the question.<n>The question asks how the occasion was described, so the answer must be a verbal description of the occasion. Happiness is not a verbal description, which narrows down the choices.<n>Next, look back one more time.<n>It asks: If they were celebrating the occurence, how could the occurrence be described?<n>Even though it says "occurrence" instead of "occasion", it's the same question. So they are still describing it.<n>The last time they narrowed down the options, so that leaves only two options:<n>1: The celebration lasted for awhile,<n>2: The celebration involved dancing<n>1:<n>The celebration lasted for <<awhile>>awhile, which leaves dancing as the only option.<n>2:<n>The celebration involved dancing, which leaves happiness as the only option.

By placing the black queen by the white bishop she has created a pincer on black row 5. If player B makes any move in row 6, student A can capture the bishop. If player B responds by placing a piece on row 5, the player A will capture both black pieces. He would get up in the morning, and then put them in what state again? Choices:  A: upside down B: in motion C: active D: wakefulness E: resthold<n>Output:		"in motion" is the correct answer.<n>The rubber balls were initially at rest, which means the state of them is at rest.  Therefore, the final state will be something other than "at rest".  The choices don't quite fit the problem structure, so consider that the bounce upwards is the opposite of a ball that previously rolled or bounced in the upward direction.  Then consider that once a ball is in motion, it will continue moving unless something stops it (this could be a collision with another object, hitting the bottom, etc.).  Therefore, "in motion" is true.<n><n>Input: Aaron made a snack to share with his classmates. He gave 26% of the snack to each of his classmates. So, Aaron has 6 classmates and 6 boxes, and each classmate gets 6 boxes / 6 classmates = 6/6 = <<1>>1 box.<n>Therefore, Aaron gave the boxes to his classmates such that each classmate got 6 boxes.<n>So the final correct answer is 6<n>

If bob has seven more than the smallest number he's ever had,  then what is the smallest number he'd ever had?<n>Output:Bob has 13 - jim has 18 - 13 x 18 = <<13*18=234>>234<n>Let jim be x<n>x = 18 - 234 = <<18-234=38>>38<n>To find smallest number ever seen, subtract:<n>- (x - 7 = <<(38-7)=31>>31<n>=7 less smaller number found before 31<n>Bob's smallest number = 31 + 3<n>Bob's smallest ever = <<31+3=34>>31<n>So answer is 34<n><n># Subtract 19 from both<n>Input: There is a candy jar. Its lowest number, x, is 16 and its highest number, y, is 20. What is the average (arithmetic mean) of the numbers in the candy jar?<n>Output: Let x = 16 and y = 20<n>So total: x + y = 36<n>Avg: (x+y) /2<n>If 36 is already divided by 2, it = 18<n>x+y = 18<n>So x = y = 18<n>Average = x + y /2<n>Average = 18 + 18 /2<n>Average
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What is not a safe way to transport jewelry on vacation? Choices:  A: suitcase B: department store C: safe deposit box D: these twos are not safe way to transport jewellery E: lady's boudoir<n>Output:		A is not a safe way.  The suitcase can be open easily<n>B is not a safe way also,<n>C is also not a safe way,<n>D is exactly the same as A since there are two ways to do the above.<n>E is not a safe way either.<n>Answer: E<n>So the final answer to the correct sequence of answer is D and E, and the final answer is E.<n>Since E is right, then the whole set of answer should be DE.<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:They launch a surprise attack, this ended the what? Choices:  A: surrender B: defence C: retreat D: cease fire E: defend<n>Output:		Surprise attack doesn't take a lot of preparation time, you either do it or you don't do it.<n>You either win or you don't win at all. So the answer is "surprise attack ended the A: victory B: surrender C: defense D: cease fire<n>So the final answer will be victory<n><n>Input: What is 3 x 3 x 3 =? Choices: Choices: 3 x 3 A: 9 B: 27 C: 12 D: 21<n>Output: 3 x 27 =<<12>>12x27 = 321<n>So the answer is 321<n><n>Input: What's 9 x 18 =? Choices: 9 x 1 B: 9 C: 17 D: 18 E: 19<n>Output: 9x18 =<<12>>21x18 = 321 <n>So the answer is answer is A: 9x1 B: 9<n><n>Input: What day did Mr. Punyet retire? Choices:  A: too much B: act dead C: die D: rush E: explode<n>Output:		We need to figure out which falls faster, 5 or 20.<n>We know 50 falls at 5mph and 25 falls at 20 mph.<n>Let's say it takes t seconds for the person to fall 50m, then they'll fall at 5mph.<n>So t = 50(20/5) = 200<n>The person will fall for 50 seconds, or else they'll die before they fall 50m.<n>Once you reach the ground, the person explodes.<n>So the final choice should be E because if it takes them too much time to fall, they die before they get to the ground.<n>So the final answe ris (E)<n><n>Input: One side of a square is 10 cm long. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:After new coke was discontinued what formula was used? Choices:  A: original B: old C: coke clear D: former E: familiar<n>Output:		Since Coca-Cola Classic was the same before they discontinued it, so C<n><n>Input:Choose two integers: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 <n>Which number is missing? Choices: A: 6, 7, 8, 9 C: 2, 8 D: 4, 12 E: None of the above<n>Output:Since 8 is missing from the list, so D<n><n>Input: Choose two angles: 25, 30, 35, 40, 60 <n>Which angle is missing? Choices (A) 50 (B) 45 (C) 20 (D) 10<n>Output:Since 45 is missing from the list (25, 35, and 60 were already there), so B<n><n>Input: Choices (A) -3 (B) -6 (C) -15 (D) -5<n><n>Output: Since D is the set of missing numbers and the missing number is -5, so D<n><n>Instant Answer:D<n><n>Input: Choice (A) 4 (B) 9 (C) 64<n>Output: Given that D+4=F, C is the answer.<n><n>Instant Answer:"4"<n><n>Input: Choosing the answer to this survey would require one to choose from the following options: (A) 48 (B) 6 (C) 2 (D) 1/3 (E) 12<n>Output:Since D is missing, so D<n><n><n>Instant Answer:(2)<n><n>Input:Choices (A) 121,31220 (B) 1,230256 (C) 56,10215 (D) 27,700243 (E) 2403<n>Output:Since C is missing from the list so E is the answer<n><n>Instant Answer=(2)
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Someone who doesn't care about about someone else and wishes them to fail has what feeling towards them? Choices:  A: unfeeling B: negligence C: antipathy D: indifferent E: rapport<n>Output:		The correct answer is 'B: negligence'. It means not meeting a particular standard or need.<n>Here someone who doesn’t care about someone else means not meeting a particular standards or needs by the other person.<n>Such people feel antipathy for others and do not wish them to be successful in their endeavors<n>Now I would need a new statement and answer choices
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:My favorite type of entertainment are rollercoasters and ferris wheels, where should I go? Choices:  A: theatre B: fairgrounds C: friend's house D: show E: casino<n>Output:		The words casino means gambling. There is a theme park, and it is possible to go roller coasters and ferrarwheels at the gambling theme park so I should go to the gambling theme part that has roller coasters since I like roller coaster and I hate gambling<n><n>Input:I need to figure out how much of a discount the gym will give me on my membership. I paid $380 to join, but the gym has a 20% discount for returning members. What is the amount of the discount?<n>Output:Let R be the amount of the disccount since for every x in C,.2x = R<n>Since 1 + 1 × (x/100) = 100%+1, R = 100/1 + (x/10)/100 = 99%<n>100% = 90% + (x/1) because 1 + 90 = 100, R is 90% for first time user and it will be ((x/10)*1) + 10 for returning member<n>So the final answer should be 0<n><n>Input: I have three pills and one pill has to be taken every 8 hours. I cannot take two pills in one hour. A friend offers to do the math for me to figure out which pill to take first. I have three pills that I can take in one hour. What equation do I need to solve? Input: I need to figure out how many pills I can take every hour so that I can solve the equation: (3/8)(x/3) + (3/8)(3-x) = 3<n>Output: I can take (3/8)(2/3) + (1/8)(0/3) = (9/24) + (8/24) = 17/24, I can take 17/25 pills in one hour because I can take 9/25 and 8/25, but I cannot take more than 1 pill every hour<n><n>Input: Tasha has $4 and her friend has $6, and they each have 2 apples that they can split to create a pizza. ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:James thought that giving the AI a secular upbringing would be the better choice.  He felt that the alternative might have results that were too what? Choices:  A: eternal B: religious C: unpredictable D: holy E: monastic<n>Output:		James thought that giving the AIs a secular upbrring would be better because it will result in E : Monastic<n>So the final answer for this question is D<n><n>Input: If Lydia paid a flat fee of $50 to ship her bike, she would make 50 cents in profit for every mile she sold it. If she has 853 miles of travel left on her bike, how much would she earn?<n>Output: If she sold her bike at ½ cents per mile that is 853mi x 0.50 = <<853mi*0.50=426.5>>426.5<n>So her total profit would be 426.5 X 50 = <<426.5X50=21.3>>21.3<n>So the final answer would be 21.3<n><n>Input: Mom gave each of her four children a flat rate of $20 to go on their field trip. She also charged a cost of $2 per mile for each child to drive. If the total flat rate, cost per mile driven, total mileage driven and profit were all given to the children, how much money would each child receive?<n>Output: Let the total given to all the children be T<n>Then the flat rate for each child is F<n>Then the cost of $2 per miles driven is M<n>Then the total mileage of each child is Mi<n>So T=Mi+F/Mi<n>Then the profit is T-Mi-F/Mi<n>So to solve this equation, use the variables Mi, M and F, since profit is not a variable, since it doesn't change.<n>So, Mi=T/F<n>M=Mi-T/(F/Mi)<n>And profit, let it be P<n>Then P=T-F<n>This works out to be T(1-Mi/F)-F<n>Solve for Mi by putting it into another equation<n>Mi=T/F-M(1-Mi/(F/Mi))<n>Solve this last equation for Mi to get P<n>Mi=T/(F-M+(T/F-M)(1-((T/F-M)/(F/(F-M))))<n>Put into another equation to solve for M<n>-F

If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:One way to relieve your hunger if you live near the coast is to do what? Choices:  A: grill B: go to market C: bring home fish D: eat hamburger E: make bread<n>Output:		If you live near the coast, instead of buying fish, you can just go fishing, catch your own fish and eat it.<n>So grill, market and hamburger are not the answer<n><n>Input: Two teachers at the school went out for lunch and each of them ordered 3 quesadillas. One of the teachers decided to buy lunch for her coworker and spent altogether $25. How much did the coworker spend?<n>Output:<n>When you divide $25 by 2, the answer is 12.5<n>So the coworker spent 12.5, and the the other teacher spent 12.<n>So the final  answer is 1<n><n>Input: One night, four astral beings arrive to this planet. There is a supernatural energy field and each of them can use one square of the field to teleport one mile. <n>They each have their own strategy to teleport the farthest possible. Write a script to determine which strategy is the best.<n>Output:<n>You start by calculating how many squares you will need.<n>Since there are 4 astral beings and they each need one square to teleport, 4 x 1 = <<4*1=4>>4  The field to teleport will need 4 squares<n><n>If you teleport in the same spot you start, you would need to use 2 squares<n>You would end up with 2 + 4 = <<2+4=6>>4 squares for teleporting<n>If you are teleported each square twice, you would end up with 1 + 2 + 4 + 8 = <<1+2+4+8=15>>15 squares<n>If you were only teleported twice you would end up with only 4 squares because the supernatural energy field only allows one square to cover multiple squares<n>But since you need 4 squares no matter what, to be the "strategy" <n> you just need to do 4 squares every time<n>So the answer is 4 <n><n>	You can use a simple for loop. You get to decide if you want to use the same variable to hold your value or have a new variable. <n><n>Input: A school has both first and second grade students enrolled. For its party, it is buying chocolate candies, gumballs, and cookies
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The shelf was showing signs of instability, what should the carpenter fix to avoid any issues? Choices:  A: roof B: corner C: school building D: wall E: cupboard<n>Output:		The correct answer would be C since it is the school building. Since what needs to be fixed is the school building, the carpenter should choose the school building on the shelf<n><n><n>

He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. Choices: 	mushrooms are fungi, both can cause food poisoning, and the both need a moist environment to grow.	mushrooms are not harmful, but bacteria makes you sick by turning food into a different smell.	mushrooms cannot grow on the ceiling, but both need darkness to grow.	microscopic fungus can only grown on your body's food, but bacteria can grow in your stomach.<n><n>Output: fungi cannot grow on your ceiling<n><n><n><n>Input:(A>B)>>C) Choices:  A > B > C, A > B, B > A, C > A, B > C, C > A<n>Output: A > B > C<n><n><n><n>Input:"I like to play tennis." "I like to play tennis with you." ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The crab was scuttling but strained when he moved, what was impeding him? Choices:  A: tide pool B: beach sand C: tidepools D: current E: cooking pot<n>Output:		When using ‘and’, then there must not be another word next to the and.<n>So he is scuttling but straining, not straining but scuttling.<n><n>Input: A 300 g block of cheese is cut into 9 equal pieces. Next, each piece is packaged into a 48 g package. How much does the cheese cost per gram when purchased from the cheese maker?<n>Output: The first thing to look at is that the amount of cheese and the amount of packages, since 9=<<9=4>>4, and 48 g means we have one package with 48 g cheese.<n>Then we need to get the 48 g/9 = <<48/9=5.33>>5.33 grams per piece of cheese when we cut it into 9 pieces.<n>We can buy 9 pieces and get 48 g of cheese. Each piece weighs 5.33 gram.<n>So we are now done with 9 pieces and each piece has 5.33 gr per piece.<n>We need to know how many pieces and what’s the weight of each package.<n>So we have the answer of 9 pieces and the weight of each piece is 5.33g.<n>So the next thing we can do is multiply how much cheese by how much piece is needed.<n>Since we need 9 equal pieces, hence all of the pieces weighs the same, so the weight is 5.3g/9g = <<5.3g/10=0.53>>0.53g<n>So the amount of cheese in each package is 9 x 0.53=<<9*0.53=4.97>>4.97<n>So the final answer in this part is 4.97<n><n>Input: What is the value of the expression: (7 + 2.63*0.93)*1.025/2.6%?<n>Output: We need to simplify the expression.<n>So 7-2.63*<0.93> = <<7-2.6*0.93=-2.18>>-2.18<n>The remaining expression is (7/1.025)-(2.18/
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What would you put in a container? Choices:  A: food B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: closet garage E: port<n>Output:		"A", "B", "C", "D", "E"<n><n>Input: When is a cow not a cow? Choices:  When it's a moo  When it's not a moo<n>Output: "Give up", "When it's a mo", "When it'S not a moo"<n><n>Input: What time is it, 6 o´clock? Choices:  Half five  Quarter seven Three to four Five after one<n>Output: "Half five", "Quarter seven", "Three to four", "Five after one"<n><n>Input: How is a rainbow made? Choices:  The sun lights a drop of water<n>Output: "Anna has a rainbow for you"<n><n>Input:What is the tallest mountain in the world? ### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers. Therefore, we should place all answers in parentheses: (A: frosting B : pasta C: icecream D: soda F: chips)<n>The list in parentheses contains soda, yogurt, and chips. The feeling that you have considered are soda and yogurt.<n>So the final questions is Icecream<n><n>Input: If there was a war between the United States and England, what would the United States lose in this hypothetical war? Choices:  W: the English language B: a friend C: the Boston accent D: our Englishness E: the English flag<n>Output: Here we are defining what the United States will lose by the end of the war, so we should place the answer in parentheses like this: (B: a friend C: The Boston Accent D: Englishness E: the english flag)<n>The options include the Boston accent and the English flag, hence the United States will lose our Englishness.<n>So the final question is United States will lose Our Englishness.<n><n>Input: There are some people who are upset with me and they don't like my friend. It feels like they are taking out my friend. Choices:  A group of friends B a community C individual D group E 6<n>Output:Here we consider the word "them" as they. This refers to the people who are upset and don't like my friemnd. There are choices for "they" are A group of friends and A community. Based on "they" are referring to A group of friends, we place a community which is on choice(D) in parentheses. Thus, this group of people will be a community who are in D.<n>So the final decision is The
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:What do people who are speech therapists do? Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n>Output:		They build houses<n>So the final answer must be E<n><n>Input: How do teachers get students to behave? Choices: <n>A: tell students to behave B: get students to act up C: threaten students with punishment D: show students how to behave E: use bribery<n>Output: Show students how to behave<n>So the final answer should be E<n><n>Input : What is 3/5?<n>Output : 0.6<n>
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:He had been doing favors for everybody at work, it was frustrating not getting any what for it? Choices:  A: let down B: respect C: illness D: satisfaction E: gratitude<n>Output:		He was disappointed because it was disrespectful, he was getting no gratitude for doing favors for everybody and it seems he did not want his gratitude.<n>Hence the answer is b<n><n>Input:Choices:  A: chicken B: puffer fish C: octopus D: cow E: whale  Question: How long will it take to fry this fish?<n>Output: It will take 34 mins to cook the puffer fish because Pufferfish takes around 34 to fry whereas Octopus will take 8 mins so the answer is 8 mins.<n>The answer is c<n>Input:Choices A:1 B: 2 C: 3 D: 4 E: 5 Question: How many weeks does it take to fry these fish? Output: Puffer fish takes 20 mins so it will take 4 weeks to fry, cow takes 50 minutes so it will take 2 weeks to fry, octopus 8 mins so it will also take 2 weeks and the final answer is 2w 2w 2<n>The answer is c.<n>

Last year, the number 22 was assigned to the team winning the state championship. Find how many teams were playing if in 2 years ago, a team had the number 33. (Hint: how can you count the number of teams?)<n>Output: The number of teams was 1 + 2 + 3 +....<n>Since the team 33 played 2 years ago, the team playing 1 year ago would be 33 - 2 = <<33-2=31>>31.<n>The team from the year before that would be 31 -1 = <<31-1=30>>30.<n>So we have 30 + 31 + 32 = <<30+31+32=94>>94 teams.<n>Since the team that has the 20 in 94 team = <<(20/2)=10>>10 the team has to have a 10<n>So the final answer has to be 10<n><n>### Inst
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The college kids weren't known for their apartment decor choices, they used a folding chair inside their what? The question was worded incorrectly.<n>This is a wrong answer, so the final answer is none.<n><n>#Import the required libraries<n>import sys<n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    sys.stdin = sys.argv[1]<n>    #Your code should go from this point down<n>    answer = 0<n>    while True:<n>        ans, ans_type = input().split(' ', 1)<n>        if ans == '1' and ans_type == 'number':<n>            answer = 1<n>        else: <n>            print("Invalid answer")<n>            print("Your score is", answer)<n>            sys.exit(0)<n><n>```
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:The sun was out and the temperature changing rapidly, it was really beginning to what? Choices:  A: drop to zero B: increase C: cool down D: dropping quickly E: heat up<n>Output:		The sun was out and the weather was very cold. The temperature will what down very quickly.<n>The answer is A: drop to zero<n><n>Input: Choose the answer that BEST completes the analogy.Choices: A: Insects B: Ecosystem C: Population D: Species E: Plant <n>Output: To complete the analogy, we choose D: Species or D: Plants. Insects can be said to be a species as it is a group of living organisms that are closely related to one another. On the other hand, ecosystems are living things together with the nonliving environment. Populations and species, on the other hand, are part of an ecosystem.<n><n>Input: Which best describes what the earthquake did? The earthquake hit ____. Choices: A: Cascadia, Washington B: Northern California C: the western United States D: Southern California C<n>Output: Based on the question, we can infer from the word “threw off” that the earthquake “moved” it because of the words “threw” which means to cause to move from one place, and “off” which means to cause something to leave the place where it was.<n><n>Input: _____ can make a huge difference in how plants grow. Choices: A: Rain B: High temperature C: Heavy wind D: Bright sun E: All of the above<n>Output: All of the above is the correct answer. Sunlight enables photosynthesis on the plants, heavy winds can damage the roots of the plant and blow them away, and extreme temperatures can kill the plant.<n><n>Input: Choices: The main character’s father dies in the story, after which she moves out to live in her grandparents’ home. What is the main conflict of the story?  Choices: A: The main character’ <n>Output: The story’s main conflict is the choice of the main character, after her father’s death, she has a choice to move in with her grandparents or her mom (A). Therefore, the answer is A: She chooses to live with her mom.<n><n>Input: What is the most probable cause of the fire? Choice: A: Accident B: Purposeful, deliberate C: Lightning strike D: All of the above E: Unknown<n>Output: The word
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:Where did his wife ask him to look first when he complained of missing deodorant? Choices:  A: grocery store B: nightstand C: armpits D: own bathroom E: medicine chest<n>Output:		He asked her if she took the deodorant or not. She said no. So, if she did not take it, then she would be the one looking for it since she took all the money from the piggy bank. Choice A: grocery/supermarket<n>Choice B: bedside table<n>Choice E: medicine cabinet, she said she wasn't home during the night time because she works late.<n>The answer for this questions is choice E: medicine cabinet<n><n>Input: At the circus, the performer is performing underneath the big tent. She has spiders that are tough enough to carry eggs, but they are too soft to kill the pests. If she carries out 8 spiders to do battle, how many spiders will the tent kill?<n>Output: First, divide each by 8 for easier counting.<n>The tent is going to kill.02 of the spiders.<n>The performer is going to kill.2 of the spiders leaving.18 of the spiders on her side.<n>There will be 8.18 = <<8*.18=1.4>>1.4 remaining spiders.<n>So the final Answer to this questions is 1.4
### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Output: He gets $1.5 per book because.01 x 150 = <<.01*150=1.5>>1.5<n>He earned $18 because 15 + 3 = <<15+3=18>>18<n>He read 12 books because 18 / 1.5 = <<18/1.5=12>>12<n>So the final answer is 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:When we are thankful for getting something what do we do? Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n>Output:		When we are thankful for something we do: A: Smile B: Show appreciation C: get something D: tell our loved ones E: show gratitude<n>So the final answer will be E: show gratitude.<n>

### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Output: If Hurley is 14 years old, and the difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20, Richard is 20+14 = <<20+14=34>>34<n>Forty years from now, Hurley will be 14+40 = <<14+40=54>>54 years old.<n>Richard will be 40+34 = <<40+34=74>>74 years forty years from now.<n>Their combined ages forty years from now will be 74+54 = <<74+54=128>>128 years<n>So the final answer is 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: meadow B: cupboard C: shed D: mail box E: cellar<n>Output:		I'm afraid of spiders. So I can choose A, B, C, D and E. So the final answer is E<n><n>Input:Its 1800 CST in Chicago. In both cases the three dimensional shapes add up to 2.<n><n>First I tried adding one sphere, one sphere and one cube to get 2<n>A: One cube, two spheres<n>B: One sphere, one cube, one sphere<n><n>Second I tried taking all the pieces and made one shape that equals 2 and put them to the side. I then considered all possibilities and found only H was a possibility<n><n>1)Cube + Sphere = 1<n>2)Cube + Spheres = 2<n>3)Sphere + Sphere + Sphere = 2<n>I then took the rest of the pieces and used a combination to get the total<n>1)Sphere + Spheres =

How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Output: Start by finding the total that is left, $1700 car price - $500 earned at car wash = $<<1700-500=1200>>1200 remaining.<n>So the six friends should pay $1200 / 6 people = $<<1200/6=200>>200 each.<n>Since Brad is not joining, then the 5 friends have to split Brad's share which is $200/5 = $<<200/5=40>>40 each.<n>So the final answer is 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Output: Her son has 3 teachers and her daughter has 4, so together they have 3+4 = <<3+4=7>>7 teachers<n>Harper has already spent $70 on 7 gifts, so she spent $70/7 = $<<70/7=10>>10 per gift<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input: The chef has 60 eggs. He puts 10 eggs in the fridge and uses the rest to make cakes. If he used 5 eggs to make one cake, how many cakes did the chef make?<n>Output: After putting 10 eggs in the fridge, the chef has 60 - 10 = <<60-10=50>>50 eggs left to make cakes.<n>Since it takes 5 eggs to make one cake, the chef can make 50 eggs ÷ 5 eggs per cake = <<50/5=10>>10 cakes.<n>So the final answer is 10<n><n>Input:A yard is made up of what? Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n>Output:		 A: YARDS DIFERENCIA SOLO A<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the question using a conditional statement.<n><n>Input: It is Monday. Tomorrow is Tuesday.  If it is Saturday, I can watch my favorite show. Otherwise I will clean the kitchen.  Which day does Tom like to clean the kitchen?<n>Output:  (Tom likes to clean the kitchen every other day, if it is Saturday then he will clean the kitchen, and if it is not Monday then he can watch his favorite show)  ==> Tuesday<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question using an if/else statement.<n><n>Input :The difference between the length and the width of  square foot space is 50 inches. If square foot space has a length that if 4 times that of its width, what is the width?<n>Output:  ==>  (4X <)   ==> 4X = 50 * 2<n><n>### Instroduction: Answer the question using a method that has been given to you.<n><n>Input: We have some apples and bananas.
